description:
Parking is easy and convenient.  

The selection and prices can NOT be beat.  

Best yet, the food was to die for!!  Would love to see them add a smoked salmon periogie to the selection.  :)
author: Marie T.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall bakery. The slightly dim, cool toned fluorescent lighting isn't really doing them any favors, but still manages to be cute. Lots of different items to choose from. The cashier was really nice helped me pick out some sweets and told me which were the most popular. I ended up getting the cherry filled donut, smoked salmon cake, strawberry & raspberry cake, and one that had chocolate mousse and vanilla custard (forgot what it was called). 

The two sweet cakes were the best out of the four my boyfriend and I tried. The chocolate one was soft and had a strong, deep chocolate flavor which I loved! This did result in it completely overpowering the vanilla, and due to lack of varying textures there was nothing to carry it through. If you love chocolate, you won't mind. The strawberry/raspberry was shaped like a strawberry which is so cute. It was fruity and delicious. No complaints. The smoked salmon wasn't very enjoyable because the cucumber came off too strong and the cake on the bottom was getting stale, I should have known better than to get a fish cake so late in the day :( (6:45ish) the cherry filled donut is a bit misleading... the donut is HUGE. So fluffy. There's some cherry filling sticking out on top. But the filling only goes in about an inch into the pastry!! It's more like a cherry topped donut. Not nearly enough to be able to eat it with the whole thing! If there was more filling it would be killer. 

Overall, a pretty good place.
author: Ronita S.

description:
Been coming here since I was a child nearly 30 years ago. Brought friends and family. Today I had a Cheburek with ground beef filling and it was raw. Brought it back to the cashier. He said nothing was wrong with it. 

This happened on 6/17/2018 Sunday at 11:45am. Cashier was a male with tattoos, poor English skills. 

So very disappointed. My favorite neighborhood Russian bakery..makes me not want to return. 

Stomach hurts. 

Baker from the back brought out a fresh tray and switched out the tray I purchased from. No business morales. 

Beware!!!
author: Tracy N.

description:
"Red wine with fish. Well that should have told me something..." - James Bond 007 

When in Moscow do what the locals do... Piroshki! 

I was told Moscow & Tbilisi has the best Piroshki west of Moscow. Hmm, well although Sasha was a stunner in any universe, I'd have to say the Piroshki is still subjective. Don't get me wrong it was delicious, affordable, and humungous, yet... it didn't quite blow me away, nonetheless 100% legit! 

So on a chilly last day in May I decide to drop by, tbh I might have been here before since I love all things Russian, ahem, sans POTUS, but I'm not sure if I have. Oh well, I lace up my bearskin moccasins and head to the Outer Richmond District of San Francisco where Sasha will be waiting for me... well in my From Russia with Love dreams, hey...

I enter to a slightly Kremlin feel. Y'know five walls and one window type of feel, but yet still not Siberia! On the left a myriad of Russian baked /fried goods. On the right side local Russian comrades reading the newspaper. Sasha greets me and I order a Beef & Cheese Piroshki, Potato Piroshki, and a cup of hot Chamomile Tea. Sasha efficiently heats up the Piroshkis and before I can say "Hey Baby, what's your sign-ski..." it's bagged & ready to go! As Sasha closes with "enjoy!" Soo Smooth lol.

I find my seat, in between the macho comrades, and take a few sips of the tea before digging-in. I immediately notice how huge they are... so I cut-it in halves saving the other half for later. I start with the Beef & Cheese, then the Potato... it's ok. Good enough, but I admit not the best, ever! Maybe it makes my top 3, yet I admit the proportions are huge here! Definitely try it once if you love Piroshki! 

All in all, a legit Russian bakery in the Russian neighborhood of the Richmond District, U.S.S.R. My favorite Russian bakery is still Cinderella, but I admit Sasha was definitely worthy of a role in From Russia with Love starring... Eric Robert-ski, of course;)
author: Eric R.

description: So I compared this place to the worlds famous piroshky piroshky in Seattle pike place.   This one at Moscow takes it hands down.   The meat and cheese melted in my mouth and it was just pure deliciousness.   Loved this place!
author: Mo T.

description:
Cheese proshki is out always. Make some more, keep up with the demand. Potato cake is also good. 
Eat 3 proshkis everyday for a year, heart attack guaranteed! Oily, unhealthy deliciousness...
author: Ricky G.

description: I'm in love. The best piroshkis to satisfy your savory fried dough needs for $3. Also tried the chebureks -- same piroshki beef filling but more crispy -- good but I still prefer the piroshkis more... so good... you need a few piroshkis in your life
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
My friend was looking for the best Piroshki in San Franciso and got turned on to this amazing little Russian Bakery!  We had to troll to find parking, but hunting for a space was so worth it!

The baked goods here are a treat for both the eyes and the taste buds!  Gorgeous treats, savory and sweet.. many look too nice to eat!  But, you'll want to try them all, and with their prices, you can afford to try quite a few!

Being on the hunt for Piroshki, we were not disappointed.  There were at least 6 different kinds, so, we got one of each.  We shared a meat and cheese one while on the road north, and... ohh my!  I'd never had a piroshki... and this one may have ruined me for all others!

My only regret was not getting a few of their sweets... I had no idea what half of them were but, wow... so pretty!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
**10$minimum for credit cards!!

Cheap/unique pastries with a few seating areas inside. It's always pretty empty no matter when I go.

My favorites are their napoleons, prioshkis, and binses! So soft and not overly sweet. Prioshki is greasy but is so chewy and boingy. i LOVE it because it keeps the filling flavorful and juicy( i'd get the beef or beef and cheese, the mushroom egg is drier and less flavorful). ALSO everyone one of these pastries seem to taste better the next day after being in the fridge 

Not everything is amazing though, I was not a huge fan of their mousse chocolate mint pastry despite how sparkly and pretty it was. I might have also tried a mango cake and didnt like it . All in all, I would avoid the pretty cakes. Their chocolate pastry was also dry and not very flavorful.

I want to try other things but it's risky trying something new here :/ The breads are cheap and huge but I'm not a bread person; I always see people buying them though so I bet they are good as well.
author: Lydia Z.

description: I've been coming here since I was a kid but I hadn't been back in years due to my hate for driving to San Francisco now as an adult. I was in town to pick up a friend and thought of this place so we went and I'm so happy to see there hasn't been a decline in quality at all. Everything we got was just as deliscous as ever. Next time I want to buy like 20 of the almond horns and freeze them at home they are so good. The man at the counter was super nice as well dealing with me and my indecisive friends. I'd drive back to SF just to come here
author: Adelita F.

description: I used to like this place a lot.  I still like them quite a bit, for what they offer, but just not as much as before.  It seems, that their prices have gone up.  The selection for certain baked goods can be hit or miss sometimes.  (I've noticed, that quite a few of these eastern european food businesses in Little Russia sell outdated or old items.  So, buyer beware.)  This bakery should try to maintain an only fresh policy for baked goods, since flavor and quality diminish, with a longer shelf life.  They do offer an interesting eastern european take on pastries, cakes, cookies, and some deli items, which makes them more exotic, rather than what we are usually accustomed to in western (european) influenced bakeries.  (French, in my book, is always (pun intended) going to take the cake!)  I love that SF has neighborhoods and districts, which includes "Little Russia".  It's nice to have diversity in offerings and choices from around the world.  Spasibo.
author: Zeoki A.

description: Very good food for a reasonable price. I ordered the meat piroshki and an cherry turnover and both were good. There was a decent amount of food with very good taste. Very light and fluffy breading on the outside with juicy meat and great tasting sauce inside. The cherry turnover was very good also basically what you would expect from a turnover and full of filling. If you come to this area definitely check it out and order something you will not regret it.
author: Taylor N.

description: Omg so we were walking down the street and this man was holding a 'piroshki' I think that's how you spell it. It smelt amazing so we found where this bakery was and let me tell you! This is the most amazing thing I ever had In my life . I'll def be back to SF for one of these
author: Janina M.

description: One can eat-in at the place, they have a few tables set up and offer tea or coffee and a limited selection of Softdrinks from a reach-in cooler. Great unique pastry items.
author: Pavel P.

description:
Piroshki with beef ($2.75): DELICIOUS! ask for it to be warmed up because it'll be extra good!! The dough is really tasty and soft and the minced beef is simple but yet full of flavor!! the size of this piroshki is so big too for its price! worth

Piroshki with potato ($2.75): This piroshki is filled with mashed potato and it's super filling. It's super good to eat it with the beef piroshki mmmm
author: Daisy M.

description:
One of my favorite places to get piroshkis.  They're big, a good price, and so filling.  They taste so good, even the next day.  I tried the potato one and the filling was so tasteful, and the bread was so good.

There's also an assortment of cakes.  So many to choose and they all look so good.  However, they weren't as good as they looked.  Not overly sweet, but the cake I chose was a bit stale tasting.

I'm definitely coming back for more piroshkis.  And perhaps picking a better cake to try.
author: Karen L.

description: Lots of stuff to choose from. Great selection. Poorly lit space. I enjoyed the cherry roll. It was a bit messy, but worth it.
author: Harper C.

description:
I wanted something sweet. Since I had a DoorDash code for free delivery, the roommate and I decided to order from Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery. We place the order on Sunday, March 26th at 5:20pm. It arrived at 6:15pm. We live in Outer Richmond.

*Chocolate Croissant ($1.75)
*Strawberry Croissant ($1.75)
*Donut with Custard Cream ($2)
*Donut with Cherry ($2)
*Eclair ($3.50)
*Khachapuri with Cheese ($5)
*Piroshki with Beef & Cheese ($2.50) ×2

I actually ended up enjoying the savory food more than the sweets. That beef and cheese piroshki? So good! Who doesn't love a fried meat donut?! And the khachapuri. Tasted like deep fried cheese in a flaky pastry. Yum! Out of the sweets, I really enjoyed the eclair and the custard donut. The donut was fluffy and the eclair had a nice chewy shell. Though I did think the custard had a slight artificial flavor.

I would come back again and again for those piroshkis. And such a good deal at $2.50.
author: Elena N.

description: This is an old school bakery that Western Asian families and grandmas hang out at. When I stopped by for a small treat on a walk there were two Russian grandmas chatting with the cashier in Russian and a small family with a young child sitting at one of the tables. Every baked good here is huge, i mean totally huge, meant to be shared among 2 to 3 people! I got the smallest thing avail, their farmer's cheese croissant for $1 and would recommend
author: Meryam B.

description:
I was in the mood for a quite bite to eat and was in the area so decided to try this place out. The bakery is quaint and has a familiar vibe. Service is good. I ordered a cabbage and beef+cheese piroshki (warmed up) to enjoy. I took a couple of bites out of the beef+cheese and was not a fan. Maybe I didn't feel like beef or it just tasted off to me. The cabbage and the dough itself is DELICIOUS! I would totally recommend trying it. 

I also bought a small poppy roll and bird milk to take home. My family enjoyed both! Just a warning to others - if you don't like poppyseed, you will not enjoy the roll. It has WAY too much poppy, which wasn't a problem for us since we like it. Others may not like the bitterness that too much poppyseed creates though.
author: Anna M.

description: Been going here since i was little and being part Jewish and Ukrainian on my moms side, I can attest they make some of the most authentic Piroski's, blintzes and other baked goods. Places that make baked Piroski's are simply catering to Americans as its unheard of them being baked that way by those born in those countries. They also carry poppy seed rolls which are delicious and hard to find. I wouldn't call the service very friendly or patient as thats just their mentality but i simply go for the food. Prices have gone up from the dirt cheap under $2 bucks a Piroski used to cost but its comparable with other places like Cinderella Bakery, although, I don't like the filling of theirs as much and find them to be smaller. Overall, i highly recommend this place for a tasty, still pretty cheap and very greasy lunch!
author: Petra S.

description: I love the piroshkis here. Have tried almost every variety, and liked them all. Plus, you really can't beat the price. Took my son, niece and nephew, here for a quick bite the other day. 4 piroshkis and 4 drinks under $15! Where else in this city can you do that? Staff is always super friendly, bathrooms are always clean.  What more could you ask for?
author: Monica F.

description: This is my favorite Russian bakery my mom has been going here for us since we were little girls that was over 20 years ago I still stop by every blue moon to get a couple of my favorites piroshki and bliss ( Probably spelled wrong) I buy some for the road to bring to my sisters to enjoy. Can't come to often because they're addictive. I've made so many people fall n love with their food
author: Elisha A.

description: Yo I ain't never been here before but I had the beef and cheese polshki. That dish was fire!! I love new food so it was nice trying. Something Russian! Highly recommend with the pear drink. Straight Russian bakery went hard
author: Sean M.

description:
i was THIS ffffn close to getting our country's 1st ever white woman pastries.

but then i swear this bakery hacked my lunch.

suddenly i held a $21 bag of russian baked / meated / cheesed foods.

all my baked stuff was inexpensive & big.

everything tasted "ordinary" in a good way.

aka what you'd get in an authentic russian grandma's kitchen.

if your russian grandma is PUTINNNNNN!! jkplzdntkillme
author: Dan B.

description:
Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery is the best traditional Slavic store...
I love this store it brings so much memories...
For last 15 years every time I'm in San Francisco we always stop by it's like a must..
It's our little tradition.
Good service...
Good food 
Best  Peroshki ever 
So much varieties to choose from 
Always fresh...
I would eat them
in a small, white bowl,
the dumplings slathered in sour cream.
I would lean into the steam, 
savoring each bite
until a great sigh escaped my lips.
Only afterwards would i speak:
maybe a funny story
or a joke
or some explanation of how a camera worked
or what history has to teach us
this day. We would eat his words
in enormous bites
until we, too, had taken our fill.
This, this
is what I miss.
author: Igor O.

description: Fave Russian bakery in San Francisco! The piroshki are seasoned to perfection and can't get enough of the Russian sweets and pastries! The meringue and poppy seed ones are my fave!
author: Alena P.

description: We grew in Russia and when we saw the variety of great looking and reasonably priced pastries, we jumped on it with excitement! Do not buy there!!! Terrible quality, not fresh staff... unfortunately.
author: Oleg K.

description:
They've been there for a very long time to get a good read product the pastries I would probably say two or three stars but the bread is four to five stars.
Quality is nice on most of their product they have a fresh bread.
Would be nice if they would have something kosher but overall it's a good
author: Yevgeny D.

description:
*** In Short ***

Cheap, filling, and tasty piroshki.

*** In Depth ***

While they carry a lot of other tasty looking pastries and desserts, having just come from dim sum across the street, I wasn't in the mood to further stuff myself. But hey, piroshki reheats well, right?

Well, not quite, since M&T's are deep fried, and a toaster oven's got nothing on that. That said, considering that they were still so tasty even given the sub par reheating treatment, I can only imagine how much tastier they'd be if you came in and had them fresh. Meat and cheese is a solid choice, and if you're like me and love carbs, so is the potato!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Pretty typical bakery layout with the high glass counters running along two edges of the space, so you may have a little trouble seeing things towards the top, but there's a lower counter to the side to pay and collect your treats. And while I didn't stick around to eat in the shop, there are plenty of round two tops that are accessible as, well, round two tops usually are with the giant pole down the middle.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Found this on yelp I was trying to find a place to wait out the traffic and saw this piroshky place.  I never knew there was a piroshky place in outer richmond, seems like a random area. 

Check in for 10% off a purchase of  $10 or more.

They have a decent selection of piroshky, and sweets. I got two piroshky, a slice of cake, a passionfruit dessert, and a creme Brulee. 

The piroshky are pretty oily compared to other ones I have had. They taste way better warm, so I brought it home and put it in the oven.  The filling is generous and these will keep you full for several hours.  The desserts were kind of stale and forgettable. I will stick to their piroshky next time.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Just the worst bakery I've ever tried.  This is the second time I've come here and the service is great, the place is clean but the pastries are the worst.  
I bought a slice of cake that tasted like it had been there for over a week.  The apple figure pastry looks great but was disgusting and unedible.  Unfortunately I have to give them a 1 as their sweets are not fresh, nor are they a good value for the quality you get.  I recommend Priscilla's a few blocks away.
author: Eduardo M.

description: More than a bakery, its an experience.  I like that the people working there actually speak russian, its not some generic place, its genuine russian.  I sat here ate my food and drank my coffee. Yes there are tables to sit.   The place stays busy, people in and out one after another, this means the food is fresh, I had Cheburek.  Enjoyed it.
author: Serge D.

description: This place was amazing. I love their poppy seed cake filled with (seems like) millions of poppy seeds. Great customer service and nice variety of cakes and pastries!  Will visit again soon.
author: rado l.

description: Grabbed some rugelach. Bad is an understatement. Truly, deeply awful. I don't know if it was a few days old or just generally bad. Truly truly disgusting. Poppyseed and chocolate. Both awful. Dough on was stale and clumpy; not a good texture. Horrible texture. The chocolate tasted like really low quality syrup or something.
author: Ryan B.

description: What is not to like about this bakery!  Its good that I live far away from it or I'll be going there everyday.  Addictive fresh Piroshki, hot from the kitchen, and the cherry donut or the big cherry roll always hits the spot.   Its never too sweet just the way I like it so I can eat more.
author: Mar H.

description: Ooooooo mama. Good bakery. The beef and cheese piroshki is  and we took a bunch of things Home with us, heated it up next day and were absolutely in awe. Forgot what it was called but some square pastry filled with cheese was ahmayzing. Enough for 4 people to snack on. They have salads, soups, other Russian goodies that I'm sure are very good but didn't try them. The desert display all the way to the right looked super delicious, I envy those of you who live near this place.
author: Arthur G.

description:
Nice little bakery with lots of different baked goods. I ordered the beef and cheese piroshki. First thing I noticed was how oily these piroshkis are. I bought two to go and by the time I got home, the paper bag was soaked with oil all around. 

Despite all the oil, I would say that it's pretty good. Not exactly sure which cheese was used but it's baked into the bread a bit inside and makes the bread soft. Also, such a great deal! Only $2.50 for one and they're quite large too.
author: Annie H.

description: Just by chance was walking in the neighborhood and saw this Russian pastry shop.  Oh my!!  Was shocked by all the goodies it had.  It was filled with various desserts, breads,  soups, filled rolled cabbages, piroshkis, pelmenis and apple strudels.  It was like walking into a Russian candy shop.  The prices were very reasonable.   Plus, they r opened 7 days a week from 7am - 9pm.  However,  if u come after 5pm, a lot of food may be sold out. . I would definitely come back to get more Russian goodies next time I am in town..
author: Mei W.

description:
Do I even want to let you guys know how great this place is?
I love the no-nonsense employees, but mostly I love the Poppyseed roll. 
Oh, it is the poppyseed pastry of dreams.
But all their sweets are tasty. Good solid Russian/Georgian stuff, lots of which reminds me of my childhood. 
I recently bought enough pastry to feed my whole office of 15 people - it was cheaper than getting bagels for the gang. 
And way, way tastier.
Be adventurous, try the farmer's cheese and raisins pastry, as well as some of the tried and true stuff.
You won't be sorry!
author: Rachel M.

description: I go to this bakery all the time when I can for all of those favorite childhood desserts! They have an amazing section of cakes. Bird Milk would be my all time favorite. I would always order one whole cake for my birthday. It has many thin layers and is very moist on the inside. Recommend!
author: Oxana S.

description: Fresh beef and cheese piroshky for 3.50? Yes please. Will come again to try other flavors.
author: Karen C.

description:
I must have passed by this somewhat dated-looking Russian bakery many times without taking much notice. When curiosity finally struck, coupled with my desire to try more bakeries, I finally stepped inside and was pleased to discover their expansive display case filled with delicious-looking baked goods. Most of the items looked familiar, but none of the names did.

I ordered an almond horn and something called a mishka. The almond horn looks a little like a cannoli, but it didn't taste too interesting. The shell seemed a little soft and the filling wasn't too special. The mishka looks like a cross between a napoleon and tiramisu. I thought the layers of sponge cake were a little to dry. I felt like I needed something to drink afterwards. 

I'd say both of those were not bad, but I'd need to try a few more items to fully assess how I feel about this place. Too bad I don't know where to begin to order. Based on the two pastries, I give it a 7/10.
author: Joy W.

description:
Most of my 1980s elementary school cafeteria ladies were from the Eastern European block. It was common for them to add their own touches to our rotating breakfast and lunch calendar. I ate breakfast at school most days because my mom worked 12-hour shifts. Fridays were the best because we had golden foil wrapped peanut butter and jelly graham cracker sandwiches for breakfast and piroshkis for lunch. I loved those damn piroshkis. Potatoes stuffed into a potato pocket?! Uhh, yes! Fuck the chocolate milk, the fruit cup and whatever else was on my tray; I'd trade it all in for another piroshki. Piroshkis sent me into a gorda frenzy. My mother would have been terrified to see her child clambering and begging down the aisle of the cafegymatorium tables for piroshkis. Soft potato pillow pockets stuffed with ground beef, onion, potatoes and cheese. Although these had a sort of grainy exterior, the inside was rich and moist. 

Moscow & Tbilisi is a small bakery, with a large kitchen. The delights behind the counter are impressive: apricot roll, black sesame pastries, cinnamon and walnut danish, napoleons, cakes and lots of choices of piroshki. 

I sat near the counter and set to demolish the $2.50 beef and cheese piroshki, a long sphere of fried dough and meat. It was exactly as I remembered it in elementary school. The dough was chewy and tender and filled with webs of gluten development. These cheese was possibly a type of quark: ultra tangy, white, fresh and not unlike farmer's cheese. The ground beef was rich. I just wish there was more of the filling. It was still satisfying. Enough to put a smile on my face, something missing from my repertoire that week. 

Limited inside seating. Comfortable for gordas. But, you don't want to come here.
author: Illyanna M.

description:
The piroshkies sold here are amazing !!!  I usually come here when I need to purchase a large quantity of piroshkies for families and friends when they come over for the holidays.  I came in yesterday to purchase some piroshkies (my favorite is the one with meat) and the lady at the counter was exceptionally helpful.  I couldn't decide how many to purchase so I asked her how many fit in a box.  She showed me 2 different sized boxes and I chose the larger one which fit 20 piroshkies.  There were not enough meat piroshkies in the display, so she went in the back kitchen and brought back a full tray.  I purchased my 20 piroshkies ($50) and returned home.

I packaged 5 for me to save and 5 for my brother to take with him when he went hunting the next day.  I left the other 10 on the table on a platter and everyone who came by that day wanted to taste them (either a whole one or a half one).  Several people who came by looked at them and said, "what is that?  can I have one?"  Even the people who work out frequently wanted to taste the delicious piroshky - the comment was "I worked out today, I can eat this."

By the end of the day, all of the piroshkies were gone, but I still have my bag of 5 piroshkies for another day.

I might have to come back here soon to purchase more piroshkies to put in the freezer....
author: Antonia M.

description:
Bakery/delicatessen with some outstanding items. 'Moscow and Tbilisi' refers to the capital cities of Russia and Georgia respectively. That would be 'Georgia', a nation in the Caucasus, right?
My faves 
(plz forgive bad Russian):
Cheburecki (): fried bread pockets loaded with herbed-up lamb;
Kharcho (), spicy beef and rice soup flavored with tart plums sauce (tkemali) and spices;
Pirozhki with Mushrooms (  )

Perhaps not exactly health food, but SO good!
author: J.Fred D.

description:
3-4 stars for the almond horn and piroshki, but the rest of the items were very mediocre. We came in on a Sunday afternoon, and it was pretty quiet during that time. We tried:

-Beef & Cheese Piroshki ($2.50, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3yKR6L8dTgoTZ93cj0Wq_g&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Pretty good, and you get a giant piroshki for the price. There was a decent amount of filling, and it had good flavor.

From L to R: Poppy Seed Cake ($3.50), Vanilla Meringue, Almond Horn ($3.50) [http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gq_sLMOY58E8dyVjMX3_pA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]
-Almond Horn ($3.50): Pretty good- it's like a Lacey's cookie wrapped into a roll and then filled with whipped cream. I liked the crunch of it.
-Poppy Seed Cake ($3.50): Yuck- this was super dry and crumbly, and not sweet. I didn't like this at all.
-Vanilla Meringue: I'm not a fan of meringue and just tried a small piece, but didn't like it. 

Service isn't very friendly here, but I appreciated that all the items were clearly labeled with the prices. I would consider coming back for the piroshkis and to try some of their other items, but would definitely skip the poppy seed cake in the future! Parking can be tough since street parking is limited.
author: Amy D.

description: This is my probably favorite neighbourhood cafe -bakery in town together with the oasis cafe in Oakland....great cakes ,pastries selection always very fresh !they put out the bread every morning -,No exceptions -I've been buying there with years since I live across the street in a regular customer I adore their sun shine prioleti Napoleon and PEOPLE YOU HAVEEE TO TRY THEIR  Authentic PIROGI AND GEORGIAN CATERING FOod THAT THEY MAKE BY ORDER .. ITS OUT OF THESE WORLD! I was recommended by a Russian friend- great prices very friendly service -their staff are awesome and patient;I had stuffed cabbage GEORGIAN stuffed eggplants tried all their cakes  rye bread and apple strudel ate mu favI'm so happy with my catering g order .for my birthday ...love u Russian bakery , thanks for being in my neighborhood
author: Tina R.

description: Very impressive cakes etc, great quality and very friendly crew. All fresh and beautiful
author: Ben R.

description:
Neighborhood place, check.
Pastries, check.
Piroshky, triple check.
While shopping in the area, my friend suggested stopping here.  Being my first visit, I was surprised to find a pretty good crowd of sit down diners and shoppers like us on a weekday afternoon.  I saw plates of cabbage rolls and piroshkies on customers' tables and a good variety of pastries in their three or four display cases.  
Needless to say, the mushroom piroshky was my take-home choice since we'd just finished lunch before coming here.  My friend saw an attractive cake which I took home for my family.  I can't remember what it was, but it disappeared in two days... the family devoured that cake.  Will update the identity of that when I return in the next week of so.
I reheated my piroshky at home in the toaster and it reminded me of a chewy version of the crullers (bread sticks in Chinese restaurants that accompany porridge - jook).  I was not disappointed as the mushroom filling (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5YZXEOof6cTW49rrJb-ybA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) was nicely flavored and balanced well with the bread.
As mentioned, hoping to stop in there again this week.
Check check.
author: Mike C.

description: Finding good piroshki in Santa Clara County is as hard as finding parking in SF!  This spot has solved all my problems.  They sell the best piroshki I've ever had.  I usually go there once a month, and buy a dozen or so to freeze at home.  My favorites are the beef and cheese, and mushroom and egg.  The price of their items is very reasonable considering SF, and the people are very cordial.  Okay, the bakery hasn't solved all my problems - the parking is really, really tough.  Well worth the effort, and to those that live in SF - take MUNI - they need your business!
author: Tom M.

description: The service was excellent. I had the little mousse cakes and omg they melted into my mouth it was so delicious and sweet!!!! It's so beautiful
author: Abigail S.

description:
Been a few years since I've been back here and ta da!  They finally have beef AND cheese piroshkis.  Interesting choice to go with feta cheese in their filling.  Which isn't a great melting cheese in my opinion but delicious nonetheless.  

I had never had their beef chebureks before until my last time here.  It's not as doughy as their piroshki but it's flaky and filling.  Just wrap it over two napkins to soak up the grease.  Before you crush it!
author: David C.

description: My favorite place to get authentic Poroski. I get the mushroom and cheese. I also the beef and cheese. It can be reheated but I prefer to get them toasted so the outside is nice and crispy.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Five pastries and three coffees for $14. Unbelievable. Desserts are mostly really tasty and always fresh. They also have some interesting deli salads.
author: Mark F.

description: This is a great place to go if you would like to try some Russian/East European food. They offer a variety of selections including traditional Russian salads and soup, cookies, bread and pastries, fried dough stuff, cakes, etc. They all taste good and the price is very reasonable. The size of their bread is very big. I really love their poppy seed pastry and the cheese and raisin bread. Their piroshkis are popular, with many different types of filling. I would personally prefer to have thinner doughs for piroshkis, but maybe that's just what piroshkis are like.
author: Melody H.

description: Love the cabbage piroshki and cream horns. Would suggest skipping some of the more random items like salmon cake. But the pirohskis are to die for - and the perfect snack on-the-go. Great before catching a 38 bus.
author: Levi F.

description: I went here specifically for the Georgian cheese bread. The bread was much flakier than others I have tasted. The filling of cheese was good but average. The bakery itself offers many other traditional pastry. I don't think I will go out of my way to try this place again.
author: Erin J.

description:
Friend and I walked down Geary discovering all these amazing Russian gems! This place was known for their Piroshky so of course I had to try one. We got one beef and one potato and it was so yummy!! Make sure you eat this fresh or retoasted in the oven. The Piroshky breading soaks up all the juices from the filling, it's wonderful. This hearty treat only runs u back $2.50. 

Service was great, too! $5 minimum for card.
author: Oanh L.

description:
We were looking to grab a quick breakfast before heading out to Lands End. Yelp pointed us to this bakery. I figured it's different and why not give it a try. We walked in and felt a little lost. The woman working there was really helpful and tried to explain the options to us and recommended some first timer items. We ended up with a huge beef cheburek and an apple turnover.

The cheburek was enough for a meal and while it was tasty, it was a bit oily and heavy. I'm sure that's how it's supposed to taste though. The apple turnover was rather standard. 

Not bad for a few dollars and a few minutes of our time.
author: Yi Z.

description: I've been coming to this place for over 20 years. I love this bakery. They make the best stuff.  I love how they're open late making it really easy for me to stop in last minute. I always pick up the poppyseed bread.
author: Leah L.

description:
This is a comfortable place in a great area.  The tastes are slightly different than you'd expect from a "regular" bakery. Cherry Turnovers are  huge, soft, flakey and delicious!! A :cheese and raisin danish is made of a fluffy, slightly sweet bread and a cheese I'm unfamiliar with, but it's delicious, We also sampled the poppy seed roll and found it heavier on the seeds than we are used to seeing.  

All in all, it's worth a visit.  Next time I'm going to try the Piroshkies based on the rave reviews on yelp.  See you there!
author: Cassandra C.

description:
My baked goods were paid for by a super generous male that was a regular at the shop. He originally wanted to purchase a Napoleon for me while I already (almost) purchased my Rose. It seemed interesting and the workers has suggested it. 


Napoleon: Moist, milky, flaky, delicious! Major thanks to the person that suggested and bought me the items! If I were to ever come back, it'd be for this. 

Rose: Rough and crunchy on the outside, moist and pastey in the middle. I believe it is walnut or almond paste which was yummy!

Workers were nice and were on top of their customer service. One had some troubles with their english but that's okay! 

Happy I stopped by.
author: Liza H.

description: Every time I'm in the Geary Blvd. area, I always come here to get my Russian snacks and pastries. The place also isn't fussy. You come in and you go out pretty quick. My favorite is the beef piroshki and I buy a dozen of them. I go home, put original HP sauce in it, take a bite and I'm transported to heaven. :)
author: Cecille A.

description: Omg this is the best bakery for poroshi and cheese blinztes fabulous pastries and salads. Great spot to pickup a picnic on the way to the park/beach.
author: Rochelle A.

description:
The piroshki here is really good. The girl that works here is super friendly and always nice to talk to. And the cheese blintz is DELICIOUS. 


One night I came in late and there were no more blintz. She said I could order fresh baked ones if I bought a minimum of 4. No problemo! 

I'm definitely a repeat customer here.
author: Munir M.

description: Great VALUE for your hard earned mullah!  The baked goods and pastries are old world greatness!  (Don't spread the word, and let's keep this our little secret!  Okay?)  It's one of those kinds of finds!
author: Michael W.

description: All I have to say is the piroshkis are AMAZING! You really can't beat almost a foot long piroshki for under $3 a piece and freshly made. We tried the beef and the beef and cheese piroshki. Both were sooooo good. There was plenty of beef in both so you know they don't skimp on the ingredients. The breading of the piroshki does remind you of chinese donuts and what is so bad about that? Will definitely come back to try the other piroshkis and you should too cause you're missing out.
author: Yvonne T.

description: Even though the food here is good, nothing can excuse the poor service I received on 8/5/17 from the blonde, russian cashier. I also witnessed her being rude to other patrons.  She had a ton of attitude with no manners. Makes me not want to come back, especially since there are so many other great Russian delicacy stores within the vicinity...and I probably wont.
author: Emily G.

description: Ooooh. Perhaps I should not have done it! I bought cakes in the morning and they probably were not very fresh. But my friend and I were very hungry, and began to think after everything is eaten. But we're alive and that's the main thing. And cakes were greasy and not very tasty. But on the whole tolerated! But the name is very cool. Tbilisi and Moscow is not compatible. But in San Francisco, they are together.
author: Roman G.

description:
I was not let down coming here with all the reviews and some youtube videos on this place. Their food was fresh & delicious & their pastries we're also very good and sweet. 
I will be coming back for more.
author: Jlc D.

description: I love this place for piroshki and khachapuri. The reason for 4 stars is due to the service. The cashiers are very unfriendly and rude.
author: Victoria B.

description: Whenever I am in the area, always stop for PIROZHKI, fresh and tasty. Fare prices, food always fresh.
author: Anatoliy Y.

description:
Mushroom piroshkies. Get them here! Be forewarned that they also contain egg, but they are fantastic.  Beef, cabbage,  and cheese versions also available but mushroom is by far the best.
 This place may be down the street from New World but I come here for my baked goods. I prefer savory, but their sweet pastries and cakes are surprisingly modern,  with varieties including green tea,  white chocolate, lychee, and ginger.
Location is small but clean,  service is sweet.  Challah sells out fast so grab it if you see it.
author: Stefany V.

description:
Co-worker brings in the meat and cheese piroshki. They are delicious! 

Delicious meat donuts.
author: Stu H.

description:
Craving some Piroshkis the other day, I found myself wandering around Outer Richmond where all of the russian stores are in search of a quality one. Moscow & Tbilisi was my first stop.

I picked up the beef and cheese piroshki and it was utterly disappointing. The dough was so thick and chewy it was hard to even bite through this. Also, it was of the baked variety and I definitely prefer them fried. I much prefer Anda's or Cinderella's to this.

As an afterthought I also picked up a Ginormous with ground beef and it turned out to be the saving grace for this shop. It was massive, fried and flaky with a generous ground beef filling. The filling could have used a little more flavor but I definitely enjoyed this item.

Overall, while it didn't satisfy my piroshki craving, I did find a unique item which made this place "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: the best place for cheap, fun, delicious pastries & downright hearty russian classics. the peroshkis are so good and filling, and every time i go i try a new pastry! they are all delicious so far! tons of little cakes and tarts to choose from, i feel like i'm in great british baking show every time i go (except, you know, great russian baking show). customer service is always sweet, and everything is SO affordable!! a must go if youre in the neighborhood
author: Maddie Y.

description: This is my favorite Russian bakery store since I was in high school living in Richmond. The price is reasonable, but the food is excellent.
author: Abraham S.

description:
Wow. I haven't been here in about 8 years.  I was ecstatic. Even though we were stuffed from a late lunch, we ended up here anyway. This place has had a serious remodel.  I was kind of shocked. 

Almond horn = still as awesome as it ever was.

Napoleon = always worth it. Flaky layers filled with custard.  Use a fork, and napkins!

Cherry strudel and apple strudel = perfect pastry with fruit filling.  

Prices = reasonable.  All of the above was under $14.00.  

Oh, and they still have breads, cakes, and savory Russian delights (piroshki, blintzes, borscht, salads, etc.)  My friend really enjoyed the beef piroshki, $2.00!
author: Fannie S.

description: I came here for the Georgian khinkali, but it didn't taste link khinkali at all. It was basically just a bigger version of pelmeni, and I felt nauseous after eating it. Definitely a disappointment.
author: Allegra G.

description:
A co-worker brought some piroshkis with cheese inside and others with what looked like onions and cabbage. Considering these had no meat in them, they were so tasty. They reheated nicely in the toaster oven. mmm!

She also brought a large, round pastry that had meat inside. This was also delicious! Full of flavor and the bread on this, just like the piroshki are so dangerous. I'd love to go back to try more items. 

This co-worker is from Russia so I trust her patronage of this place and am so glad she introduced me to it.
author: Susan G.

description: Yummy Russian   food.  Good owners and staff is very friendly. I love the fresh bread they make too.
author: George B.

description:
Pirojki and chebyreki are delicious!  And that's pretty much the only things we buy because the rest is not very good.  Their baked pastries like blinz are good too. DO NOT BUY THEIR DESSERTS. They are awful. Old pieces of cake that are sooo bad. We tried a variety of them through the years and the pattern is clear: they do not know how to make dessert nor do they care if that dessert is fresh, took several bites and we always ended up throwing stuff away even stuff  that is very popular like napoleon and eclair is beyond their abilities. 

If you end up buying dessert try it on the spot so you can at least get your money back.
author: Julie B.

description: Excellent neighborhood bakery that has become a family tradition. I had an aunt that lived off 27th and Geary, my mother would walk down Geary and always returned with a bag full of piroshki. Now we carry on the tradition, we always stop in whenever we are in San Francisco.
author: Michael S.

description: Keep coming here again and again ! I live like half hour away in sunset but I'm addicted to these lovely looking cake gallery so fresh and unique!!!! Try the kachapuris chebureks or their cabbage rolls  - it's out of these world! The girls on the counter are always smiling and welcoming And the place smells sooo good ! I always try a different cake and I bring a friend- they usually get the piroshkis and some pastries ! How u say heaven in Russian?
author: Tina J.

description: Have been coming here since middle school for their piroshskis. They are cheap, delicious and will soak your paper bag full of the oil.
author: Bernie H.

description:
Nice place. We are coming here for many years, but not too often.

There are many things we like a lot, and some items what we are staying away from.

Overall - it worth your money. The food is fresh, no doubt there is nothing too expensive.
author: Dmitry D.

description:
I love their piroshki, cakes and home-made salad. 
Tried their "shuba", and it reminded me of how my mom used to make it.  Really good. 
Not healthy, but REAL!
author: Marianna K.

description:
Don't forget to Check-in for 10% off! 

They have the best little pastries if you're looking for a something small and sweet. Also great for personal birthday sweets. A small shop, if you want the baklava you got to come in earlier! It goes quick. Always come for The Napoleon and Cheese Blintzes!
author: Kristel L.

description: Very yummy bakery with lots of options! I got bulochka s makom mmmmm poppyseed pastry! They also have borsh and shuba salad!
author: Natalia M.

description: Not only they are cheats in cookery, their place itself is dirty. I came in and just left at once - the smell in the store was so unpleasant...
author: Svetlana B.

description:
Came here just for the famous piroshkis.  Came after the lunch rush.  
Bought beef & cheese and plain beef.  More piroshkis were coming from the kitchen newly cooked.  Dripping with oil.  Unhealthy but simply delicious.  
Also bought napoleons for my girls and meringue for my mom.  Loved their beautiful selection of pastries.  Will buy challah next time.  Coming back for sure.
author: Corine C.

description: I highly recommend this place for their meat blinses and meat piroshki's. Their blinses have a high impact of flavor that just bursts as soon as you take a bite into it. Sadly around 7, they usually run out of them. You can always special order though. The lady that cashiers here is always friendly and kind. Reason I dropped a star is because their desserts aren't as good as they look.
author: Ada H.

description: When I'm in the area, I sometimes end up walking a couple blocks just to grab some piroshkis at this Russian bakery.  The beef & cheese ones are really delicious and my go-to here.  They have a good selection of piroshkis and other baked goods here, as well.  The piroshkis are always so big that I can never finish them.  The high oil content, because they're deep fried, ends up making me feel a little sick before I get a chance to.
author: Eric L.

description: Ordered 3 different piroshkis. All three were a greasy mess, and delivered cold. I also ordered a soup. It wasn't borscht, but it too was very cold. Perhaps it's supposed to be? Won't be ordering again.
author: Matty B.

description:
I've been coming to this place for over 15 years and ifs been getting better and better

Pros:
Great prices
Authentic taste...very homey
Fantastic taste not just authentic
Amazing variety and everything tastes great
Nice seating to eat in

Con:
Parking is a bitch. Worth the wait...You can also find side street parking if you're lucky. Don't give up. Its worth the parking nightmare.
author: James M M.

description:
While the piroshkies are hit or miss depending on the time of the day, you can't go wrong with their selection of desserts and baked sweats. My favorites are the poppy-seed rolls, and if you need something filling, look for the "potato" dessert. It's this dense, heavy sweet mini-log that can feed two. 

When the piroshkies are fresh, though, they are pretty amazing. Crispy outside with a slightly doughy bite, giving way to a well-seasoned filling (I'm a fan of the potato, and cabbage).
author: Andrew L.

description: Absolutely the best Shuba salad and poppy seed roll. The piroshky were delightful as well.
author: PleasantonCA C.

description: I grew up coming here for the best piroshkis in SF!!  Every time I'm in the city I have to make a stop to pick up at least a dozen!!  Because now my husband and kids are addicted...They are contagiously good!!!!
author: Rosie M.

description: I haven't been to other russian bakery for comparison, nor have i had much exposure to russian food, but all the items I've had from this bakery are tasty. I been here a few times and always end up with a bag full of piroshki to bring home.
author: w m.

description: Fantastic selection of savory and sweet treats at a great price. Enjoyed a beef and cheese piroshki and a almond horn. Will be back!
author: Greg S.

description: How amazing is this place? Really, super awesome! We went here on an early Friday afternoon (we both were off from work) and parking around this place is a nightmare. Luckily, we found a spot nearby in the residential area about 2 blocks away. There isn't too many tables and chairs for those seeking to stay. However, their selection of goodies was really impressive. I loved everything we ordered here: a bag of frozen pelmemi, beef and cheese Piroshki, cheese blintz, and a giant meringue cookie. Everything was delicious except for the novelty item: meringue cookie. That was everyone's least favorite item. However, for their Piroshki and Pelmeni alone - I'd got back. Plus, the service was super nice and not pushy at all. I'd love to return and try out their Georgian Cheese Bread (Acharuli Khachapuri), if they're still serving that. Overall, great place and super yummy food.
author: Lisa R.

description:
After eating at B-star Asian fusion a few blocks away, my family decided to stop to get desert. The Russian bakery seemed like a good idea and we were prepared for something a little different.

The bakery is pretty standard with its layout and look.  Nothing too fancy, and a few display cases with huge deserts.  I ordered a giant almond cookie and my mom got the marble cake.

The almond cookie was a 7/10. It could have been more moist, but the taste was perfect and the softness was on point.  The marble cake was absolutely amazing. I would say as high as a 9/10. Very moist and soft, and you could taste all the different flavors melding together.

My one gripe is that the servings were too big, so this limited our options because we did not want to bring home half an apple turnover.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I agree with some of the reviewers that some of the pastries could be fresher. I'm not one to like things that are sickly sweet, so on our last visit, I picked out a mini challah with raisins and a piece of poppy seed cake. They were both dry but tasty. This is not food for wimpier, more pampered Americans who don't want to have to chew their food. The things I ordered are not Frenchified. This is hearty and filling and could be used as the foundation for a good, soulful, Old World meal. Or a small building.

There's a reason they put dried fruit in a lot of these pastries. Without the raisins & things, you'd clog up like that orange spout on the old container of Elmer's Glue-All that's been sitting in your junk drawer for years. But it is tasty, filling food. The challah is not like the fluffy, airy kind you might find at a local Trader Joe's. The poppy seed cake was especially flavorful--loaded with enough poppy seeds per cubic centimeter to make you fail your next few drug tests.

As they say in the old country: "Rusev machka. Dasvidaniya."
author: J R.

description: I come to this Russian bakery at least once a week and wanted to write a 5 star review. They bake all the piroshki and pastries in house and they are all delicious and fairly priced. The breads are also great and they slice them for you. The poppy seed roll is one of my favorites and well as their savory foods such as the eggplant, soups and other salads. I would highly recommend you stop by and try some of these tasty delights.
author: Ilya K.

description:
I haven't had much experience of Russian pastries but I sought this place out after seeing a recipe for khachapuri, thinking it too difficult to prepare at home but then discovering that Moscow and Tbilisi Bakery offers them up for sale. The premises looked a bit tired, with a couple of gloomy corners but the table in the front window is neat for watching life on Geary Street.
The prices appear to be consistently terrific. Piroshki with various fillings are each $2.50. The khachapuri are $5. The pastry aren't dinky little things either. I sat down with a cup of coffee and a strudel (both passable but not that impressive), and spent about twenty minutes listening to old Russian ladies buy bread and other stuff. Honestly, I'd probably give them three and a half stars but since that can't be done I rounded up.
author: Brian G.

description: Found this bakery on Yelp, we stopped by and were not disappointed. Their is a big variety of pastries, cakes and piroshkis. Service was ok and parking was tough. Ended up spending around $35 bc everything looked so good.
author: Serge K.

description: We were looking for a gluten free dessert and we discovered this great bakery. There are many varieties of gluten free, flourless desserts and giant delicious meringues! I'm definitely going to return to try more. Price is very reasonable. People are very nice, friendly and helpful.
author: W S.

description:
It is cool to see how many of the recent reviewers have come from those that have a connection to the character played by Kate Mulgrew (RED) in Orange is the New Black, 

But I come for things like the Challah Bread, which is an Easter Staple , BUT also makes KILLER FRENCH TOAST ,  and their meal size Pieroshki , with my go to options being their Cheese, and the Beef & Cheese both bargains at $2.25.

Lots of great Breads, Pastries, and Desserts at the Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery though I tend to focus on the less fancy options.

FYI: The staff has English as a second language with their primary being Russian so be gentle with them :)
author: Joseph A.

description:
Street parking is a pain, so tag-team this spot with a friend.
Beef and cheese piroshki is a must!
author: Angel L.

description:
As far as Russian bakeries go - I'm a huge fan. This little Richmond area gem did not disappoint! The woman behind the counter was very nice and helped me pick out some of the most appropriate delicacies to share with my friend who was less than well-versed in this type of cuisine. 

Everything was steaming fresh and tasted excellent - almost the way my mother and grandmother always made it! It was very reasonably priced, with over 6 items that left us stuffed coming out to only $16 dollars! It's a definite must do.
author: Yuliya S.

description:
I give very few places 5 stars, but Moscow is one of them!!  The value you get for your money here is incredible!!.  I used to go here for their GIANT fantastic piroshkis at $2/each-----yes, TWO BUCKS EACH for piroshkis that can substitute for a heated sandwich or hearty lunch meal any day which is especially valuable in the expensive Richmond district!!!  Now it's $2.50, but that's inflation for you! :-)  

They also now have tables and seats and sell coffee/tea if you want to hang around and talk with a friend or relax.  They also now accept CC.

They're not a Schubert's with ALL quality pastries.  In fact, I think their Napoleons are more than a bit flat and not as fresh a I'd like, but if you just keep to buying their piroshkis, I don't think you''ll be dissapointed.  They have different types (mushroom, ground beef, ground beef and cheese, cabbage, etc.)  Ask them to heat the piroshkis up for you if you want to eat them right away.

They have some street parking but also the 38 and 38R stop here on 20th ave/geary.

As far as coming back, any time I'm on Geary, this is one of the 1st places on my list to eat!!
author: Frugal C.

description:
I liked all the piroshki we purchased:

Mushroom
Beef
Cheese (was my favorite surprisingly)

The borscht soup was okay.  A little bland.  I wouldn't get it  again.

The service was fine, she was nice.  No problems getting 10% off with Yelp check in.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
This is old style baking. When you walk in the aroma reminds me of home baking. 
Big pastries. 
Flavorful. 
Affordable. 

Anything here with poppy seeds is amazing. The piroskis are big and taste great. The borscht is wonderful, I probably buy it 3-4 times a month.  I love this place.
author: Mark W.

description: Love the piroshki, had beef, cabbage and mushroom, big and good price.  Strudel like desserts had too much bland bread taste. Borscht was lacking some beets this time. Pelmeni a great value. Counter girl kinda rude to my husband, large order, would not keep at counter until he could pick up later, he already paid for order, like return in 30 min when he asked, had to run errands nearby with 2 large bags. She must of had a bad day.
author: Maria D.

description: The piroshki is awesome!  Worth it to fight through SF's nightmare parking situation.  But I would suggest for you bring a friend who can drive around the block while you run into the bakery.
author: Maggie T.

description: The Chocolate Eclairs are, most unfortunately, not as good as they used to be. The potatoes piroshki are delicious.
author: Artie F.

description:
Tried some Russian bakery delicacies for the first time. The piroshkis were fresh n tasty. I tried the one with mushrooms, the Che..... Can't remember the name, was stuffed with beef just came out fresh from the kitchen were super fresh light tasty...(considering its fried !!!) Also tried this flaky pastry stuffed with cheese.. Was nice too...

I didn't like the desserts at all !! The tiramisu had a peculiar flavor... N the napolean was just OK... My friend makes way way better napolean  at home. The dessert section is a two star for me. 

I thought the staff was ok, however my friends who are also Russian felt that they were very rude. 

Only gave the place a 4 star for the baked savory items.
author: Insiya N.

description: Bought more stuff a week later, now the cherry strudel had barely any filling as well...
author: Alisa Z.

description:
Sort of stumbled into this bakery. Had the beef & cheese piroshki and it was delicious. Also had some sort of pastry with cheese which for the life of me cannot remember the name, but it was excellent.

Will return next week
author: Manny M.

description:
Saturday, 11:45 AM.

Quickie:
+ Delicious pastries
+ Menu options
+ Friendly service
+ Clean
+ Bargain

And then...?
Pair some of this stuff with good coffee on a mellow weekend and it's chill mode. 

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Beef piroshki/pirozhki
     + Lots of filling
2. Cheese piroshki/pirozhki
     + Gooey like it's supposed to be

Constructive comments:
*Remove residual oil from the fried goods?
*Higher quality ingredients for the piroshki fillings?
*What about recycling?
*Compost option
author: Chuck N.

description: I stumbled upon this bakery while staying at an Air BnB in the area. It was within walking distance and we were looking for a quick breakfast to pick up. I am so glad we did! It was so yummy that we went back a second time the following day. The first day my husband and I shared a cinnamon roll with cheese in it that resembled ricotta. It was good but nothing exceptional. We also got piroshki, which I had never heard of. It is a little pocket of fried dough filled with savory ingredients like ground beef or cheese. It was amazing! My husband and I each got our own piroshki the next day; too good to share! My favorite was the ground beef seasoned with onions and cheese. It was still warm from being freshly fried. We don't have a Russian bakery at home so I really enjoyed getting to sample these gems and look forward to returning next time I am in SF.
author: Ashley D.

description:
I live two blocks away. I am screwed. 

The beef and cheese piroshki will make your eyes roll back. It'll also keep you full for hours and doubles as an excellent hangover helper! Super greasy, so skip those paper-thin industrial napkins, and go straight for the Quilted Bounty on these bad boys. I once left an empty piroshki bag in my car all day just so I could revisit that intoxicating smell after a terrible day of work. It was like a warm, buttery blanket wrapping itself around me and telling me that everything was going to be ok...

I only wish that the piroshkis were always available within the first hour of opening, but then again, maybe I'm the only one wanting meat and cheese at 7:30 in the morning.
author: Alexis H.

description:
Came here about 2 months ago to get munchies before shooting some night photography in the Presidio. We randomly came across it after eating dinner nearby. As soon we we walked in, I knew I was going to buy everything I wanted. They had so many different kinds of piroshki! I had the cheese and beef and it was DELICIOUS. The woman at the counter even warmed it up for us. I'm kind of mad that I didn't take any pics or remember what else we tried there but I know everything we had, I would get again. My Russian friends in the area say this is their go to spot.

Also, I was so inspired by their food and pastries that for weeks I was on a "Russian Operatic Pop" kick! Look up Chum Drum Bedrum by Vitas on YouTube. You won't regret it.
author: Chris C.

description: I'll give this a 4 star because I love the piroshki here. I get the steak and cheese piroshki, heat it up and BAM! Dig in dig in . This is actually a quick stop for me , if you want to get something quick, and cheap. I haven't tried the rest of the baking goods such as the donuts, but I think the apple fritter is good. Convenient if you're around town
author: Santiago E.

description:
A very nice change from the ordinary donut shop. Nicely lit and even has some tiled tables that you can enjoy your baked goodies. 

Having no clue as to the many Russian pastries, we just got what looked interesting, including something called Ponchik, a rounded dome of cream/fruit-filled fried dough. Unlike regular donuts, this texture was dense (Challa-bread-like) and there wasn't lots of filling, but it was still good.

We also had a very flaky-cherry turnover and a cherry roll whose crust was more like a cookie than found on a turnover. Both were very good and something that would certainly go with a cup of coffee or tea.

Service was polite, bordering on tolerant, given our ignorance of what we wanted, we were not otherwise helped to decide what might be a good sampling of their many items.
author: Glenn H.

description:
damn effen tanalizing to the tastebuds. Downside it's greasy, but who the fcuk cares? 
Blinses both cheese and meat are soooo good
beef piroshki was ginormous, yummy, but so greasy
huge beef empanada was great too but extremely greasy as well
napolean dessert was ok good but ok

Definitely coming back here because what I have tried was awesome! Definitely grabbing more napkins because extremely greasy. Maybe some green tea to cut the grease haha. After coming here I did need an extreme workout to compensate for my guilty pleasurers. The lady behind the counter was very helpful and patient with all our questions. The place is really well kept, clean, and organize.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
Love, love, love this place. Everything is delicious that I've tried and most of the prices are totally fair. To clarify, the only things I've noticed that seem a bit expensive are their full sized cakes which hover around $30. All things considered however, this price actually seems quite fair. I have not ordered one of the full sized cakes yet (in a month I am planning to for my boyfriend's birthday), but I have tried their mini cakes and they are all quite delicious, so I imagine the large versions follow suit.

On top of the flavor, these are some of the most beautiful and artfully executed cakes I've observed in the city. They appear to use special pans or molds to give the mini cakes interesting, solidly-structured shapes and make use of a variety of ingredients for decoration. Among these are typical cake accessories like striped chocolate shaving pipettes, but also more uncommon adornments like small garnishes of brightly-colored fruit gels. They also use traditional decorating ingredients creatively, like a cake I observed where they created a lace or wallpaper-like design in tangerine colored powdered sugar. The flavors of these cakes also demonstrate culinary finesse, from tart cherry with white chocolate, to coconut marshmallow with lychee gel.

What I initially sought this place out for (and what continues to bring me back) however, are the amazing piroshki. For $2.50 each you get a 6-7 inch flash-fried golden, fluffy bread pocket filled with one of five types of ingredients that weighs in at nearly a quarter of a pound. What a deal! When I started going here I was a vegetarian and would always get the potato (think savory, beautifully seasoned smashed potato filling) and cabbage (peppered, slightly tart, slightly sweet kraut-style cabbage filling), which are still my favorites. The mushroom one might make a good veg breakfast as it has egg and green onion as well. Tried the beef one the other day - amazing! If you like philly steak you should give it a try. Tried the cheese one too and it was ok...similar to a giant mozzarella stick.

Don't be put off by the serious-acting staff...they are not giving you attitude, they are being normal Eastern Europeans :)
Check them out!!
author: Astrid E.

description:
Best "Chebureki" in Bay Area. :) Also have wide selection of various russian food. The quality on various items varies from "okay" to "awesome", but lean more toward awesome side.

All and all - this is the best russian food store in Bay Area, and I've been living in Bay Area for 20 years, and have tried all of them.
author: Vadim B.

description:
I love Beef and Cheese piroshki. Yes it is oily side but I love it. 
Price is $2.50 and one piroshki made me full. 

I will stop by this place whenever I am in the area!
author: Mo F.

description:
After binge watching the latest season of Orange is the New Black, I was inspired to have some peroshkis and do Red proud! Found this little gem of a bakery on the way home over the weekend. The line was super long, but I knew it was going to be good due to the many Russians grabbing food and the newly married couple decked out in wedding gear waiting to get peroshkis. 

This place is all business and no frills, but the peroshkis are super cheap. $4.50 for two. Got mushroom and cheese, came home and warmed them up-my tummy and I were very happy!
author: Christine E.

description: Got the hazelnut mousse and Napolean. Pastries tasted old and dry, like they've been sitting out for too long. Stars for presentation though. They were really cute.
author: Molly S.

description: Growing up a few blocks away, I grew up going here (I'm also Russian and am familiar with the items sold at this bakery.) The bakery has gone so downhill I'm never going to step foot in there again. For Mother's Day I got my mom a piece of Napoleon cake (her fave) and an eclair and the cream was sour and disgusting and we threw it out. My mom was so upset and disappointed given how expensive these cakes have also gotten and we had to throw them out because they were gross and probably went bad. Anyway save your money and go to Katia's instead.
author: Marianna L.

description: I don't like posting negative reviews, but seeing as this place has mostly favorable reviews, I feel slightly less guilt in offering my opinion. As a customer who was born in and grew up in Russia and being familiar with Russian/Soviet baked cuisine, I was disappointed for two reasons: it is overpriced for what it is (granted, I know this is SF), and the quality leaves a lot to be desired, e.g., tiny filling and plenty of dough in the several items I have tried. I know most non-Soviet customers find this interesting and exotic, as they probably should, but from the Russian/Soviet perspective, at least mine, this is mediocre at best.
author: George A.

description:
This place is awesome.
They always have fresh Russian pastry and great tasting European white bread. Their piroshki is the best in town. It comes in meat, cheese, cabbage, potato, and mushroom flavors. A little greasy, but totally filling and very affordable.
author: Feri F.

description:
I found this no-frills Russian gem after looking for a bakery that opened early on weekends. I was really impressed with their cheese blintz. The dough was cripsy but still delicate and soft once you bite down, and the cheese was warm and tasty. For a $1, it is such a deal.

I haven't tried everything but I do like their pastries. Their walnut bread was so good and surprisingly not too heavy. Very fluffy and light, great with a latte.

Will definitely be back! A cute mom and pop shop. $5 min for credit cards!
author: Veronica S.

description:
Khachapuri. That alone is a reason to give this place five stars. I had been craving Khachapuri since I moved from St Petersburg in 2006 until a Russian friend of mine told me to come here. It was well-worth the trip and I need say no more. Just like the hole-in-the-wall dim-sum places around the city, you don't come here for the service or atmosphere, you come here for the amazing food. 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zGkHRa64sDY you know this video? Well, that was me after first time coming here, only imagine the background being the 38 Geary instead of in a car. Seriously, just try it.
author: Vilde E.

description: My Russian friend recommended yhis bakery because I was craving piroskis. First off, they have huge meringues! They were super sweet and yummy. I got there too late and they only had beef piroski and potato piroski. They were good but I'll have to go back and try the beef and cheese piroski. Great, friendly service. They have plenty of other desserts to choose from. Apple fritters to chocolate mousse cake, I'm going to try them all one day.
author: Nina B.

description: I cannot believe I grew up in the Bay Area and have never been to this place previously. They have the BEST piroshki I have ever had. They were warm from the case, and so tender and juicy and - delicious. The cakes and everything else looked delicious as well - beautifully crafted and elegant and ..... I need to get back there asap! Okay, yes, it's a bit of a dive. Who cares! The food is worth the trek from wherever you are in the Bay Area. Yummy. I may just leave work right now and go back. :)
author: Amy H.

description:
Best piroshkis in SF.
I love this bakery, and it's very convenient they have online ordering. Their soups and traditional dishes are fabulous too.
author: Ellie M.

description:
This isn't your trendy cafe where you will find menials with their heads buried in their screens, sipping on pricey blabachinos, this is where your parents and grand parents would shop for their daily breads, piroshki's, and other fine baked sweets that decorated your family celebrations

When I have the time to trek my way to this end of the city, its usually a special occasion like my birthday, and I feel like I went back to when I was 10.
This place is kind'a magical, if not the last one of kind, definitely a rarity seldom found here in California. 
There's little point in mentioning their offerings, list is too long and long reviews are boring.
I will highlight their "Napoleon" as in my book this is like one of 2 places in Northern Cali who knows what a  Napoleon is and makes it the way it was made if you ate it in EU or tthe balkan states centuries past.  As for the 2nd place, I'm still searching for it, as far as I'm concerned everyone else here in California who puts Napoleon in their display case is joking themselves in ignorance and I wished the other 99.9% of bakers in California would eat it here then go learn how to make it the right way!
Lastly but not the least is the lovely wonderfully fresh piroshkies made daily, I recommend both the mushroom, as well as the beef, but only buy what you can eat that day as its best when its fresh. 
Let me put it this way, you can go hear everyday for a month, each day try something new and you'll still be missing things you haven't tried yet, I only wished I was 50miles closer to this place so i could go there everyday, life is too short without a REAL good bakery in your path!

 If you speak Russian, you'll have an edge, but everyone there is English speakers.
You should know what you want to order before you get in line as they move a LOT of people through quickly.
If you see items you've never seen before its normal as they make very traditional items, if you don't like what you bite into, don't complain, have respect and go ask what's in it, they'll explain it to you, but don't make a face like a brat and ask to exchange it for something else, this is not a place to have things your way, expand your horizon and learn something new while you're here.
Room for improvement: yes, the coffee served is really not one to be proud of (I'm being nice about this), until they get more serious about the coffee you best buy your java from one of those other places you frequent, or buy the goods here and have with your own brew at home.
author: Far K.

description: Yummy Russian baked goods! Overpriced salads, olivie didn't taste like real Russian olivie salad. Russian customer service is below average - expect it, this is a given. They refused to apply yelp discount towards my second purchase during the same visit.
author: Val B.

description:
Fresh made pastries.  My Russian employer says they are just like the Old Country. 
All I know, is now I go every time I work out here and get a Blintzes or a Piroshki.  They are fresh and sometimes still warm.  They do offer to warm them up for you.  

The service varies depending on who is behind the counter.
author: Matthew K.

description:
I remember this place being so much better years ago when we would pop in and get piroshkis before hitting up Legion of Honor.  I was talking it up to Remy so hard as we were headed west across the city for our last hoorah.

But Moscow & Tbilisi failed me....

So, I'll overlook the fact that the hot tea was the pathetic tea-bag kind (this is kinda ridiculous to every Russian since we like ours hot and strong, not Lipton-esque).  That's fine.

But the baked goods, in particular the cream horn (trubochki) were not good at all.  The shell was rock hard and the filling had rice grains (what the hell?!?!?) in it.  The chebureki weren't garlicky enough although they had a great ratio of filling to dough and the piroshkis themselves were deceptively named.  My mushroom one was about three-quarters boiled egg.  Now what is that, right?

The two outstanding dishes were the meat blintz and the cheese blintz.  Actually, the cheese blintz was pretty freaking delectable and comes highly recommended by your fellow Russian.

Sad that it's come to this...but two stars, M&T.  I know you can do better.
author: Alina M.

description: Delicious, addictive fried beef/cheese piroshki, as well as mushroom for the husband. Cheap! $2.50 each compared to $3.50 each at Cinderella.
author: Nini M.

description: Food was delicious! Best chebureky I have ever had! So juicy! I highly recommend this place! Girls at the counter were really nice and helpful!
author: Kate H.

description:
I normally don't have the time to review places, but when something stands out,
in this case bad, I need to let others know. I went here because I was craving piroshkis. I got one mushroom, one cabbage, and one cheese to go - $2 each.
Then I said, why not try the baklava - big mistake! Fortunately, as we were cutting it, we noticed patches of disgusting green mold on the bottom, and didn't have any.
Unfortunately, for us, we didn't get to end our lunch on a sweet note, and wasted our money. I tried to call twice, to warn them from selling to others, but they don't pick up their phone. Even though, I kinda liked the piroshkis, I may not return, because
I felt cheated and disgusted. I learned, check the freshness before I buy.
author: Catherine B.

description: Man..haven't had Piroshky in awhile..soo through advice we stopped here!!! Excellent..try the mushrooms. And cabbage..yuuum
author: Herm W.

description:
Been coming here for years! (swore I already wrote a review for this...Hmm!)

I like coming in when the open at 9am.
Its all fresh, there is parking on busy Geary St and they don't run out of what I like here....

P I R O S H K I !
$2 for each one. I get Cheese & Meat and the Beef & Mushroom. C  & M could use more cheese.  B & M is might tasty!!  AND GREASY!  they can heat it up there and the grease seeps through the deli paper AND paper bag.  But even when not heated it still seeps through - but maybe because its so FRESH!

I can only eat half because I am diabetic and it totally messes with my sugar levels.  But its totally worth it!!  

Some day I will try their sweets.

Oh yeah - Cash Only!
author: Erika G.

description:
I swear to god - this place makes THE best piroshkis i've ever had.
Since I moved out of town, every time i go in there, i buy a dozen or more to freeze for later. 
This place is a damned institution and in this ever changing (not always for the better) city, I'm glad i can count on their fresh, goddamn delicious food and sometimes confused looks when I order.
author: Hans H.

description: Delicious, delectable, splendid, affordable.... And, in a word: "authentic".
author: Mike S.

description: Always tasty! Love their delicious creations and keep coming back here whenever I am back in the city. I miss our Czech flavors and this place is bringing me back to where I come from.. Or at least my taste buds :) my favorite is their poppy seed cake, poppy seed strudel and the cheesy triangle and strudels, yum!
author: V L.

description: God, the piroshkis kick butt, and they're damn cheap ($2.50) for something that is massive and will keep you feeling full for an entire day. Get any of them, seriously. Cabbage, mushroom, beef, cheese, a combo of any of the above, and you still can't go wrong. The people working behind the counter here are so helpful and nice, and their selection of cheap, Russian pastries and baked goods just makes me salivate thinking about it. I do wish there were more filling inside each piroshki, but man, they're good.
author: Danny C.

description: Great piroshkis many different selections, cheese and beef, beef, cheese, mushrooms ... Great selection delicious and reasonable price treats.
author: Sharine d.

description: Can't recommend this place enough. Everytime I'm visiting the city this place is my first stop! Great variety of things to choose from!
author: Ella N.

description: A great, very authentic Russian bakery. I go every time after my dentist appointment and waiting for my fluoride to wear off is the worst because it's so hard to resist all the treats. Every time I go, I get a beef peroski and an almond horn. The ambiance is very simple and rarely do people stay there to eat their goodies. ​
author: Bailey A.

description:
