While seeking out a Starbucks to get work done at, my buddy and I spied a Russian bakery and dropped in for some foreign baked goods.

While he got a bunch of stuff to take home, I opted only for an apple roll.  While tasty and great for powering our hike in the Lands' End area, I wished there was more apple throughout.  My buddy's cheese roll was really good though, and the prices are totally reasonable for the homestyle stuff.

While I didn't have my mind blown by this first experience, I will definitely go back for the cheese rolls and perhaps even try their black bread.  There's so much cool stuff to try that I guess I may not have just chosen the best thing to sample.

Food: 6/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: Ok even though it wasn't perfect I still give it 4 for flavors... I've been stopping myself from stepping into this place knowing they have delicious piroshki and I only work 2 blocks away, that just equal weight gain! I finally caved in today got the mushroom piroshki and cabbage rolls. The piroshki was so freaking greasy and good!!! Crispy edges tasty filling damn good!  $2.50 and it was big. The cabbage rolls are so flavorful and delicious!  Only problem that ruined it, the rice in it wasn't cooked!! I was biting into hard grains of rice eeek! If the rice was good I woukd of given them 5 stars because the flavors are ridick!
author: Karen T.

description: This place is super delicious. There are so many lovely desserts that are so beautiful. The colors are gorgeous and the textures devine. The flavors are unique. My favorite though is the Piroshki. They have beef and cheese, potato, cheese, beef and more. The also carry pelmeni which is a dumpling that you cook in broth and serve with sour cream. Sooooo yummy.
author: Orleana P.

description: The worst customer service ever!!! They always cheat, don't like to give changes!!! Stupid people!! Rude, mean ladies!! The lady charged me for 5 piroshki, and guess what? She gave me 4 piroshki and still arguing with customer in her rude language!!! Never going to come back here again!! Don't recommend also!! People go to another places!!!
author: Zull E.

description:
We've been going here for years, and this place keeps getting better.
Here's why:

Best Napoleon Torte in Little Russia (that's huge).
   Very creamy with moist cake layers, no dryness or toughness. Melts in your mouth.

Heartstopper piroshkis shamefully good fried. I recommend the meat ones. (Russians don't differentiate meat like Americans do. It's just meat.) "You like it meat, ? It's a meat., you like. You try it meat piroshki, you like. It's a good."
Sometimes its pork, sometimes beef, sometimes mixed with turkey. I don't ask anymore. Just friggn enjoy it, OK?

Poppy seed roll. Perfect with coffee in the morning.
author: Scott A.

description: Too many things to choose from and great prices. Tried the meat piroshka for $2.50 and it was a meal. Even warmed it up for me when i asked. A little greasy tho. Tried the cherry Napoleon and it was delicious. Took a cherry strudel to go.
author: Susan B.

description:
If I had to name the SF eatery that offers the highest ratio of pure hunger fulfillment for the price, it would be this place.

The piroshki are $2.25. They are heavy. One is almost a normal size meal. Two will cure you if you are famished. They are tasty too. I like them all. I wouldn't eat these every day but they are a fun change.

Some people think Russian shopkeepers are cold and unfriendly. Same goes for the French. The trick is to say hello and smile when you enter a small shop. They consider it rude otherwise and treat you accordingly.

You can grab a soda from the fridge and eat in.
author: Chuck G.

description: Less than $3 for a huge piroshky!? SOLD! stumbled upon this little Russian bakery on our way to an Irish bakery down the street. Such a little gem. It's a struggle trying to find piroshki's in the bay. They have a variety piroshki's (5-6 diff kinds), savory & sweet breads, as well as fancy little cakes and such. I chose the beef & cheese piroshki, which was deeelicious! It came still warm, with tons of flavor. I thoroughly enjoyed it, for half the price & twice the size of Anda Piroshky, which is also in sf.
author: Elise T.

description:
The peroskis' are delicious. Stuffed with many different flavors. I have tried the cheese, and the meat and cheese. 

Ask them to warm it up for you and the peroski transforms into a delicious meal. 

The bakery also has a full selection of delicious looking pastries and bread. 

Inside there is a good number of seats, and outlets to plug into :)
author: Hayden C.

description:
Amazing Russian Bakery. The poppy seed bread is amazing. 

And the Borsch soup & perogies are delicious and authentic!
author: Jenn J.

description:
This place is awesome. Amazing pastries, piroshkis, and coffee. I come here all the time, maybe more than I should. Everything only a couple dollars.

While they open their doors earlier, they don't have all the pastries out until after 8:00. If you show up at the right time, your poopy seed roll is hot fresh out of the oven- my favorite. Big enough to share (but I never do). Try the Rose for a less sweet pastry. And the callah is wonderful.

The piroshkis (savory meat donut-like things, for the uninitiated) are awesome. Love the beef and cheese, and the cabbage ones. One makes for a filling lunch.

If you like strong black coffee, this is the place. Sometimes they have cream too.
author: Kelly T.

description: The piroshkis are delicious!! Must try the mushroom piroshki. They're really oily but so yummy, and they give you a large amount for really cheap.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Cravings! This would count as one of the lovelies that I think about next to House of Prime Rib on Van Ness, Submarine Center in West Portal, and Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown! I have my routine down. Every visit home, I have a mental list of foods to satisfy my cravings until my next visit. This time it was a PIROSHKI! I searched around for it in San Diego, but there was no morsels of deliciousness in sight! I asked a Russian friend if she knew of any in San Diego (not that she would automatically know) but I was desperate. So, that's why I still and will always love San Francisco, for diversity in good food, but also for the people who have talented hands to share their culture and food with us!

Tip: Order the beef & cheese piroshski!
author: Angie K.

description:
Anytime we are near this place it's a must stop for us! We mainly go for the piroshkis which are the best so far! The prices are great! I loved it when it was $1 for the piroshkis, but now I think it's $1.50 still totally worth it! One and half of these fills me up for most of the day. That's pretty tough for the price! 
The pastries are well priced and most are just as good. My kids love to get the eclairs. 
Seating can be a little crowded, but to be honest we usually just pick up and go. You can tell the piroshkis are great when the brown bag is soaked oil a little while later. Go there and get the meat and cheese piroshkis! You won't regret it!
author: Ron K.

description: I got 1 small size golybtsi of poor execution and 2 tablespoonfuls of olivie of OK make.  The woman behind the counter asked me to pay almost $5, so supposedly I got half a pound of each.  I'm sure she included the weight of plates in it.  Or their weights are messed up, which is a common practice where they're and I'm from.  The amount of food was SOOOOOOOOOOOOO miniscule.
author: Irena M.

description: A nice assortment of Russian/Georgian baked delicacies - cherry, apricot, cheese pastries and meat, mushroom and cabbage piroshki. Everything is very FRESH, YUMMY and CHEAP! I mean it's like $2 per pastry. Also, they have a few tables to sit down and enjoy a pastry and a cup of coffee. They have metered parking upfront.  I will def return!
author: Irena P.

description: Cute little Russian bakery in the Richmond. Had the Bird's milk cake (layers of honey cake and custard).  Was delicate and not too sweet. Would love to try any of the other treats they had, great selection!
author: Rebecca B.

description:
I go here all the time to get a beef & cheese piroshki, it's so delicious!

I've had their potato piroshki, meringue, chocolate pastry, strawberry pastry, all were fantastic. Great prices too!
author: Brett N.

description: The poppy seed roll is so delicious- I can't help but get one every time I walk by this bakery. Love it!
author: Julia P.

description: Awesome place, great bakery goods, HUGE Piroshki's and even if it's greazy a bit.. YUM, so good. Clean, nice staff, and totally worth the prices!
author: Brian W.

description:
All of their Piroshkys are amazing (and I have had them all) and an exceptional value to boot.  Their pastries are colorful and delicious... like little pieces of great tasting art.  On top of the great food the owner is super friendly and nice

This place is well worth a visit (and more).
author: Jay F.

description: Come earlier in the day to get the best warm Russian pastry and food item. Piroshki with potatoes and meat is delicious. Each time me and my wife Are in the Bay Area, we make sure to stop by here and buy some food to take back home.
author: Andrey M.

description:
Delicious and cheap! What more do you want? They have a huge selection and every thing I had was amazing. The Piroshkies were great, even when I ate them cold a couple hours later! I had the cheese blintze right away and it was already warm. The desserts are just as good. I will be back next time I am in the area!

I took away one star because the cashier was not very helpful or welcoming.
author: Michelle P.

description: My favorite piroshki place but with bad costumer service here like the mad woman Oyong/Oyo I better find another russian bakery for russian goodies.
author: Reese P.

description:
This place is a must stop for some Russian/Slavic food if you're in San Francisco. I would've given it a 4 star, but the place doesn't look too clean when I went there and the service was slow.

We bought the poppy seed roll, the meat and also the potato piroshki. Poppy seed roll was a little burnt in my opinion, the meat piroshki was too greasy but the potato piroshki was delicious! After I tasted piroshki from Piroshki Piroshki in Seattle, this has nothing to hold to them. Now, gotta plan next trip to Seattle.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

0/1 Star: Hard to find street parking.
_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: Nice clean to go bakery.  Really makes you feel good to know the food is made right there fresh every day.
_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

3/3 Stars: I don't know how they can sell a meat piroshki and a veggie one fo rthe same price, but I'm not complaining.  Their piroshki are the best in the city hands down.   
_____


Overall Experience
4/5 Stars 

_____

Pictures

Store Front: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hak3kl6F0AHR3nau6Q9kvQ?select=v1CVzvCjajHH5LtuOeOYjg#Sn2FoC50b5y7ZBqEaXZz8g

_____

Last Words
author: Elliott N.

description:
This is a really cool little Russian bakery, they have all sorts of breads, cakes, pastries, and piroshki's.  the piroshki's are made there and are by far the best I've had in San Francisco, best part, they're only $2 each.  This is one of those rare places where you can walk in with $5 and walk out full. 
 
Good hours, decent parking, great food, great prices
author: John S.

description:
If I was to look back upon my life, I would define it in two ways:

The days after I had a pirohski, and the days before it.

Gladly, there is no image of Putin here in this Russian temple; no, the farthest from his loathsome stench. Instead, only the glorious odours of the sweat and affection of Russian mothers expatriated from the homeland.

Bless thy holy hands, and eat all of the cheese. Your life has meaning.
author: Peter S.

description: The best bakery in SF. Always stop by when I am in SF. Very tasty treats,  owner is very kind and they have huge selection of baking goodies.
author: Vladimir G.

description:
Ever since checking out Piroshky Piroshky up in Seattle, I've been curious to find where you can get a good piroshki in or near SF.  The only problem?  Not too familiar with where to go around here!  Finding a decent Japanese or Chinese restaurant is easy enough, but I have no idea where the best Russian bakeries are at.  So after walking by Moscow and Tbilisi countless times, I figured they would be as good of a place as any to start with (their four star average doesn't hurt either).

With about a half dozen different options available, I ended up going with two to try - meat and potato (also saw cheese, cabbage, and mushroom available as well).  The breading for both was super soft, and I liked how there was a slight crispiness to the outside.  Neither was bursting with filling, but that was probably a good thing.  Both were very flavorful - the meat one was seasoned nicely and didn't seem noticeably oily, while the potato one had a nice mix of spice to it.  To be honest, I'm not really sure how to best describe the potato one's flavor, but it was pretty good and not as starchy as I would have imagined.  Between the two, I definitely thought the meat one was better (I'm a guy, so no shocker there).

The one thing that I didn't really care for though was seeing how much oil the brown bag they gave me had soaked up by the time I got home.  It's not something that I fault them for since it's inevitable with piroshkis no matter where you go, just that it's something I'd rather not see.  For me, it's one of those things where I already know it, so I don't really want/need to be reminded of it.  On the flip side though, it's actually a good thing since it's that much less oil you'll end up consuming and it shows it's still fresh enough that the oil hasn't congealed.  Yum!  Haha.

As far as their prices, it's really reasonable, as the piroshkis run for only $2 a pop.  Considering that they each measure out to about a foot in length, we're talking about a pretty good value.   I'm still on the search for more piroshki joints, but good to know it's off to a decent start (I'll keep you posted Alesia T.!).
author: Mike L.

description: Twice have we stopped here for piroshkis and twice the piroshkis were absolutely fantastic. We also have gotten two different pastries both times and those have been tasty, but really heavy and dense. I'll just stick to the beef and cheese piroshkis. They're life-changing...even if you have fierce piroshki burps for the following five hours.
author: Julia D.

description: My husband got a couple of pastries from here and they were inedible - stale and tasteless,  went straight into the trash. Not sure if that is how their pastries usually are or they gave him the old stuff because he didn't speak any Russian. Either way, we will never come here again.
author: Kaya B.

description:
Rum runner.

In the days of prohibition: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rum-running

In the days of today: Chocolate potato cake with rum. Was very happy after eating it. Was also perhaps a bit drunk. One of my favorite desserts of the year.

But don't stop there.

Save room for a creamy eggplant dolma, decadent cherry filled donut with powdered sugar, chewy khala bread and excellent potato piroshki.

All for $9.

Don't walk (or drive) to this Outer Richmond gem. Run.
author: Jason B.

description:
I stopped by here yesterday on my way out of the city, and I was amazed at M&T's selection, as well as their prices. I initially only came here for a cheburek, but when I saw their piroshki I had to try them. I ended up getting:

1 borsch
2 goluptsi
1 potato pirozhok
1 mushroom pirozhok
1 cheburek

All that for $16. Bargain. All of it traveled an hour to the south bay and was absolutely delicious after re-heating. Their dessert selection is equally amazing. Would come here again and again if I lived closer.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Take it from a native: this place is delicious!

I remember coming to the Little Russia block with my parents all the time when I was a kid (we lived an hour up north). We used to get a bunch of European food before heading back home, and we would always stop by Tbilisi bakery.

Now that I live nearby, it's much easier to get all my favorite Russian goodies.
The first thing I would suggest is the Napoleon (Mille-feuille for all you French peeps ;)) It's a delicious, flaky, creamy pastry that's heaven in every bite. No other way to describe it-- go hop on a bus and try if for yourself right now!
Also, a pro tip: If you ever have any office parties/potlucks/whatever, bringing a sheet of Napoleon and your whole office will love you, no joke. 


My other favorites--
*Blini with meat: A little oily, but perfect for when I'm craving something meaty. This is a thin crepe with meat and sauce inside. Plus, they're only $1 each!

*Khachapuri: Super cheesy with a fluffy bread texture, it's also a pretty huge portion that you can easily split with a friend.

If you're not in too much of a hurry and want to order a lot, you can ask the ladies who work there if they can make a fresh batch. They're really friendly and will gladly do so.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Even though this place is pretty far from downtown, I've been making the long trip a lot recently. I've tried a couple of their piroshkis and the beef one is definitely my favorite. I actually really like that the dough is thick and chewy. If you get it for there, they'll even warm it up for you. I've tried a couple of the pastries and the ones I really liked were the apple roll and apple strudel. Some times they have this fruit leather wrapped around walnuts that looks really interesting, but is pretty good. On my recent trips, I've discovered the challah bread with raisins and it is probably my favorite item there now! They also sell cakes, but I've never tried any of those.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Recently discovered this place as I was craving a poppyseed roll. My favorite poppyseed pastry is one that Three Girls Bakery at Pike Place Market in Seattle makes. The ones they make at TGB are specifically called poppyseed rugelach - but they're similar (Yelp them, you'll see what I mean). Anyway, I thought while the Moscow & Tbilisi's is not bad, it is too bready and not filled with enough poppyseed filling. I think it should be overflowing almost. Because of these factors, the roll is too dry. I think perhaps if they made the rolls smaller and put more filling, they would taste much better. 

Their Napoleon is tasty though. Everything looked good, so I'll be back to try more!
author: HM N.

description:
Piroshki!!!!!!

It's oh so bad for you because it's deep fried!!! But that's the best part! The crispy dough on the outside.

This bakery makes them in house. 

There are 3 kinds to choose from: All of them are awesome!

-Mushroom and Egg: There is a lot of mushrooms and onion tossed in a bit of egg. Don't expect chunks of scrambled egg inside. Great flavor! 

-Plain Cheese: It's a different kind of cheese, not straight mozzarella. I really don't know what kind of cheese is inside but it tastes good. 

-Beef and onion: Ground beef sauteed in onions. A classic flavor.

*Tip: We like to go home and pop them in the toaster oven, just so the outside gets crispy again. Try eating them with taco bell hot sauce! 

The bakery also makes a whole bunch cookies, cakes, and pastries. We like to come here mainly for the Piroshki!

Restrooms: Not sure.
author: Aimee R.

description:
Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery Store aka The Russian Bakery. You can't really miss it. They have a pink sign out front that says, well, Russian Bakery. 

They sell the biggest, greasiest (good greasy not bad) Piroshki
 I have ever seen in my life!! They also have the most delicious eclairs ever! I went there to buy a cake for Superbowl Sunday and was not disappointed. The only problem was that I ended up eating a Piroshki
while I decided on what cake to select. I took home this chocolate number with white frosting and it was off the charts good! I love the feel of this place, the people have always been friendly and helpful. I could probably spend the better part of a day eating through this place and likely wouldn't spend more than $25. One $ in the price range doesn't do them justice b/c they sell super sized items for dirt cheap and I love em for it.
author: Hector G.

description: This place is great. When I went, the piroshkis were $2.50. One thing to note is that yelp pulled up this bakery when I searched for "Polish Bakery" and there was absolutely nothing Polish in this bakery. If you're looking for a Polish Bakery, go to Seakor Deli, which also has some baked goods. They are not open until late morning.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
remember coming here with my mom a lot back in the days.  we always got the cherry rolls, which is huge and filled with cherry preserves.  bread is like challah/brioche-eggy but dense.  they have apples or poppyseed ones too for $2.50 each.

pirohskis are fried deliciousness.  

good childhood memories.
author: Linda T.

description:
Holy amazing piroshki, Batman!

Stopped here on a whim (driving down Geary and we saw the big, stark "Russian Bakery" sign... couldn't pass it down, out of curiosity if nothing else)

The dolmas were eye-catching, the desserts even moreso, but we were hungry for something warm and fresh, so we bought a meat and cheese piroshki and a cabbage one. They looked so good (and such a reasonable price) that we decided on a potato one, as well. And two dolmas to take with so, for good measure.

SO. FRIGGING. GOOD.  All of it.  But especially the piroshki... warm, fresh, soft, doughy, with just the right amount of crispness on the exterior... filled with a satisfying helping of juicy goodness inside.  All of them were great, but the potato and cabbage ones were AMAZING.

We will be back every single time we are in the area -- maybe even go out of our way to make SURE we are in the area. (It's a good thing we don't live there. Pretty sure I would definitely get fat.)
author: Matthew G.

description:
ummm....
Good pastries at good prices!
Too bad they do not have a sitting area and do not serve coffee drinks.

And also, be prepared for Russian customer service :)
author: S ..

description:
Great Borscht!  Far better than another unnamed place nearby that sells insipid slop that I would not give to a hamster. This is the real thing - just needs a huge dollop of sour cream and a hot cup of grog to go with it.

They are also polite here which is a commodity in short supply in some of the Russian places.
author: George S.

description:
Fantastic food at a fantastic price! 

Make sure you get both the cabbage and meat & cheese piroshkis and eat them at the same time! A little bit greasy but that's what you're in for! :-) 

Will make sure to go to this bakery every single time I'm in San Francisco!!
author: Leo X.

description:
Everything here is WAY too greasy. Even the borscht is greasy!

The marinated mushrooms are also greasy, but at least it works in this dish.

The perogies make me want to drink draino after eating them, in the futile hope of despackling my arteries.

Some of the counter girls are cute, and the service is decent for an FSU-run place.
author: Jacqueline A.

description: I was lured into the bakery while waiting for the bus by the sweet and cheesy smells. The cheese and potato piroshkis are my absolute guilty pleasure. I'll skip the donut and come here for a treat when possible. I also recommend the cherry scone with a cup of coffee. :)
author: Jay C.

description: I went to this bakery for the first time today. All I can say is omg....I had the potato piroski  (i think that's how you spell it,idek). It was a little greasy but delicious none the less. I got a few more potato and the beef and cheese (which I haven't tried yet). My tummy was I'm a happy place after eating that. This, I would say is comfort food for me.  Yummerzzzzz!
author: Jennalyn Zhu Y.

description:
Update:
The kharcho soup was really delicious, def need to order it again & take home for dinner. It had a little more flavor than the traditional borscht soup that she also sells.
This has become one of my "go to spots" when I'm on Geary & craving a quick snack.
The piroshki's & blinz are quite oily though, so I try & limit how many I eat at one time. :o)  

Update:
My eyes were definitely huge tonight!  On top of the 4 cheese blinz, i ended up buying 2 piroshki (1 potato & 1 cabbage), container of spicy kharcho soup, a strawberry cheese croissant & an apricot cookie. SOME of which I'll save for tomorrow!

Update:
Called to see if they still had any cheese blinz as it was almost closing time. She was out, but asked how many I would like & had 4 fresh ones waiting for me 10 min later!

The apt I was heading out to look at was already rented, so I had to console myself with an AMAZING cheese blinz & beef piroshki to make up for it. I will be working nearby, so I can see this will become a regular stop!  :-)
author: Chylene K.
Alanna R.

description: People who rave about these lousy pieroshkies obviously don't know what they're eating. This crap is like steamed, sealed hot dog buns with a bit of flavorless filling. They used to be $2.00, now they're $2.95. The joint is run by the usual abrupt, unfriendly Russians. Definitely a must-miss, especially if you have to pay for metered parking.
author: Pam J.

description:
I tried a few of their things. Most of their items are HUGE and for a low price. 
I haven't tried their cakes yet, but I tried quite a few of the baked buns/breads/piroshki. 
I like the apple roll. The thing is HUGE. I might try to poppy roll since it's so popular on yelp.
Their piroshki is veryyy greasy.
The meringues.. Please share. It's HUGE and you will feel sick after a few bites. 
I think I will come back to try some of their different items.
author: Nona T.

description: Poppy seed bread is what we drive some 30 miles for. They also have a lot of russian food like Shuba, ie herring under "fur" of vegetables. They have some seating inside, so you can order your food or desserts and eat it here too.
author: Soups R.

description:
I came here for the Piroshki!!! It was an early Sunday afternoon and I heard this place had some great Piroshkis, so me and my friend decided to check this place out. When we got there they had a variety of Piroshkis: cabbage, meat, potato, and more to choose from... 

We wanted to try the meat Piroshki but they were all out and the nice lady behind the counter said they would have some out in about 10min, so we said we'd come back in 10min. Boy, when we came back there was a line almost to the door. We weren't about to leave with out my Piroshki. By the time we were up next, the lady in front of us decided to get what we thought was all of the meat Piroshkis that was in the case. Who was she tryin to feed? Haha...and you know what, there was just a couple left in the case for us. I think she knew we wanted it :) 

We also ordered some pastries, The "Mother in law" slice of cake and she ordered the Cream Horn.. 

Wow!!! These Piroshki's were huge, about a foot long and fresh. Each individually packed in a brown bag... by the time I took it out of the bag, the bag soaked up a lot of the oil. It had the perfect flaky deep fried crust on the outside, to the tender moist bread inside, to the savory beef with onion mixture in the middle. The Piroshki had the PERFECT combination of meat and bread. As for how it tasted, I can't describe to you how DELICIOUS it was, my mouth just couldn't stop eating it :) YUMMM!!! You just have to go get it and try it for yourself... 

The Best Piroshki in town!!!
author: Jayne M.

description: Gotta drop by this bakery. Fast service and baked goods is the bomb. Their piroski is kick ass and their poppy seed pastry is the bomb. Very good food for decent good prices.
author: Harry L.

description:
Every once in a while we are treated to these delicious greasy... doughy... pockets filled with beef, mushroom, and cabbage.  

Piroshkis and hot sauce... would be a great breakfast for those who are hung over.

Although I have never been in the bakery I can say that I like their food and will keep it in my bookmarks for a future visit.
author: Sheenie L.

description: Great place for piroski or borst. They also have fresh ly made bread for very reasonable prices. The deserts are an acquired taste, not known for delicate pastries, Russian deserts tend to be heavy. I usually come here for a $150 each piroski that will fill you up. If you speak Russian all the better
author: Matt A.

description: Awesome place, delicious food.  VERY busy.  The customer service is really good.  Wish they served coffee.
author: Tanya O.

description:
We were in the area and stopped by for some "delicious Russian food". We bought Shuba (Russian layered salad with beets and herring), which cost $5.99/lbs, mushroom pirogi and almond tubes filled with cream. When we got home and started eating it all, we found out that Shuba has almost no herring at all, just some microscopic pieces and potatoes were shredded and mixed into every layer so it tasted... like potatoes. Horrible waste of our hopes and $9. We called the bakery just in case they don't know what they are selling, but woman answered the phone said that she made that Shuba herself and it's great, so they are saving $ on purpose.
Pirogi were inconsistent on proportion of dough and mushrooms (one was ok and one barely had some mushrooms in the middle). Do not waste your money! This is not what Russian cuisine taste like! Almond desert was good though and the lady at the counter was nice... But I will not go back.
author: Vera M.

description:
Yelp reviews!... you've steered me wrong this time man!  I'm honestly not very difficult to please- especially with sweets.  Walked in, saw a line, and was excited to try what they had.  Gal at the counter had a terrible demeanor - basically a bitch. I ordered a slice of Napolean and a Potato with walnuts(their chocolate cake w/ rum).  Again, I'm not very picky and I could barely swallow the first bite and literally threw both in the garbage.  I'm Chinese! I don't throw anything I paid good $ for in the garbage!  

Maybe everyone was in line for the Piroshki's?  I dunno... be warned people.
author: Andy W.

description: I adore this bakery.  The food is authentic and great.  The bakery is awesome.  The prices are well worth the great items.
author: Donna M.

description: Bird's Milk cake made perfectly. Reasonable prices, authentic russian bakers. What more can you ask for?
author: Leon M.

description:
Who can resist Russian goodies!! I can't :)
They have a HUGE selection of food. I have tried their cakes (note: cakeSSSSS, plural. I believed i've tried all of them) and the unfamiliar looking stuffed goodies (stuffed eggplant and pepper). 

Cakes - absolutely amazing. My all time favorite is the napoleon. Love the custard. All their cakes have different flavor and textures and you'll have to try them all to find your favorite. BF Mr Rabbit likes "Prezident" (something like that?). I believed that's the one with coconut and have a crunchier texture. The cake with coffee flavor (forgot name) is good too. Chocolate cake is always good, very rich and dense (BF really likes it, but I'm not a big choco fan myself). We also tried the chocolate/granite looking thing, called "potato" I believe? It definitely not for the fainthearted. It has a really, really strong alcohol taste (rum) in it, as if the pastry chef accidentally pour a whole bottle in it. We tried it twice, it is consistently strong. I guess consistency is good. 

Savory goodies - We tried the stuffed eggplant and pepper. Absolutely no idea what they are, but taste really good. I believe there's cabbage and meat inside. 

Service - Staff are very friendly and helpful. They took their time to explain everything to us (trust me, we asked them what everything is.. all the cakes at least) and are very patient. No sign of annoyance at all. Double thumbs up!

Decor - It doesn't look as empty now there are tables and chairs inside which we can use. It's actually pretty spacious.. look clean too!

If the cakes at the bakery only have 50 calories each, I swear I would get some everyday :(
author: Doris H.

description:
Feeling adventurous? Definitely a great place to check out if you're looking for a snack. 

A friend of mine and I were walking along Geary and decided to check it out. I was  surprised at how cheap the pastries and desserts were. We tried the Potato, a chocolate cake in rum and had a hard time finishing it, because the rum was too strong. 

The Blinses was delicious and definitely recommend it!
author: Akina C.

description: Best fried russian food. They have awesome piroshki the best are the potato and the beef and cheese bring sour cream with you to dip them in and you will be very happy with your meal. We stop here every time we are in San Francisco.
author: Arky P.

description:
Eat mushrooms and hachipuri piroshki, very delicious, highly recommend!
Me and my family go there to get bakery piroshki all the time when we are in SF.
author: Mark Z.

description:
Dude,

Almond horns. $3

Your life will change.

kthxbai.
author: Alex M.

description:
I went this place to buy some goodies and especially kharcho, Georgian spicy lamb soup with rice. It is delicious when it done well. I got chebureki (fried meat pirojki), 2 lb container of soup kharcho, bread, cherry strudel, and few pieces of different cakes. A half an  hour later, after I got home, I opened the container with soup to heat it up, and didn't find even one piece of meat. Rice was overcooked. It wasn't kharcho, it was spicy rice porridge.   My children, who like cakes a lot, said, that the cakes wasn't good enough. 
I can't say that everything I bought was bad. I liked chebureki, which was fresh and juicy. For them only I could give 5 stars. My son liked merengue . But overall my experience today was only for 2 stars, mostly because of kharcho.
author: Lola B.

description: Well, we wanted to make sure that we share with the feedback here. We purchased Russian "blintzs" with cheese yesterday in this store. Being around here in San Francisco for about 17-18 years, I (and my wife as well) was quite shocked with the quality of their blintzes last night.  They were not just bad but plain bad - they were big time overfried with lots of heavy smelly oil (just like in old time in 90-s in Macdonalds or something) and had a bad taste as well.  There was little cheese in them as well.  Being the huge fan of anything with farmer cheese/cheese in general for my entire life, I was quite upset. Moreover, we decided to call up this store to share with the feedback, but it was plain rejected in a rude manner.  This was surprising as well - big time.  Thus, we wanted to post this feedback - to make sure others can see that. If needed, I can share my observations with the food inspection in San Francisco accordingly - to check the quality of oil (and gross/vast amounts) used.  I was told also by someone on the phone at that store that - this store is the only one that sells such blintzes with cheese.(?!?) Which was extreme arrogance as well. Is that a monopoly voice here??  Others DO sell blintzes with cheese, and they ARE MUCH better. Jee. To be honest, we just made our decision to not to go there ever again.  Whenever you're in business, you LEARN to LISTEN what your customer says and appreciate feedback, not REJECT it immediately and try to talk down.  Amazing.  :(
author: Alex F.

description: I love coming here. Everything is really fresh and tasty. This bakery also has (arguably) the best piroshki's in the City. Get yourself one, you won't be disappointed.
author: Yelper F.

description: More than satisfies my nostalgia for Eastern European treats. Mmm, khachapuri, mmm!
author: Michael M.

description:
*drool* This place was fantastic! Display counters full of a really amazing variety of delicious baked goods, and the prices were fantastically cheap. If I lived in town, I would eat here daily (It might speed my death, but SO worth it). The potato piroshky was amazing...the dough was perfect, with enough bite/firmness, but still lovely and chewy. Great flavor. And $2 only!!!  The cheese blintzes tasted like home-made (that's a GOOD thing, as I'm remembering a russian heritage home) and only $1 each. Honestly, all of the pastries we chose were fantastic. We were on our way to a fancy-pants dinner at Aziza when we saw the sign and stopped in. Loaded up with 6 or 7 items and the total was only $9.  We each had to have at least one before going to our fancy michelin starred meal across the street.  And having the rest of the pastries the next morning in our hotel room was fantastic! This means that we bought our pastries at 8:30pm, the end of the night, and didn't eat most of them until 9am the next day. And they were still some of the best I've ever had. I can't even imagine how much more magical they must be hot and fresh from the ovens in the morning. Yowza!

The woman at the counter was very sweet.  After we'd already selected more pastries than we could reasonably eat, we noticed the third display case towards the back, full of gorgeous and delicate looking neopolitan things and other layered pretty pastries. Holy cow! This is now my "MUST DO" stop when visiting San Francisco. Mmmmmmm. Thank you! 

There's a Giant sign out front that reads RUSSIAN BAKERY. Honestly, I had trouble finding it on yelp, as I didn't realize it had a longer name than just that. But I knew it was on Geary, so tracked it down. Thanks for existing and being full of deliciousness.
author: Tracy M.

description:
I had my first piroshki and first experience with Russian food here. Therefore I'm not really qualified to compare Russian food.

However, I can say that the piroshkis that I have tried were really good. I've had the cabbage, meat, and cheese ones. I liked all three. I'm not a big meat person but meat was definitely my favorite (super flavorful). Also, the bread encasing the filling reminds me of a Chinese fried donut, something I never have often enough of. Eating them is like a trip down memory lane. 

I've also had this poppy seed bread that was good but not great. The service was just...average.

I've gone back at least twice and will still be going back.
author: Lily Z.

description: 3.5 stars. Not the same as Piroshky Piroshky... not even close. I tried the cabbage, beef, and mushroom-egg piroshkies. I'm not the Russian bakery expert (please Russian mafia, I don't mean no harm...), and this review is just for their piroshkies. They're good, and perhaps even pretty great for $2.00 a pop, but if you've been to Piroshky Piroshky in Seattle and are looking for a similar experience, I am sorry to say you will not find it here. Sounds like from the other reviews their cakes are the right thing to try..........
author: Joanne Y.

description:
The neighborhood has about a half dozen Russian delis and shops, all selling Russian Jewish fare (smoked mackrel, carrot salad, challah bread, etc).  This bakery sells fried piroshkis, which are significantly more oily to handle than the baked variety.  

We tried the mushroom piroshky, which was very good.  The potatoe ran out when we got there, though we wish we had gotten it.  We ordered one cabbage piroshki each, which turned out to be a disappointment because it wasn't the buttery delicious cabbage filling that we had expected - it was stuffed with sauerkraut.  

The sweet deserts looked tempting.  We ordered the poppy seed which was a bit more sugary than I liked.  The bomb (chocolate and rum cake) looked good, and the mother-in-law looked curious, maybe next time!
author: Di Yin L.

description: This bakery is a unique and thriving place that is wonderful! I'm not a huge pastry person, but the poppy seed pastries are my fav from this place.  The prices are very low, which makes it even more of a treat.  This is not a place you go for low-carb anything.  But it's a tasty and great cultural experience once in a while.  I've been going here every so often for many years, and it always puts a big smile on my face!
author: Gregg L.

description:
Cool, this place still exists!
I used to go there whenever I got the chance when I lived in the south bay.
Their piroshkies are, yes, greasy, but nothing can beat them and I still crave for them.
author: Miwako T.

description: Been going here for years since I accidentally went in because I needed a quick bite to eat. I love the Piroshki here. It's made daily, super cheap, and delicious. It's one of the best bang for buck meals in SF. Try the Potato Piroshki!
author: Ron R.

description:
I came to little Russia for the first time. My friend took me here.
I never try Russian sweets before.  I and my friend were pick a chocolate cake for desert. It was so good! 
I want to eat a different flavor of cake next time :)
author: Ria D.

description:
One of my best friends is from Ukraine, and his mother always makes amazing Russian food. This bakery, so far, is comparable to her cooking.

The first time I went in I was with my boyfriend, and we got a slice of Napoleon and something called a "bomb" or "chocolate bomb", something like that. The Napoleon was creamy and flavorful, although I needed a knife to eat it because some of the layers of pastry dough were thick and tough to tear apart with a fork. The "bomb" was some sort of lite rum cake, and it was delicious - would go great with a cup of tea.

The second time I went in was to pick up a few treats to take home. I got another slice of Napoleon (despite needing a knife to cut, it was still delicious enough to want more), a slice of "Diva" cake, a cream horn and a mushroom piroshki - all for $10! I ate the piroshki on the way home, and it was really good despite the amount of greasiness. I kept it wrapped in a napkin and it was fine. It wasn't until I got home that I realized that the woman had given me a wrong slice of cake - I'd asked for "Diva" and got something else instead. It was still tasty, though, and I'll just try the cake I originally wanted the next time I go.

Haven't tried the borscht yet, its on my list.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Okay, if I could give this place zero stars I would. 

THIS PLACE TOOK $90 FROM ME!!

If you care to hear me vent, here goes...

My friend suggested that I go here because I love piroshskis so much! I read the Yelp reviews and I couldn't wait to try. Anyways, I ordered 5 piroshkis: 3 meat, 2 cheese, & 1 potato. I was so excited to try & when the lady behind the register told me it'll be $10, I was happy to see that their prices were cheap. As I reached into my wallet, I knew I had only 2 bills: A $100 bill & a $10 bill. I accidentally, without knowing, pulled out the $100 and gave it to the little old lady (short, mid 40's, brunette with hair tied in a pony tail), she didn't say ANYTHING. She was rather rude, too. 

I went straight home and looked in my wallet and all I saw was a $10 bill. WTH?! I am one of those people who NEVER carries cash on them so I know exactly how much money I had on me. So, I called and asked to speak to the manager: Ketcha (Sp?). He told me that he would call me back and blah, blah blah. He also told me I could come back in and see the video footage of when I was there, but when I got there, he was no where to be found & the clerk behind the counter would not show me the footage. 

In any case, I am sad that I was jipped $90 -- this place left a bad taste in my mouth and I probably won't return again. And, I'm sad bc their piroshskis are pretty good. This Russian bakery ruined piroshskis for me :( Well, I give 6 months and we'll see...lol. Thank you little old lady behind the register for NOT telling me/giving me my change back.
author: Annette Y.

description: Nice greasy Piroshki up in here. The filling provided good flavor, and the dough was a bit thick. These beasts- like Apple Fritters- are best enjoyed with a significant other.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Highly recommended: cheese blintzes, cheese and cabbage piroshki 

Avoid: cherry turnover (I may have gotten a bad one; it tasted several days old)
author: Elma C.

description:
I'm Polish and this the closest I can get to a Polish community in the bay area (yes, a Russian Bakery). I love heading out to Geary for some European fare, I mean there really is no other reason to out that far otherwise. Walking around this area sometimes makes you feel like your in a different world as you hardly hear any English being spoken. There are about 3 places I go to when I am out in this area - New World Market, the Polish deli and this place.

I've tried a few bakeries in the area and this is by far my favorite. Get the poppy-seed cake when it is freshly made and moist otherwise don't bother. The other items I usually get the names escape me but I'll try my best to describe what they look like. I usually get these square crepe looking things. They come with either cheese filling (slightly sweet) or a more savory ground meat filling. I say get both and then cross the street to new world market and buy some home made sour cream to dip them in. 

If you get nothing else here I would definitely get the the cannoli looking pastry. It has a butter creme filling and the outside was dipped in chocolate. I always describe them as a cannoli but better.

Good eats can be found here. Enjoy !
author: Daphne B.

description:
Sure the women that work here are not as polite as the Safeway bakery but they're Russians, culturally they have different standards. I'm not trying to be funny this is a fact.

They have huge, delicious, greasy piroshkis for only $2. You know what cures a vodka hangover a huge, delicious, greasy piroshki. I have tried a few of the sweets too, pretty tasty if you like freshly baked sugary goodies.

Go in there, order what you'd like, give them your money and leave happy. It's really easy to do business with people from other countries if you don't expect them to act like they were raised in this country.

I never thought my anthropology degree would be pertinent to a Yelp review.
author: Richie C.

description:
One of my favorite piroshki joints in the city. Arguably better than Cinderella's. Decently sized piroshki for two dollars a piece. Try their mushroom or cabbage varieties (but in the name of all that is holy, save some for me!). 

I have to abstain from giving this place five stars largely due to the unpleasant flat light and overall sterile feeling of the building that reminds me of fast food chain restaurant. It just doesn't strike me as a pleasant place to hang out in. 

Besides this, it's definitely manage to become my go-to place for Russian fingerfood when I'm meandering through Geary.
author: Taylor W.

description: This is my favorite place for sesame seed bread. I love to eat it toasted with butter.
author: Carb Q.

description: After watching Orange is the new black, I had to try piroshki. I got potato piroshki and meat and cheese piroshki. They are incredibly greasy outside(not in a bad way). But, the filling was well seasoned and delicious. For 2.25, it was a good quick dinner, can't complain!
author: Anna H.

description:
Best peanut butter cookie ever.  So delicious.  I did not like my chocolate and walnut pastry thing.  I purposely ordered the smallest piece and was surprised to find it fairly dry.  Not that it's a bad thing - it might be one of those types of pastries that is made for dipping into coffee or something.  It just didn't suit the taste buds of what I was looking for.

To the poster to gave them one star for not selling her a box to carry her own baked goods to a party, sorry, but that's completely ridiculous.  Rate them on what their business is about, not because they didn't satisfy what was, quite frankly, a silly request.
author: Tamar D.

description:
I've never purchased any of their bakery items, but I went in there today because, after all, it IS one of my local bakeries. 

I am going to a dinner party tonight and so I made my own baked goods and just wanted a couple of those cute pink boxes to transport them in. I went in and asked the woman behind the counter if I could buy 2.

I could tell she thought it was strange but, she said Yes, I could buy some boxes for 50 cents each. Great! I was really happy so I took out my money to pay for them and decided I wanted 3.

When I said that, she said, oh, wait, let me ask my boss first. Which is annoying because A. she already said she'd sell them AND B. she gave me a price for them.

She came back and told me her boss said no, I can't buy any boxes and then totally ignored me and went on to help the next customer.

At first I thought to leave but, it being my first experience there, I was absolutely PERPLEXED at the fact that ANY business owner doesn't want to accept money for his business. 

I was polite and asked to speak to the woman who said I couldn't buy the boxes, she laughed at me and said no, continuing to help the other customer.

So I said EXCUSE ME, I said that I would like to SPEAK with the MANAGER. And as the woman behind the counter was telling me she was so busy, the "busy manager" walks out from the back on her cell phone.

Extremely professional. While she continues to hold her phone to her ear she tells me emphatically that they are a BAKERY, they don't sell BOXES! 

After she yells at me that they DON'T SELL BOXES I begin to walk out but then realize that I don't know the name of this horrible place where they treat their customers so poorly.

I walked back in and asked the manager what the name of the place was, she and the woman behind the counter looked at each other blankly. I repeated myself 3 times before she first of all lied to me about the name of the bakery and second of all the owner of the store, who she says she was on the phone with magically answered the phone she had been on the entire time and said I could buy some boxes.

By this time I was already out the door. I will NEVER go back there again.
author: Aili P.

description: They have a lot of delicious breakfast snacks as well as ordering personalized cakes. I definitely will be here to get my cake for my niece birthday.
author: Krystal S.

description: Great Russian Bakery filled with different goodies! My favorite are the piroshki. Either the cheese, meat or potato one, you can't go wrong! And very reasonable prices.
author: Nadezhda R.

description:
Most of the food sold here is super greasy, unhealthy, not fresh. Some items might be from yesterday or the day before and nobody will tell you that, and the price is the same. Even if a batch of pastries come out of the bakery looking like mash potatoes they do not hesitate to sell it.
Choose carefuly, ask how fresh it is and you could still enjoy some things (Napoleon--nothing close to Asian food , but good).
author: Grish O.

description:
LOVE this place. I working on making it a weekly Saturday routine to walk to this place for breakfast! (I miss being able to just pick up something from the bakery and eat it on your way to wherever you go).

Great products
author: Em S.

description:
Asked for six large poppyseed buns, and one pound of the small ones. Got six large at LEAST day-old, hard, dry, stale tasteless poppyseed buns and one (1) single small one. I was charged full price for the six large buns. Upon arriving home to cut up and share the buns, I realized I was double charged for stale bread and didn't get the one pound of small ones at all.

Went back to the store, to explain, the girl at the counter made no offer of exchange or compensation and kept asking what I wanted her to do. I was surprised, and expressing a desire for fresh poppyseed buns or half my money back. The bakery chef, overhearing this, came from the back, angry and waving his arms aggressively. He said he baked them last night, he kept yelling at me, "are you calling me a liar?!". He even came from behind the counter, physically coming toward me, yelling in an intimidating manner, telling me to leave the store.

I was disappointed by the quality and price of the baked goods, but really saddened and disgusted by the crass aggression and completely unprofessional lack of integrity by the chef. I've been coming here sporadically for over ten years, whenever I'm in the neighborhood. 

I won't return. There are too many other options.
author: Adam R.

description:
I'm not sure I know how to judge Russian baked goods accurately, so bear with me. This place has the brand-spankin'-new feel, in that the walls are too white and the floor is too clean and the chairs skid noisily against the linoleum floor, which means it doesn't have that inherent bakery warmth, but I'm sure it'll get there. As will the girl behind the counter, who was very sweet but seemed a little overwhelmed at the prospect of serving all the people who randomly piled into this bakery at like 9pm on a Sunday. 

Anyway, why two stars? Well, I bought a lot of things (for friends I SWEAR) here--a cake slice, a cookie, a cherry turnover, a merengue, an almond horn--and I wasn't overly impressed with any of them. They were beautifully baked, to be sure, but none of the flavors from any of the pastries really jumped out at me. It seemed more presentational than delectable, which is unfortunate. Dessert should not be bland. Ah, well. Better luck next batch(es).
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Poppy Seed Roll was poppin off this A.M.

A fluffy soft buttery sweet dough with a hint of hazelnut in the sweet poppy seed filling. Not to mention the large $2 roll was still warm at 8 a.m. after I crossed the GG Bridge and posted up at my favorite bench that overlooks the bay. If watching a sunrise over the bay with a coffee in one hand and delicous pastry in the other isn't on the 7x7 list then nothing should be.

I'll admit I naively arrived at this bakery with low expectations looking for Kolaches which is actually a Czech thing not Moscow-an? but this roll was the next best thing. The type of bread and choice of filling is a close kin to the Kolache. Now if they took this roll and filled it with Jalapeno, Cheese and Spicy Country Sausage I would've died and gone to the Hill Country. Oh Well we can't have everything.

Oh yea the Cheese Piroshkis MEH... If you're gonna fry something up it should be at least half way hot and fresh otherwise though shalt be cast away to a truck stop display case in the far reaches of town.
author: R J.

description: Holy Hell!  Always a fan of bakeries, I couldn't resist checking this place out.  And it did not disappoint.  The pastries were full of amazing flavor.  Just thinking about it makes me wanna drive 20 minutes to the Richmond for a poppy seed or sour cherry danish.  Maybe I just made a plan for this AM?
author: Ivan L.

description:
I have been coming here for the past 8 years or so, for the European baked goods. The service is still friendly and warm, but something has happened to the food. The various things I used to order seem to have lost their flavor. The fried piroshki or blintz used to be light and flavorful - now they taste greasy and heavy. The cakes just taste plain (did they cut on the amount of filling they stuff in?).
After my last visit, I realized that all my recent visits hd been a disappointment.  I wish they would bring their old baker back (if people had changed).
author: Ben D.

description: I found this amazing little bakery years ago. I have only tried their piroshki's, after all it is a Russian Bakery. They are the best piroshki's I have ever had. Only $2.00. And it is a meal in it's self! They are huge! I read other reviews saying they are a bit greasy and I have to disagree. I think they are the best you can get! Just go there & try one out! It's just $2.00!
author: Heather D.

description: The pastries are too dry for my taste. The fruit jerky, though, when they have it, is amazing.
author: Denise N.

description:
Came here late afternoon, so perhaps if I came in the morning, breads would be fresher. 

There weren't a lot people, but the service still made me feel rushed (and somewhat snubbed just for taking a minute to look at what I want). 

I had piroshki in Seattle's Pike Place Market "Piroshki, Piroshki" and it set the bar pretty high, so I wanted to continue trying out others to compare. This place's piroshki looked good, but dang, after a couple of minutes, you can see the oil and grease seep out and saturate the WHOLE paper bag it was in. ECK. I don't remember Seattle's piroshki being so oily (well, maybe it's because Seattle's was baked and here it's fried...but now I know, I think I prefer baked).

We also got their small challah bread (somewhat stale - but I DO see how challah bread is great for french toast), walnut and cinnamon bun (again, sort of stale but would taste good warmed up), and a meringue (i thought the different colors meant different flavors, but it had no flavor). All for $6, so prices are good.

I'd like to come back and try more, especially the poppy seed roll, because when I came in, everything looked quite appetizing. I just wish they were kinder to those of us who might appear naive but are curious enough to come in and eat!
author: Hana K.

description: Not many of my friends know about this place.  I used to live on 25th Ave. and Geary and my mom took me here a couple of times when I was younger.  I recently revisited this place and the stuff here is still so good.  I usually get the mushroom, potato, or cheese piroshki.  The mushroom is probably my favorite, but the potato is good too.  The cheese blintz is great tasting too- the crap they sell at trader joe's does not even compare.  If you have a sweet tooth, I would have the Napoleon Cake.  It's bomb!  The only downside to this place is that everything is greasy as hell. So good though.  Will come here when I get the chance again. :)
author: Victor L.

description: Worth the hour drive! Best Piroshki's ever! My fav is the beef and cheese piroshki! I will definitely come back next time I am in San Francisco!
author: Gon E.

description:
This is an awesome little gem in the Richmond. I LOVE the beef piroshki! I could seriously munch on them all day long. I tried the cheese prioshki too-- it wouldn't hurt to skip them. 

I also love the little cheese pastries... we were lucky to have them straight from the oven! SO GOOD.
author: Cheryl C.

description: So spent the day wandering around the city and started craving Russian goodies so ended up at Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery.  We were not disappointed took awhile to decide from all the choices!   Ended up with some Beef Piroshki for savory and am assortment of sweets to take away.   I couldn't resist the giant meringues!
author: Michele R.

description: I checked out this place thanks to all the good yelp ratings. I was craving another piroshki after my earlier trip to seattle. My husband and I tried out their cabbage piroshki (yummy!), potato piroshki (slightly bland but satisfies your carb cravings) and the meat filled one (nicely spiced, I took a bite and liked it although I dont eat meat). We took their poppy seed roll home and enjoyed a good breakfast for the next three days. All for a price of 12$, cant be beat.
author: Meghna G.

description: This is my favorite bakery because every time I've bought something here it has been fresh, delicious and cheap. There is a five dollar minimum, or something like that, for credit card transactions, but I assure you you will not have a hard time picking a little something extra to meet the minimum. The hallah bread is delicious, the pirozhki are right on, any filling you choose is good. The things with cottage cheese inside, the roll with the apple or cherry filling, all of it is great. Sweet or savory, you won't go wrong. If you need cheaper bread for something you're making, for example, they have day-old loaves for like a dollar. Also they have these biscotti type things (suhari) that are sold in huge bags, mmm! The speak russian and english and you can get a coffee too. My next thing to try here is the stuff in the display to the right of the register.
author: Yolanda Y.

description:
A lovely old-world bake shop with the ultimate comfort food. The Hamantashen (I don't know if that's what they call them here, but you know, triangular cookies with poppy seed filling) are MASSIVE. Try the "milky bird" cake too.

Yeah, it was all a bit oily, but...it's a bakery. You don't eat there if you care about fat! And they take credit cards for purchases of $10 or more. I could have spent $100 if money was no object, everything looked so good!
author: Julia K.

description: This is the only place i have been getting my piroski with meat for the last few years! It is amazing!!
author: Kevin N.

description:
Was daydreaming on the 38 Geary today and ended up all the way on 20th Ave!  But this turned out to be a blessing in disguise, since I got off the bus right in front of this Russian Bakery. Woohoo!! 

I was craving some sweets, but also picked up a $2 meat piroshki. What a steal!  The piroshki was placed in a paper bag and heated in the microwave.  Upon first bite, I experienced a savory oily chewy dough that reminded me a bit of Chinese donuts (the kind you dip in congee).  A few more bites later, I can taste the salty ground meat which complimented the bread really well, probably one of the best ones I've had in my ONLY piroshki experience. =) After I gobbled it up, I wanted another one but controlled myself! Warning: don't try to eat 2 at one sitting or you may die on the spot.

Oh and I also tried a pastry that I forgot the name of, but it had multiple layers of alternating cream and cake topped with chocolate cream.  This was a little disappointing, since it was deceivingly dry and required a milk chaser to down it.  It spent some time in my fridge since I was not able to finish it in one sitting.  When I got hungry about 40 hrs later, it had turned into a piece of brick.  okay, a flaky piece of brick.
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
Heard by the KGB outside the Kremlin:
First soldier: Vhat do you do in the summer, comrade?
Second soldier: I vait for the vinter.

Like me, you have likely passed by this authentic Russian bakery a hundred times. It was only tonight as I was walking on Geary after a mediocre meal at Khan Toke that my friend and I noticed it. It's a compact place with what seems like yards and yards of yummy-looking baked goodies. It was like watching the Soviet version of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", and the bulbous Augustus Gloop has become a KGB agent gorging himself on all the available sweets. Just looking at the huge variety and the piles of each kind of pastry made me feel like the fat was going to attack me whether I ate anything or not.

In a way, it was probably good they all had unpronounceable names.... tkemaly... khachapury.... perashky... papycid. We decided not to order anything we couldn't pronounce. That limited us severely leaving us with something called a "horn" ($1.50), a rather large cone-shaped pastry filled abundantly with creme, and the cherry neapolitan ($2.00), which was a multi-layered, flaky pastry with a fresh cherry compote filling. Both were extremely tasty and admittedly quite heavy. In fact, the flimsy plastic forks they gave us could barely pierce the density of these treats.

There is no Californication done to these sweets...no, no, these taste like old-country favorites with all the calories amassed without apology. By the way, the Russian bread looked amazing, and judging by the number that came in and out as we were perusing the pastry case, it seems to be the top item for the locals. Before you take yourself away to a non-fat gulag of your own making, give this bakery a try. And then you'll realize why all the peasant women in that fashion show in the old Wendy's commercial were of sizable girth. 

FOOD - 4.5 stars...an unending sea of huge pastries 
AMBIANCE - 1 star...what ambiance?
SERVICE - 4 stars...an unsmiling young woman, sans babushka, served us but she packaged our goodies nicely.
OVERALL - 4 stars
author: Ed U.

description:
Alright. I love piroshkis. Especially these.

The bread itself is greasy deliciousness, and it really reminds me of the Chinese fried breadsticks used with soy milk or porridge. Now take that bread and inject it with a delicious filling (I stick with the meat because I like animals). The bakery also has some other ones (cheese, potatoes, cabbage, mushrooms) in case you're not an animal lover.

Yum. And the piroshkis are all $2.

Ugh. Now I'm hungry again. Mmmmmm.......piroshki.
author: Steven W.

description: JUMBO piroshkis from a bonafide Russian bakery?? My life has been changed.The meat&cheese is my new weakness. The paper bag they are housed in gets oily, but the piroshkis here are such gastronomic delicacies....and they're only $2 a piece. How can you say no??
author: Caralisa L.

description:
Everything is so delicious! It was my first visit, and I kind of freaked out and ended up with a huge bag full of goodies - a couple of cheese piroshki, a beautiful little coconut and passion fruit cake, poppy seed and cherry rolls, khachapuri (my favorite and hard to find around here, Georgian cheese bread), a big container of borscht, and a bag of frozen dumplings. I'm going to have to come more often, because all that food didn't last long!

The experience was great, not just because of the food. I'm puzzled to hear that the service was bad for anyone, because the two girls who were working at the time were super nice, helpful, and friendly. Everything seemed clean and orderly as well, and even with so much food that they struggled to fit it all in a bag, it was very affordable. I was a little too shy, but next time I'll practice my really bad Russian. There was a huge selection in their cases, so I'll definitely be back to check out some other treats.
author: Kaitlin A.

description:
I've been coming to the Moscow & Tbilisi bakery every since I was a little boy who just came to America. It still remains one of my favorite places in SF and a must if I'm in the area. You really can't find anything like this place in the whole Bay Area. Even amongst the plethora of Russian stores in San Jose, none of them have the baked goods that are available here. 

Must haves when you go here:
- Piroshki with either meat, cheese, or mushroom. Mushroom is my absolute favorite! It just melts in your mouth and is packed with flavor.
- Chebureki. When I used to come here with my parents, we would usually take a good 15-20 home, since it's not every day we come up to SF. Theyre chebureki are really good and all you have to do is heat them up when you get home. 
- Cottage Cheese Danish: Basically a roll with cottage cheese and raisins baked into it. Absolutely delicious and kind of hard to resist.

I could go on and on about this place, but words don't do it justice.
 
WORD OF ADVICE: Don't eat the savory baked goods (peroshkis, cheburek) more than two days in a row. I did this for a week once and had chest pains for a good two weeks. These things are extremely fattening, which you can probably tell from the grease soaked bags. That shouldn't stop you from eating them though =]. 
Also, make sure to drink after you eat them. It helps everything digest better and won't give you stomach problems down the road.

The only negative about this place is the customer service. It used to be pretty friendly, but now everything just seems very rushed. No real personal atmosphere here, even if you are a Russian speaker. Doesn't stop me from coming back though =]
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
Moscow and Tbilisi seriously blows Cinderella Bakery out of the water!
The piroshkies were HUGE; bursting with meat and even had some kind of slightly spicy chili with it (many piroshkies that I've had are bland, not these) or filled with three kinds of cheese-very savory-my 12 year old daughter loved it. Now, I've seen coffee houses on the Geary strip offering those small, bland hockey puck sized piroshkies for $3.50 or more. So, imagine my surprize that these babies are only $2.00!!!! 
We picked out a giant cherry turnover (again only $2.00) and a nuclear sized apricot humentashan (shortbread-like pastry) which were both divinely flaky. Next time ( and there will be many) I will try the challah and the chocolate and rum "bomb." Whoever does the baking here really cares about using quality ingredients, and giving generous portions and this Lithuanian and Polish lady greatly appreciates it! :D Daddy, this borsht's for you!
author: Antoinette S.

description: Many yelp reviews mentioned the piroshki. Since I was in the neighborhood, I stopped by and picked up a piroshki with potato. It was disappointed: outside, it was very oily, inside, the dough was dry and chewy. I did not finish it. There were lots of sweets displayed in glass shelves, looked very attractive, but I did not try, cannot comment.
author: Emmy P.

description:
I used to come here when I was in high school for their huge Beef Piroshki for only $1 (back then counting carories, carbs and fat was unheard of)  I thought it tasted pretty good at the time.

Fast forward 15+ years later, the Beef Piroshki still look huge and only $2. So I ordered 4 to go, which came each wrap in tissue paper and all into a paper bag and in a plastic.

By the time I got to my car, the brown bag was all soaked with oil. I didn't realized how greesy this piroshki was.  I must of used up all of my paper towel roll just to get the oil out and it was still greasy regardless. I started to eat from the middle where the meat was and didn't bother eating the end which was about a 1.5 inch of oily bread left. By the time I was done, my whole hand was oily (I could of fry two eggs in my palm if I could)

About 20 mins later, I felt kinda sick (queasy), you know the feeling when you've eaten way too many oily food. This remind me of  eating one too many KFC chickens, Yuck! 

Only reason I gave it a star is the price, sure they give you lot of beef but being the greasiest just killed it for me.
author: DVS A.

description: if u like russian authentic food u should visit this place. piroshki and chebureki are greeat, same taste as my grammas piroshki.
author: Nikita A.

description: I went here in like 1999. I have craved the cheese blintzes ever since. Finally came back. Still worth the trip!
author: Ev L.

description:
I love having Ukrainian friends.  I always have someone who knows someone who can get me something, every meal becomes communal and everyone eats off of everyone else's plate, we talk about our faith and grow, we laugh and joke and no one gets butthurt about it, and I find out about places like this.

Pastries, breads, piroshkis...I love them all!

Praise God for the originators of the Hot Pocket, the Soviets.  The beef and potato, I could eat them for days!  But literally only days, because I will have a heart attack and die after.  But what a way to go...

Don't complain about how greasy the piroshki is.  The more you talk, the greasier your brown bag is getting and the less fat you are actually getting into your body.  EAT.
author: Ramy S.

description:
Really like how the energy of the bakery matches the ebb and tide of the day:
Go there at lunch and you'll find a busy lunch counter catering exclusively to pastry and bread-buyers.
Wait a couple hours and you'll find a few Russian-speaking retires who'll shuffle in and talk Russian with the counter ladies a little while before ordering.
Go for dinner and you'll find fellow travelers ordering mushroom piroshkis just like you.
author: Sam A.

description: When I go to this part of the City (far from everything!) I ALWAYS drop by to pick up TWO beef cheburekh--my favorite food, ever. Imagine taking a flaky, crunchy strudel and putting in seasoned ground beef (like the piroshki filling). Simply decorated, no frills, plenty to choose from. Also, the poppy seed roll is so. good.
author: Hannah Y.

description:
Every time I head out to this part of the Richmond I find myself stopping here regardless of what I originally went for.

The Russian and Georgian sides are actually separate businesses, the Georgian side accepts credit but the Russian side is cash only.  Both get five stars though.

The Russian side has a bunch of piroshkis for $2 each, my favorite is the meat one which has seasoned hamburger.  It's bread stuffed with a generous amount of stuff then deep fried.  They also have potato, mushroom, cheese and cabbage.  Then they have more pastries than you could possibly consume in a year, most of which are like $1.25-$1.80 ~ ballpark.

Now the Georgian side, that would probably get 6 stars if I could.  I usually can't decide what to get so I end up spending at least $20 on some combination of shuba (beet/potato/carrot/smoked salmon cake with cream and dill on top),  Katchapuri (cheese pie in a pastry shell - the square one is better than the circle one but both are good), khashi (tripe and kidney fat soup, the nice lady explained that you must put salt and crushed garlic on your plate while eating this...I did and it was such good advice), borscht, carrot w/ walnuts, liver pate, and/or a few kebabs w/ hot sauce.  Damn I could buy out that entire side.
author: David A.

description: Eat their Piroshkis!  More than one kind!  Eat them fresh and hot!!  They are big and amazing and you can just thank me later!!
author: Beth M.

description:
These Pirozhki are the same you see in all of the upscale farmers markets, but much cheaper and about 2 times bigger.
The lady behind the counter always laughs when I try to order in russian - via my google translator. The food is really good and fresh.
author: Pug P.

description: Beautiful place, super sweet desserts/bakeries. Very eye catching food. Will go back for sure!
author: Eric G.

description:
It had been around a few years since I tried a Piroshki so I first went to Gastronom - another Russian place and had one of theirs, but Gastronom's must be a healthier version (?) since it seemed like it was baked.  Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery's Piroshki is what I remember a Piroshki to be.  Much greasier (as in the brown paper bag it comes in will end up being soaked from the oil).  Don't know if it was because of that fact in particular, but honestly, these were much tastier than Gastronom's.      

I tried the Cabbage and Meat Piroshkis, and they were $2 each.  The meat Piroshki from Gastronom was dry and had a shredded consistency to it. . . I was honestly utterly confused and a bit let down when I tried theirs - I didn't remember a Piroshki tasting like that at all. . .  But the one from Moscow & Tbilisi's Bakery was more flavorful and had diced onions in it.  

I recommend this place if you're looking to try a Piroshki.  Next time I go there, I would love to try some of the other items like their blintzes and eclairs.  Was a bit inconvenient for me in terms of location, but if you're craving a Piroshki and have the time to stop by 20th Ave/Geary, then it'll definitely be worth your time.
author: Kahanalei M.

description: Nowadays bakery owner hired young russian female sales person who is very rude. she did not know basic customer service. bakery management have to remove her from cash register at all. it seems she is racist and not customer oriented. she exact b...h.
author: Odil B.

description:
ochen xorosho! 
Spacibo spacibo spacibo! 

Impressed? 

This place has GOT to be one of my favorite eastern european bakeries in the bay area. Yah. Better than cinderellas. Here's why.

The potato piroshki is off the chiz-ain! That's "chain" in gangsta talk. hot, pippin warm delicious piroshkis. Some places make them, leave them in the display case all day then heat them up in the microwave and hand you the greasy, doughy pastry that is piroshki. Not here. Ovens baby. Which that in itself gives them a huge star.

My all time favorite- chebureki. Think of a thin, russian empanada. It's the best way I can explain. I've tried making it myself, my eastern european roommates, although greatfull, have since opted to us venturing out to inner richmond for these amazing treats.

Last time I was surprised they had Khachapuri, which is basically just a baked, Georgian cheese bread. I'm not sure if it's something that they regularly have but it was damn good.

Wash it all down with some cherry juice and you're set!

Let me also just say- these treats and baked good are as authentic as you can get, unless you're blessed with family to make you home-baked eastern european treats. This being said, don't let the word "Bakery" fool you. You won't find super sweet, fluffy cakes or cookies that are soft and gooey pillsbury-like. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Just dont set your sights on an American type bakery here.

The women working here are great with awesome suggestions. I wish you were closer though! I don't mind the 45 minute walk or 20 minute bus ride over! I'm 'bout it, 'bout it!
author: Amanda S.

description:
I love their piroshkis!  I've had the cabbage one and my hubby had the meat one which he really seemed to enjoy.  For $2, you get what looks like just a long piece of fried dough, but inside it is filled with yummy, savory fillings (cheese, veggie, or meat).  The cabbage inside my piroshki was tangy with a hint of sweetness, and the bread was soft, chewy and oh so good (I could just eat the dough by itself).

But if piroshkis aren't your thing, they do have many other things:  breads, cakes, apple and cherry pastries, cookies, blintzes....list goes on and on (and all range from around $1.80-$6).  I had a sweet cheese filled pastry which was good, but I thought the cheese filling was just a bit too salty.  Their apple pastries are flaky and have the right amount of gooey apple filling without being overly sweet.  I also tried part of a cake roll (vanilla cake with whipped cream in the center, $5.90 per pound) that was so simple but so very tasty.  

What a great little bakery!!
author: Ailene M.

description:
OMG, I died and went to heaven when I entered this bakery. I didn't know what to buy first. I had to have a piroshki so that was first on the list but then I saw all the delicious poppy-seed treats and knew I had to try one of them as well. Good thing it's in the neighborhood because I was so overwhelmed I had to leave. LOL

The staff is super friendly and their is a vast selection of baked goods to choose from. They only take cash so be prepared. You won't have to shell out a lot of money but you do need some. :)
author: Leanne S.

description: The place is pretty big - and the range of desserts and pastry is amazing! I wish u could seat there eating those delicious cakes with coffee, but the y don't have tables.
author: Katie K.

description:
I'm a bread snob, yes, I'll admit it. Coming from Europe with everyday fresh bread, made it hard for me to get used to processed bread from Safeway. Yes, I know, that's probably the worst bread you can eat, but not knowing the city very well, that was the only bread (or that from Tradr Joes) that I tried at first. I'm also not a big fan of Sour-Dough bread, so that made my options pretty small. Soon after arrival I stopped eating bread. 

Now, after 4 years, I finally live in the Richmond district and must say, I'm loving it.
