Although Russia is not even close to where I'm from (not in distance, not in culture and not in food), I'm a big fan of their bread and it's very similar to the bread I'm used to. It's fresh, the crust is crispy and the inside super soft. Yes, the way it's supposed to be, and yes, it gets bad within a couple of days (only because it is actually fresh), but do I come here every week to buy my bread, of course! And for only $3 a loaf why wouldn't everyone go here all the time? Isn't Safeway bread $4 a loaf? Well, I'm glad not every goes here all the time, cause that means I don't have to wake up at the crack of dawn to get my fresh bread before it's sold out, but people who love bread, check this out! 

And their Piroshkis are great, I'm a fan of the ones filled with potatoes. I'll tell you that I don't have a lot of experience with Russian food and bakeries, so I'm not sure if it is authentic, but I assume it is, because I'm usually the only none-Russian speaking person in the store.
author: Helen D.

description: The piroshkis are really good, but really, really greasy. Mildly-spiced, as I like it. very filling  for two bucks.
author: Joe G.

description:
After a delicious but hardly filling meal at the nearby Kappou Gomi, a friend and I stopped in out of hungry desperation. My Georgian cheese bread and his Russian mushroom piroshki were the perfect antidotes to the shivering slivers of raw fish and dainty pickle slices we'd wolfed down next door. Sure, our pastries may have been microwaved, but it was done with love and affection. Heading out into the chilly fog, my chewy, pizza-like cheese bread was like a warm hug from a big, fat, friendly Slav. 

Lovely.
author: lindsay m.

description:
3.5 Stars

I've always got the piroshkis. Yum. It's quite greasy though, but the meat one is awesome. The bread texture reminds me of the fried chinese "dough nuts."
author: Mandy D.

description:
SO GOOD. I dont have much experience with Russian Bakeries but this was DEF. a great place to start. As the other reviews said, there was so much to choose from totally splurged and basically got one of every other item.

I tried to rye bread that they bake daily in the store- SO GOOD. one loaf only lasted me and my roommates half a week. 

Another favorite was the stuffed bellpepper- especially for vegetarians, this is like the best quick deli snack you could find! Stuffed with carrots, ginger, zucchini and rice.. I don't even know what else.
author: Sirina K.

description:
While dining on Geary the other day, we decided to grab some cookies for the long trip back to the Monterey Peninsula. My Ukranian friend convinced me to stop into Moscow and Tbilisi. I'm not really all that familiar with Russian pastries, so I was thankful to have an expert with me. It was so colorful inside, thanks to a diverse mix of sweet and savory pastries. The staff were vey friendly and patient with us as we perused the pastry case trying to decide what to get.

There were tons of cookies and other sweet things here, but we settled on an almond cookie . . .  and then proceeded to forget about it until about 1.5 hours into the 2-hour car trip home. Oops. When we finally did break into the cookie, it wasn't what I'd expected--it was less of a "cookie" and more of a "giant biscotti in cookie form". It was packed with almonds and quite large for a pretty reasonable, price. But I have to admit I was bummed I didn't have any coffee to pair with this biscotti behemoth.

Would I make a special trip back here next time I'm up in the city? Probably not--but it's certainly a place I'll keep in mind next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Raul N.

description: you can find  lots of russian deli's and restaurants around here!!! let me tell you this place and stuff what they cook is "real deal" russian . piroshki and pastry are awrsome. my favorite so far is meat and cabbage piroshki. tastes like back home at grandmas kitchen!!! absolutely and trully delish!!!keep it same way "moscow and tbilisi" bakery!!! i just found new great place for lunch...
author: Ilya K.

description: I love it here! Every time I'm in town I have to go here. I've never had a bad experience with the food I've bought or the service. It's nice and quiet, and I always see a cute little Russian grandma in there stocking up on goods.
author: Lauren D.

description: great place to have Russian food without overpaying restaurant fees!!!!
author: Dmitry O.

description:
After passing by this place for a year on the muni 38, I finally stopped in with friends to pick up some random things for dinner. Each item only cost a couple of dollars each so we were able to try some random things. We scored the last beef piroshki which we sampled along with the mushroom piroshki, another meat filled pastry, and a flat round cheese-filled something-or-other. The left side of the store serves up the bready goods like piroshkis, cookies, breads, pastries, and more while the right side serves up at least a dozen different deli-style cold salads as well as a few meat or cheese filled items. We threw in a green bean in tomato sauce salad to make our 'meat pocket' dinner seem a little healthier. 

They asked if we wanted anything heated but we brought it home and threw everything into the oven for ten minutes. It was all delicious. M&T's is the kind of place where you'll want to try everything but will have a hard time not picking up your favorites each time. Service was friendlier than the stoic service I was familiar with in Russia, thank goodness. 

I'll definitely be back soon.
author: Tony S.

description: During many years living in the City I drop by to this bakery sometimes to buy piroshki. Every time after noticing that their dough is too thick and the filling (potatoes, mushrooms...) is so small-I was giving them a break thinking that maybe it's just this time and the next time would be better. But they would not improve the quality. Today I came again and bought 2 piroshkis with mushrooms because I was told by cashier that my favorite piroshkis with potatoes will be ready in 10-15 min. Same story with the dough... I was eating right there inside the store when after 2-3 minutes a lady brought a load of potato piroshkis. I asked politely to exchange the one with mushrooms to potato. The cashier lady who was busy with her cellphone refused despite I told her honestly that I didn't touch the second one and she saw/knew that. That's ok. No biggie. Then I reminded her that she didn't give me a receipt on my cash transaction. She goes, "What receipt?" After I told her which receipt she started digging in the recycling bin and ripped a piece from a long strip of creased paper and handed to me "here is your receipt ". I just  took it and put on the table where I was seating. I think I'm not going to that bakery any time soon.
author: Ara A.

description: This...is the most amazing bakery I have ever been to in my entire life!  The pastries are beyond delicious, light years beyond delicious, decadent beyond anything I have had the pleasure of consuming.  The people who work here are also very kind.  When they added the indoor cafe interior it became even more amazing.  The only down side is you have only a card you have to spend atleast $10 which isnt bad at all unless you just wanna grab one or two and be on the go.  Im sure you friends and family wouldnt mind a pastry or two tho.  So if your out of the area, I recomend you head out to the Outer Richmond realm, grab some pastries and take a seat in the cafe.  You can also take a walk down geary to lands end and eat them at the beach (bus ride rather).  Either way, im sure you will be glad you came, my personal favorite is the nepolean btw!
author: Colzie T.

description: Wow, I just discovered this place after having dim sum at Hong Kong Lounge.. and I am in love!!! We ordered a bunch of baked goods and desserts. Oh and they are super cheap.. $14 for everything. So far I have only eaten the Mishka.. wowzers sooo yuuumy!! And I had a fruit bar with meringue on top.. wish I remember the name but had that last night and I had an orgasm. Seriously. I'm going back over and over and over again!!!
author: Vol T.

description:
Everything I have ever gotten from here has been delicious. My favorites are the Almond Horns, they are soo good, I could probably sit here and eat 10 of them, and be in food limbo.

Other than their great food, yeah they have remodeled lately, and thank god, because it was a little less than normal looking... just sayin
author: Drew P.

description: Russian pastries and desserts galore! Delicious and large variety of your favorite Russian treats. Wonderful place!
author: Olya S.

description:
Sighhhh.. I have such a sweet tooth it's ridiculous. I really don't know how I still have all of my teeth in-tact.

This Russian bakery is awesome. Cheap, delicious and always satisfying. The store is no-frills... very minimalist and straight to the point. This is how I likes my bakeries - I want to see the goods, not some frou-frou sunshine cuppycakes crap. SHOW ME THE GOODS!

Some of the best desserts: NAPOLEAN (try it, you'll love it), eclairs, chocolate cake... I know there's more but I haven't had my daily dose of sugar today so I'm a little sluggish. Pls forgive me.

The piroshkies are also bomb - a little greasy but bomb. Beef is good but I actually enjoy the mushroom a lot more. Eat it quickly before you realize how much grease you're consuming.

Please help me in eating all of this deliciousness. My waistline thanks you.
author: Tay R.

description:
I am a HUGE Piroshki fan! I have eaten over a thousand of these deep fried stuffed doughs of perfection for years. When my good friend suggested Moscow and Tbilisi Bakery, I was so excited! 

There are about 4 kinds of Piroshkis (Beef, Cabbage, Cheese and Mushroom) which are about 10' inches long and incredibly cheap!

In addition to the Piroshkis, there are other varieties of sweet baked goods, such as the "Mother in Law", The Creme Horn, Meringues etc...and Eastern Eurpoean Deli salads and sides.

The Piroshkis go fast but I can definately see why...they are that good! So be prepared to wait a little.
author: Cat L.

description: I was at a potluck when I spotted them.  There was a horrifying amount of grease on the paper and plastic bags the piroshkis came in.  I wish I could say it stopped me from trying both the meat and potato options, but nope.  Even lukewarm, I thought they were very delicious.  I hope the bags soaked up most of the grease.
author: Seong P.

description:
Wow,
amazing chocolate eclairs, thick creamy chocolate on top, lightly sweet creamy filling and a slightly crispy but soft dough. After the first bite, my Tummy Tiger was purring and nearing bliss. 
Like the TV cook personality Nick Stellino, I had to go "Stellino Style" and I powered down the rest. Growl !!  Totally yummy. The Hamantash apricot triangle thingie was buttery and excellent. Don't tell anyone, the prices are fair for this kind of high quality. Friendly service; humble looking. They put all of their effort in the pastry.
  This is the place for sweet salvation.

Before coming here, we at at Gaspare's Italian Restaurant (two doors down), I enjoyed the house lasagna, deelicious!
author: Bert K.

description:
Piroshki
Pastries
Meringue
Borscht
Cookies

I especially loved this dense nutty poppy seeds cake! It might be the reason why I don't do drugs...
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Ah the piroshki. Or the original hot pocket as I like to call it...lol. I can't remember the first time I first had one, but i do know it occurred sometime in my childhood. Most likely at some deli or liqueur store where they serve up the frozen variety. One day I found myself really craving one and set out on a pilgrimage, much like Harold and Kumar in their quest for White Castle, in searching for that perfect piroshki.

And in my journey on Yelp!, I found that perfect piroshki here at Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery Store. Their piroshkis aren't the type I remember from my childhood. Instead of being circular shaped, these were elongated, like burritos. But that's was perfectly fine with me. Just more cubic inches to house all that diced onion, parsley and beefy goodness. The dough that was the vessel for this sublime stuffing was chewing and light and permeated with savory flavors. I'm imagining myself walking out of the store right now. Brown bag grease stained and sniffing the bag and inhaling that intoxicating aroma. Best part is that they are only $2 each! There's a variety of different ones, but my eyes can't seem to wander past the beef one. Try one...you'll be glad you did...=)
author: Derrek O.

description:
No nonsense, and very cheap russian bakery in the outer richmond neighborhood. Their piroshkis are delicious and very different from Anda Piroshki in Bernal Heights as well as Piroshki Piroshki at Pike Place market in seattle (the mecca, as far as I'm concerned). Sure, the ones here are more greasy (I'm pretty sure they are deep fried and not baked), but they have their own charm. The dough reminded me more of the Indian bhatura or the Native American fried bread. Very satisfying, and just a steal for only 2 bucks, given their size. I paired it with the kharcho soup which had that comforting home cooked feeling -- you definitely taste the fresh dill and herbs. 
In terms of the sweet stuff, I only tried the cheese blintzes that were superb--like thicker eggy sweetened crepes stuffed with a ricotta-like cheese filling.
Service was fine -- friendly and competent, no complaints at all.
author: Crushed Wi Cardamom C.

description: If I didn't live so far away, I would have gotten fat off of the food here a long time ago.  I had another piroshky with meat today.  Even though the price is slightly higher ($2.25), it seemed oilier, and I generally don't like oily food, I'm still craving another and will be back for more.  In fact, I'm trying to find a cheap place nearby because it's one of my favorite places in SF.  If you're not a fan of meat, they also have some with mushroom and a wide selection of other breads and pastries.  Also, I don't think the girl at the counter is angry at all.  She just has a thick accent and was patient while explaining what was inside certain foods to multiple customers.  I like the place better because she doesn't have a fake smile on her face all of the time.
author: M. N.

description:
I finally got my piroshki fix at this Russian bakery on Geary.  Easily distracted by the rows and rows of hand made napoleons and other tasty pastries, we refocused on our original mission:  Get Piroshki

I guess it didn't help that we arrived towards the end of the day.  The woman behind the counter stuffed our 2 piroshki's (one cheese and one beef) into a paper bag and nuked them in her creaky microwave for one too many minutes.  We were handed a greasy bag of goodness.

Took them back to the car to inhale...I was a happy camper.
author: Rochelle D.

description: Just happened to come across it ended up spending 20 dollars four a bag full of delicious goodies.... I'm not Russian but loved everything will definitely be back and everything is extremely affordable PS the young lady behind the counter was very helpful
author: Kelly M.

description:
My friend Dmitriy S. took all of us (a full car and someone in the trunk) to this place while we were in SF. The place screams for credibility as an authentic Russian bakery through and through. My memory may be failing me, but I don't remember seeing any English language signs out front. It was all in Russian, and that's fine with me. If I want a place that's struggling to be hip and "white" I can go to any of the culturally less interesting or diverse bakeries in SF.

I only had a small taste of the place while I was there: I walked in, stood in line (felt the overwhelming irony) for a little while, got my sweets, and left. I had some cherry strudel thing, which was good, but not quite what I expected. The cherry filling and even the dough was kind of stiff, not very soft and savory like you might expect, and the strudel filling was very nutty.

If you happen to be in the area and hungry, this place is worth checking out once. The beauty of a bakery is that you can just pace back and forth in front of the display glass ogling their baked goods until you finally find one (or several) things you want to settle on. And there's a lot of good eye candy here.
author: Ali A.

description: stuff was good, spent nearly $30 there but lady behind the counter made a deep sigh when i requested the yelp 10% off more than $10 in baked goods. she slammed receipt down and waa basically super unfriendly after spending that much on three boxes of piroshskis and desserts. attitude needs total adjustment! be warned!
author: Pretty P.

description: I made it my life quest to find a piroshky in San Francisco that compared to the ones I get in Seattle from Pirsohky Piroshky. After 3 dissappointing experiences at other bakeries around the city, I finally found this one and the quest is over. The meat piroshky is amazing and I'm so excited to try the other flavors. I've also been trying some of the other treats which have been amazing as well. I could literally eat everything in this place.
author: Laura A.

description: I've got a friend that lives literally next door to this place and somehow, despite my best intentions, I've never actually stopped in and checked it out until yesterday.  I was starving and looking for a quick and cheap snack before heading out on a long drive.  $1 for a cheese or meat blintz?  Hell yes.  It was warm and crisp and deliciously cheesy.  The poppy challah bread looked absolutely sumptuous behind the counter....I'm looking forward to trying out more of what they've got to offer.
author: Cara D.

description: Where you gonna find a piroshiki at 4pm on a Sunday? Right here! They are a guilty pleasure and I found myself in Richmond last Sunday, suddenly consumed by a craving for one. I stopped in and they had cabbage, potato and meat versions. I went with the meat and a chicken croquette, that I never had before but was amazing. I got two piroshiki, one to eat at the store and one for breakfast the next morning after I got off my red eye flight. The desserts looked amazing with names that I will not even try to attempt.  The pricing is cheap.  If you're in Richmond, stop in.
author: Ethan R.

description:
I used the Georgian deli side. 

There were khachapuri, badrijani, kharcho, ajapsandali, chakhokhbili, stuffed bell pepper, salad olivier, etc. 

I had khachapuri, badrijani, and chakhokhbili. The food was a bit salty but decent and thick. 

There was only one person on the side, but his service was courteous and friendley. Also, he spoke English well.

I'm definitely going back!
author: Kenneth N.

description:
This is a great bakery for some less-than-common items.  My favorite is the poppyseed cake.  It's called poppyseed, but it's also heavy on ground walnuts.  It's fairly oily, but that means that it just gets better & better as you keep it for several days after you buy it.  The slices are fairly large, so one piece will be enough to slice off of for several days, unless you want to eat a lot.

Another favorite is the "chocolate potato," a Russian specialty.  Like the name suggests, it's shaped like a potato, & it's basically chocolate all the way through.

Most of their bread is already sliced, which means it won't keep fresh that many days.  If you can get there early to get an unsliced loaf (or order it ahead), then it will keep for longer.  All in all, a very fun place for baked goods.
author: Jerry R.

description:
Eric E. said it best:

"I love a no-frills, no bullshit bakery like this."

SF is full of frilly bullshit bakeries.  The transplants and the posers love 'em, but old-school San Franciscans of 33+ years like myself despise all their evil new gentrified crap.

Moscow & Tbilisi keeps it real.  My TA for 20th Century Russian Literary Masterpieces was from Tbilisi and, while hipping me to Boulgakov and Babel and a feminist perspective of Sergei Eisenstein's "Oktober", she didn't mention squat about Russian/Georgian baked goods.

Damn you Natasha.  You should have told me all those years ago! :)

Like Eric, I also got an eclair, and it was made pretty good.  I'm a French patisserie snob, but this one tasted right and was creamy as heck.  I have a few friends in the Richmond that asked me to pick up some other unpronounceable items.

Let me just say that I will be back for more.
author: Justin C.

description:
If you're into piroshkis you have to go in the morning when they are freshly made. The meat and mushroom piroshkis are the best. These are hefty meals by themselves, especially because they are fried - but they are wonderfully delicious fresh...don't let them sit, because the grease starts to ooze.  They are not the same if they've been out for awhile and "nuking" them doesn't make them fresh again... so wait till they come out with the big tray from the back so you know they're fresh. If you ask, they will usually tell you when the next batch is coming out of whatever it is you would like to buy.

I have tried some of their other items, but am not a fan of Russian desserts. Have not tried their breads but they are popular because when I'm there that's what people are usually ordering...
author: Dee Z.

description:
I love a no-frills, no bullshit bakery like this.  They have a superb selection of pastries I've never heard of before--probably because I can't remember ever setting foot in a Russian bakery before.

They make a cake called "Bird Milk" which sounds intriguing and frightening all at once, and reminds me of a song Eartha Kitt performed, Uska Dara, where she purrs, "I like to feed my lover...bird's milk!"

Rather than try something new, I wimped out and got an eclair.  (I know, who goes to a Russian bakery and gets a fucking eclair??) .  But you know what?  It was creamy and damn good.  The woman behind the counter even packed it up in a little pink box which triggered a nostalgic flashback to Donut Day in first grade.  Good things come in pink boxes.  Always.

I like Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery, and will be back...I might even grow a pair and try something new.  Maybe.
author: Eric E.

description: We stop at Moscow & Tbilisi for "dessert" and other goodies every time we eat at Gaspare's Pizza.  We usually buy Almond cookies, my husband gets a piece of chocolate cake for himself and we load up on beef and mushroom piroshki to munch on the following day.  This was the first time I saw Chebureki, so I bought one... OMG, we have a new favorite now.  The crust is so flaky and delicious!
author: Barbara L.

description:
Piroski's are the best here. I always wrap it with a thick paper towel to soak up some of that grease before eating it. I don't mind the extra trouble. Really. Do get the meat and the spinach.

The Blini's are great for a snack or a meal, depending on your appetite. Get the meat and ask them to heat it up for you. They're cool like that. The sweet cheese is not really my thing, but the eclairs are! They are usually bursting with custard and covered in a thick ribbon of rich chocolate. I love it!

Best bakery in the Outer Rich.
author: Deanna T.

description:
On our way to the Golden Gate Bridge, we kind of stumbled along this bakery on Geary St. looking for some sweets.  

Cash only, the pastries are cheap and totally worth it.  We got this chocolate potato cake - I know what you're thinking.  Chocolate and... POTATO?  But trust me, it's definitely something you should try.

This cake doesn't really looking appealing at all... but one bite and it is good.  Dense and rich, surprisingly tasty. 

The Russian bakery is very simple and clean.  The lady behind the counter was very nice.  I should have gotten a piroshki.  Oh well.  Next time!
author: Christine K.

description: Unfortunately the Georgian side of the store packed up and disappeared. That is a harsh blow to anyone desiring a stuffed eggplant. Vamos con Dios Tbilisi.....
author: Zhenya S.

description: Great bread & piroshkis, the desserts are a little too bland and dry for my tastes.  Prices are very fair, and even when there is a line, you're in and out pretty quickly.  They've remodeled very recently, and it's nice - much cleaner looking, and there is a little table in the front now to enjoy a cup of coffee if you choose.
author: Heidi M.

description:
Lots and lots and lots of pastries and sweets! Also available are huge, deep-fried pirozhki and chebureki, hachapuri, freshly baked bread and buttery cakes. They also have a selection of salads in the opposite case which I've never tried but am a little curios.

During Easter they sell paskha cakes - sweet if you celebrate but are too lazy to bake your own.
author: Tatyana K.

description: Love this place ..... when ever i am in city I always go there.... I been coming here for over 10 years and they always had fresh pasries they are amazing ..... I  will see u soon again .......
author: Boris M.

description: Their piroshki's are my favorite. You have got to try it especially in the morning or before lunch or afternoon.. whenever. They are pretty good. I have never had an old one. They are the bomb-diggity. I am telling you, it is the best $2.70 (price is somewhere between $2-$3) you will spend in your life. They are also very filling so you won't get hungry.  My other favorites are the following: Napoleon, cheese blitzes and apple roll. I love their cheese blintzes. I just tried them today. They are super good. I was going to save some for my husband to try but I ended up just eating them all.
author: J C.

description:
I'm afraid that I never actually got to taste the food here, but while waiting in line I saw one of those little cockroaches crawl from a hole in a pink meringue and enter the hole of a yellow one.  My eyes boggled and I just left... speechless.

The food may be great, but it's not worth the protein surprise.
author: Gina H.

description:
um. just as an fyi - take it from an eastern european - ull PROBABLY get food poisoning. the stuff here is pretty much never fresh - stale....dry....old. ugh.  and the women that work here are ridiculously rude.  ....i dont careeee that you hate your job, its YOUR JOB so unless this is forced labor at least try to fake a damn smile. 

im giving it two stars because i think they have moderately fresh baked bread. lol.
author: alana v.

description: Food was delicious .. Really everything was just so tasty and so Russian I would know.. Took a Russian with us and she said it's just like back at home.. Only the service was a bit on the strict side. Thy didn't fool around and looked impatient with the orders. But I would expect that from the russians-) overall great.
author: Olga N.

description:
MmmmmMmmMmmMm PIROSHKIS are so good! 
My mom has been buying Piroshki's from here since I was a little kid. I don't think shes ever bought one that wasn't on point! They are sooooo good! 

The Piroshki's are only 2 bucks and are really big at that. They are even good the next day when you warm them up. I like the meat spinach and potato one...
author: Nette A.

description: Make sure and pull the door (don't push when entering) otherwise you'll hear a load screechy noise and your service may not be as good. Other than that, this place is just like a trip to grandma's house. I don't have this same feeling with too many other places on earth. The meat and cheese blintzes are delicate and precisely the way they've been made for the last 200 years; the counter person can heat them up for on-the-spot sustenance. The guy/lady on the counter opposite the baked goods sells a mighty swell borscht. They also have a mushroom barley soup, and all types of great dishes that I am only beginning to discover, like a beet and walnut pâté and a salmon, dill and cream cheese pâté. Oh yeah, if you own this place: please use a tad less salt in the borscht.
author: Brian J.

description: Holy Toledo! Best damn piroshkis in the city.
author: willy j.

description:
There used to be asian women working here that spoke Russian and acted Russian and served me Russian piroshkis.

Hawwwt.



*one time I did find a spider in my piroshki though.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
$2 Piroshki.

Cheap, long, greasy and filled with cabbage.

Just like me.
author: Keane L.

description:
Do you know what these are?
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hak3kl6F0AHR3nau6Q9kvQ?select=VDpnCVyt3Y1GNzzaUjCoMw
Neither do I.  Aren't Russian people weird?

Upon entry, I was immediately confused by all the bright colors, so I bought the first brown looking thing I saw.  
It was called a "Piroshki"  pronounced "Pee rosh Kee" (according to myself).
For $2, you get a big slab of greasy dough with stuff inside like meat or cabbage.  I got some kind of mushroom and egg mixture.  It was tasty.
After a speedy consumption, I felt it sitting at the bottom of my stomach like a baby.  
Like a fat, greasy, beer sucking baby.  This could be disturbing if you aren't drinking beer, or if you felt it kicking, but otherwise this works out well.
I will return.
author: Starla D.

description:
This is now a neighborhood bakery for me and I love it. I had been here once before years ago and since then have always wanted to go back but never found a reason to stop. Now it is in walking distance, which is actually about 6 Richmond blocks which is more like 12 regular blocks, but this is good because I am going to need to walk off all the extra calories. 

My little one wanted a snack and we were out running errands, setting up house in our new place and I stopped here. We got an apricot hamintashen and a big round bun filled with what the lady said was cottage cheese and golden raisins but tasted more like delicious cheese cake! 

The cookie was okay but the bun was sooo good. I want to go back and try the piroshkies and a sampling of their many other offerings!

The first thing you see when you walk in is a mountain of the most beautiful and colorful meringues. I would love to through a tea party with mountains of those piled all over the room on every surface! They are so whimsical.

The other items I would like to try are the various poppy seed filled items. I got hooked on poppy pastries when I was in Buddha-pest years ago and when ever I find them I want them! 

I must go back!
author: Esa Y.

description:
UPDATE 2015: the owners have made the place much better by providing bigger variety, cleaner store, and tables where people can actually sit to eat and drink. I've no idea whether the owners are the same or not, but the store is better.

Some popular items like Chebureki and Piroshki should have less grease in them, or at least there should be alternative versions that are baked instead of dipped in oil. 


The store offers a wide variety of cakes, pastries, and baked goods. The problem is the quality. One of the more popular items is the Chebureks and Piroshki. When I bought each, they were full of grease and oil. That is ok. After stayin in the fridge over night the piroshki fat became white and solid which means its the meat fat that was used more than once. It wasn't made in fresh oil. The meat in piroshki didn't taste very good.
author: Monkey C.

description:
Alright so the countdown begins...new episode of Heroes tonight and a productive day at work..just a good monday- if there is such a thing.  Wait, let me rewind a bit.  Why am i in such a good mood you ask?  Well, lets just say there is always one place that i must stop by on monday after taking the 28 from work...da weekly piroshki fix!  

I only ask for one thing and that is the meat piroshki--tried the others and just don't give me the same oral arousal.  I was at the counter and a new girl was working, always the same experience of a lot of russian or georgian that i do not comprehend, but iam not here for conversation.

So anyways, back to the counter-girl...she is petite, looks asian but definitely more visual stimulation than the other mongolian women that work there.  I asked her for the regular..of course heated up for 30 seconds and i couldn't help but ask what her ethnicity was.  She smiled and responded with the usual response- why don't u guess?  i responded with my usual- i am not so good at this game.

She told me she is Khazakastan and being i just watched Borat at a friend's house last night i couldn't help but stupidly respond- wait, there is no way u are from the same country as Borat!  She instantly laughed, tho was a bit fumed and said she is so sick of that joke.  I immediately apologized, smiled, and thanked her for my footlong, meat-filled pie of love(i didn't actually say the last part--duh).

Okay so you really need to keep the piroshki in its wrap, brown bag, and an additional plastic bag to really enjoy this cause we are talking greasssseyyyyy.  I am so happy when eating this i drool all over my mafura, but what do i care.  A hot tea, my choice- hojicha, really helps to cleanse out the tummy of the serious nastiness i feel after eating this.  I have tried many piroshki far and wide-- no place serves it up like here--see ya next monday ;)
author: omar b.

description:
I can't believe that my ex-boyfriend's parents' bakery is on Yelp.  

I remember asking him why they have the word "Store" in their name, as the word "Bakery" already indicates that it's a type of store.  

He didn't have an answer for that.

He and his parents are psycho, but I say that with love.  Well, not really, but the food from this place is delicious.  ALL of it.
author: Karen F.

description:
By the way, in case you're wondering what Tbilisi is, it's the capital of Georgia.  And if you thought that was Atlanta...I can't help you.

One of the many treasure troves of Russian goodies in the Outer Richmond, M&T bakery is a very utilitarian-looking place with a lot of selection.  There's a bakery counter along one wall and a deli counter along the other.  I only went to the bakery side.  Picking out just a few things to order was tough, but in the end I went with mushroom pieroshkis, poppy seed rolls, and some pumpernickel bread (at least I think it's pumpernickel--it was the darkest bread in the store).  I had heard that the counterpeople were as Russian as they get here, so I was surprised to see an Asian girl behind the counter.  Though perhaps she was the Kazakh girl so many of the other reviewers mentioned.  At least I didn't get a blank stare after ordering in English.  

The poppy seed rolls, having a pretty subtle flavor, went excellently with morning tea, and the mushroom pieroshkis were perfect--the breading in particular was a step up from the dull stuff you often get at delis.  It reminded me a bit of onion ring batter, and also of an unsweetened doughnut.  Delicious, but make sure you have some mustard to dip the pierogis in.  The pumpernickel bread is really crisp on the outside, but soft as a pillow on the inside.  Not as bursting with nutty flavor as some pumpernickels I've had, but still good.
author: Wes M.

description:
This place used to satisfy my penchant for greasy goodness - I'm fond of the meat blintzes, meat piroshkis and cheese piroshkis.  The meat items are ground beef (I think I hope I'm pretty damn sure) sauteed with onion, and the cheese in the piroshkis seems to be some type of queso fresco variety (the Russian name for which I haven't a clue). 

Once upon a time I liked the fact that the grease would just ooze through the paper and get my fingers all messy, but my body isn't really down with it so much lately so I don't frequent the place as much as I did.  However, I'll get their fresh baked bread and if it's one of the rare times I'm in the mood for something sweet I'll get a slice of cake or an eclair.
author: Sus... B.

description:
I think my big-city-girl past prevents me from breaking into song and dance like Froggy V, here, but I can see how this place would warrant it! 
They have the absolute best pirozhki I've had in America (if you prefer your pirozhki to be the deep-fried, artery-clogging delicious kind). I recommend the cabbage, though I hear the potatoe and mushroom are good too. My only problem is with the beef ones, oddly. I used to love their beef pirozhki, but I think lately they've become sub-standard. I just stick to my cabbage, and I am happy.

They also have the best poppyseed pastries, so Froggy, that's one sweet of theirs that you can trust. I'm also fond of their vatrushky. 

Froggy does raise a good point about their other sweets. They tend to be a bit heavy on the lard, and light on the delicious. It doesn't matter to me, since I live down south and get my cakes elsewhere. You can't get pirozhki or poppyseed pastry like this, so when I'm in the city, I try to stop by here and pick up breakfast food for a week.
author: Sasha W.

description:
An extra star for the good ass cake! You'll have to do with my descriptions because I forgot the names. 

There's a pastry that's rolled up with a cherry filling, it looks like it will taste good, but the dough has no flavor at all, bland, bland.  The only flavor comes from the filling. 

But with the deli, there's a salad worth trying, that has rice and pickles and mayonnaise? 

And the Piroshki's are satisfying.
author: Glu C.

description:
I can't think of a better way to welcome in the new year than with running straight to my computer and Yelping the first restaurant that we've visited in the new year.

How do you bring in the new year? Some people watch the Rose Parade, some go shopping, some seek out foods for health and prosperity for the new year. I, on the other hand, sought out hang over food. 

And, I can't of a better way to cure a hangover than with greasy food (okay, maybe I was just craving the greasy food). And the first food that came to mind were piroshkies. 

On my search for piroshkies, I stumbled upon a great little bakery in the Richmond district. The selection of baked goods was large, from cakes and pastries to meat filled turn overs (piroshkies) and khachapuries. The price was not comparably large, thankfully.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
The delicious Piroshkis alone give this place 5 stars for me! Whenever i'm feeling fat, I just grab $10 walk over to geary st and buy delicious russian pastries! Pretty much everything I've so far tasted has been delicious. And the prices are ridiculously cheap.

The perfect combination, this store has. Cheap prices, delicous pastries and close to my house.

One thing, when eating Piroshikis, do not eat more than one during the same sitting. These things are heavy and will give you a massive tummy ache when eating two or more.
author: Kamel P.

description: Russians know their baked goods. I love quality holes in the wall, and this certainly qualifies. I was waiting to go to Gaspare's next door, and I found this little gem. It smelled so fresh and the variety was so exciting that I just couldn't resist. They had some old Jewish favorites, and it was so cheap. My mouth was literally watering. The fresh apple dumpling thing that the saleslady suggested was magical, with crispy crystallized sugary pieces flaking all over. I am GLAD this is not next to my house, or my cholesterol would be in major trouble. Georgian bread is divine!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great artery clogging piroshkis. The meat filling with onion is by far my favorite. The potato is much too filling. It has a good flavor but it's just too much going on between all the potato and the fried dough. I also like the small blinis. There is a meat and a sweet cheese with golden raisins in it. I'm not a fan of raisins but there are never too many. I also come for the poppy seed pastries as it's the closest I can find to anything my grandmother used to make.

Just don't go expecting particularly friendly customer service. Being half polish I think most of them look at me and assume I'm about to speak Russian and then any chance of friendly service disappears when I order in english. 

One star reserved for my all-time favorite long closed House of Piroshki on 9th Avenue.

FYI...cash only
author: Maria M.

description:
The only bakeries I've ever come in contact with are the Chinese bakeries. The BBQ pork buns, hot dog buns, bacon and corn buns... man the VARIETIES... thats what i grew up on, but few weeks ago I was very interested in leaving the Chinese side of me, and get into the Russian side of me(I do drive a Russian BMW LOL!) hahahaha... the only thing i know about Russian food is borstch(spelling?) and poroshki's (spelling?). Being the Russian food guru I am.. i ordered a meat/mushroom poroshki! WOW IT WAS GOOD! It was warm, and deep fried! What can't be good about this?  They had these awesome looking baked goods inside that I wanted to try, but i was too stuffed from lunch. Maybe next time. 

Definitely good poroshki's though!
author: Brian P.

description:
Napolean was stale....but they have a big selection of sweets.  I suggest you ask what is fresh...although I dunno if that will piss them off.

I can't give below a 3 since my BF is Russian.

FYI - they only take cash.
author: Neety P.

description:
Best fresh bread. Not so hot on day two, but still good.

From the sweets try the "potato" that's covered in almonds and the "horn." Their sweets are cut into managable pieces so try a few. I'm not the biggest fan of most of the stuff, but I just don't eat a lot of dessert food. 

Cash only.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
Great place to get good (but not excellent) Russian baked goods. This sounds contradictory, but the imperfect quality is EXACTLY why I come here- it's like walking into a mid-range bakery in Moscow, and THAT, my friends, is an experience that is hard to replicate! Makes me miss home. 

And yes, it is yummy. Try the khachipuri- cheese-filled filo dough squares, and the almond paste cookies.
author: Liza P.

description: The food here is solid and the prices are reasonable; not much more to say. Only reason I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 is the chick behind the counter always seems real angry. But she's hot, so its cool.
author: Joe D.

description:
This is a tough one. Being a 100% Ukrainian and growing up on the food served here I am obviously very judgmental of all things Russian. 

My BF wanted to be all thoughtful and s**t and came here to get me some Valentines Day treats and sweets. Well first of all I have never liked Russian cake.  There isn't many kinds and I've only been partial to my Grandmas and Moms Napoleon. As a kid I would boycott the other stuff. 

I am pretty bad at pretending I like stuff I don't esp. when it comes to me ingesting it. So to his dismay I wasn't even tasting it.  But his reaction to his bite was pretty similar to what mine would be minus the spit out. He described it as Irish soda bread with creamy filling between layers. I disagree because I like Irish soda bread. 

His sweet redemption was the eclair he brought home from M & T. Unreal, the best eclair I have ever had.  I don't think they made it here though. If they did, wow, but I am skeptical. I would come back just for the eclairs.
author: Frankie F.

description:
When my dad was at the Kaiser Hospitals, two summers ago, I ventured into this place and have been returning ever since.  It's a small space with sweets and breads on one side and side dishes on the other.  The bakery side is always busy, but I have yet to see anyone buy from the other side, which has helpful signs describing the salads, such as "beets and mayonaise" or "cauliflower salad".

When you walk in, there is a huge stack of meringues and I always say I will get one this time, but never do.  This visit was no exception.  There are plenty of hamintashin, piroshkis, and cookies, but the items that take over my imagination are in the back: napoleons and multi-layer cakes.  This afternoon, we got two cream horns, two strawberry napoleons, two "bird" cakes, two cigar cookies, two mushroom piroshkis and a few other things I think Dr. R. threw in for good measure.  I don't know why we got two of everything, we end up splitting them, but I guess this way there are extras for several days.

A word about the piroshkis, they are delicious, but they have tons of oil.  If you are an oil-a-phobe or one of those "fried-foods-never-touch-my-lips" sorts of persons, I would suggest that you steer way clear of these puppies.  However, if you are up for the occasional fried food, you will be licking your lips and wiping your fingers after having a savory oil-fueled moment.  They are like Russian stuffed Navajo Fry-bread.... mmmmmmmn!!!!  If it is not too busy and you want to eat it there, the Russian-speaking Asian-looking server will willingly offer to warm it up for you.  She is very nice and has a very sweet smile.

The multi-layered cakes can be super sweet and they can be medium sweet.  The bird cakes have a hazelnut flavored-cake, topped with chocolate and layered with hazelnut-flavored cream.  

Even though Dr. R. is convinced that Persians invented the napoleon, here they have perfected it.  Sweet and not-too-sweet, this is the perfect accompaniment to the espresso coffee made from the new machine you got for Christmas!

When you are at the Russian Bakery, you are only about ten blocks from the Sutro Park.  This is always a great place to walk off those surplus calories!
author: Kelly B.

description:
#1 piroshki in the whole world excluding the eastern european countries.
I have gotten quite a few piroshki here. Infact I would sometimes call ahead to bars that I used to frequent like "tee-off" and "McKenzies before they both had new owners and ask the bartenders and patrons if anyone wanted a meat or potato piroshki.

A funny thing happened to my ex who was russian. She went in there with her mom buying some piroshki and the fresh loafs of bread with that 
"old skool" bread slicer. The lady behind the counter looks asian. She looks to me like an older chinese lady. So my dumb ass ex said outloud to her mom in russian " who the fuck and why is this chinese lady behing the counter? and the asian lookin lady says in the russian language " because I am russian". 
My ex was very embarrassed and from that point on she stopped judging people.

Only russian women work the counter and they are very fast and nice workers.
author: Andrew Z.

description: Really good. We are always keeping our eye out for good peroshki's. We found this place thanks to yelp! Friendly lady behind the counter. We tried a meat and a cheese peroshki as wells as the blinses. They were both delish! We were expecting something a little different though we were comparing these to the ones we got in seattle @ pike street market. Not at all the same but still really really good. They were $2 each and a good size. I just wish they made a meat and chese combo!
author: Terri C.

description:
I don't know too much about Russian bakerys, but I must say, this place is good!!!  I had randomly came across this place when I was driving on Geary Blvd.  Suddenly I took a sniff and something smells good.  I had parked my car and sniffed my way to this Bakery.  When I stepped in I was amazed of the baked goods everywhere!!!  What attracted me was the variety of goods, but not only the goods was worth stepping in...the prices were cheap...i think that made it worth steppin-in!!!!

Fast forward: I ended ordering several delightfully greasy piroshkis.  Each one were good, but I preferred eating the ground beef piroshki.  And at the price of $1.75, you could share one piece if you are a on low budget.  The piroshki was about 10 inches long.  And if you have some hot sauce, add that into your beef piroshki...it is damn good!!!!!!!
author: Chan M.

description:
I love this bakery. I've loved it ever since my 7th grade teacher took the class to San Francisco to tour Churches and stopped by to get a snack. Seven years later I finally found the place and it's still baking the same delicious baked goods. 
Now that I live near the area I can try different Russian pastries. Their regular horns are delicious but I wouldn't recommend the almond one. The napoleons were awesome! I definitely recommend trying those =D
author: Allie W.

description:
No frills - just yum.  Had an almond horn and a cream horn.  I wish the cream that was in the cream horn was in the almond horn.  The almond horn filling was just way too sweet.  That said - I still enjoyed it.  Enjoyed the cream horn more, though.

The staff behind the counter (Asian) were nice and helpful when I went.
author: Lil P.

description:
This is the place to go to get real piroshki rather than those cardboardy mass-produced ones they sell in delis.  They are huge, they are cheap, they come with a variety of fillings (beef, cheese, mushroom, cabbage, potato, etc.) and they are delicious.  

Don't let me give you the impression that all the other things here aren't great too though, because just about everything I've had here has been quite tasty, especially for the low prices.  

Mmmm birds milk...yum!
author: Matthew M.

description:
Been coming here since the 80s for the authentic Russian and Georgian pastries and awesome bread. Ah the taste of the old country. Grab a pirozok or a cheburek for lunch, or stock up on their awesome Napoleons, ponchiki, blintzi, eclaires. Cant go wrong!

P.S. To Giana, one of the the earlier reviewers, these folks are obsessive clean freaks, I call BS on your story.
author: Degustator J.

description:
Breads, pastries, and other delectables as far as the eye can see! I had some kind of buttery sweet danish with raisins and nuts in it -- I was in MOISTNESS HEAVEN. I also had a roll type thing (also with raisins) -- not very moist but light, bready, and subtly sweet. 

And to all the ignoramuses who are dumbfounded by the Asian-looking people who work here. THEY ARE FROM CENTRAL ASIA -- DUH!!!! The Central Asian nations are former Soviet Republics, and there are many immigrants from those countries here in San Francisco. Most are ethnic Kyrgyz, Tajik, Kazakh, Uzbekh, etc....some look more Asian than others, but they all probably have some kind of Asian heritage going way back (i.e. Mongolian).  The charming Central Asian lady behind the counter on the day I visited was very nice and patient with all my clueless questions. 

Based on the other reviews here, it looks like I'll have to give the piroshki a try!
author: SfMom O.

description:
The Potato Piroshki's here are amazing.

The Cherbuka's even better. These things have ground beef and onions and taste like a white castle hamburger.

but nothing...and I mean nothing tops the Almond Horns. One bite of this and I go into this foodgasmic dance/walk.

It's very easy to come in here and buy a bunch of delicious stuff and the nice thing is that it won't cost you a fortune.
author: Patrick B.

description: So glad I stumbled upon this place! I will write a more substantial review once I've had a chance to return and taste more of their items, which I certainly will. I saw the most gigantic hamantaschen I've ever seen in my life. But instead I chose a poppy seed loaf, which had the same kind of sweet poppy seed filling as a poppy seed hamantaschen. Even though it was the smaller of two sizes available, it was gigantic, and only cost $1.85, which would get you about half a cupcake downtown. Since Ton Kiang is just down the street, I foresee a combined dim sum/Russian bakery outing in my future.
author: Michael B.

description:
parking is usually tough but i always find a parking spot right in front.

i'm not russian.  BUT I LOVE THIS BAKERY!

Great price!  Fresh Food!  Awesome price and taste for their Piroshki.  They have many different types also.  I always get the w/Meat because i love the way its prepared and cooked.

They also have fresh bread right out of the oven.  Want a fresh Loaf?  Go here.  I told them they should go to the Ferry Building Farmers Market so they can sell their food 3 times a HIGHER PRICE.  Over there they can do that.  I hope they always keep the same prices they have now.

I love this place and i'm filipino.  You want to try it? YOU SHOULD!
author: Bing D.

description:
I miss my old coworkers dearly: A wonderful group of Russian, Georgian, and Ukranian folks who tried in vain to teach me a bit of the language, taught me to drink vodka like a champion, and most of all were great friends to be around. What I miss most from those days - besides their company - is the food. We couldn't go a week at my office without several people bringing in a veritable potluck of Russian treats. So it was in reminiscence of those days that I stepped into the Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery.


 After I was done being gobsmacked by the beauty of the girl behind the deli counter, I was equally gobsmacked by the site of piles and piles of heart attack-inducing snacks laid before me.


 Having just had lunch, I took a pass on the decent looking deli spread and went nuts on pastries. One or two of just about everything I recognized went into the bag. Overall, while good, a lot of the items were hit or miss. The flaky apple strudel-like pastry (I apologize for not knowing the Russian names) was delectable, whereas the chocolate-rolly-thingies were dry and borderline stale.


 The most interesting items are the piroshkis. They hardly resemble the tasty little pockets made by my friends (and consumed in mass quantity by me). Instead, they taste exactly like the ones my mom used to make. The reason that's odd is, my mom's Japanese. Say what!?
author: Omid T.

description: My Russian grandmother used to make everything from scratch so I have  some memories of how things should taste. She worked at Cinderella for years and years in the old days. So every now and then I miss her and want to stop off and get some Russian foodstuffs. So recently I stopped off here after finding it on yelp. I brought the piroshkis home and they dissappeared. My stepson had never tried them and he is picky. Like I said, they were gone quick. Very tasty, good texture and didn't seem too oily. The pelmeni  and baked goods were also great and eaten quickly. I noticed my stepson eating the poppy seed bread which I couldn't believe because he is so picky, so I knew it was good. It was nice to share this food with my family. The girl working was very nice too, which is always a plus. I'm happy to have found this place. Thanks yelp.....again.
author: Jeannie A.

description:
I heart piroshki's. Not only because it's freakin meat wrapped in deep fried dough goodness; but because just saying "piroshki" makes me feel Russian. I don't have any Russian speaking friends so I have to make up for my own shortcomings. For years prior to discovering this little gem of a bakery my idea of a piroshki was a neat oval shaped doughy chew toy that Costco sold in bulk. But then, I found this place.

Because I lack in the Russian friend department, I'm really fearful of everything else this bakery has to offer. I'm one of those people who needs a guiding hand into a new culture. I mean, I'll try it but give me the history and something comparable in my culture. 

There are there crazy sugary puff thing I imagine are meringue like, but I'm not brave enough for that yet.
author: Alia D.

description:
Hands down they got some of the best piroshkie's I've ever tasted. 

They also have some really good white bread. A nice big puffy fresh loaf of bread is what it is!  I'm still curious what their other things taste like. I'm sure it's just as awesome as the thing's I've tried there.
author: Monina C.

description: Just had a meat piroski and it was freaking amazing. For $2 it beats Piroski Piroski in Seattle. The Piroksi's here are huge! Would definitely come here again.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Wowa!

I have never eaten Russian baked goods, or russian anything for that matter...but man this was so super delish!!  

All we got were meat piroshkis and I'm in love!  I mean really...meaty pastries...brilliant!  I can't wait to come back and try the other delightful treats they had.  Everything looked so terribly good.

Swoon.
author: desiree n.

description:
All I can say is that after visiting here, I needed alone time with my purchases. They were that good.

The piroshky's were a little bit greasy, but heavenly and I couldn't stop eating it, even when it was cold. The little raspberry filled donut type thing.. oh.. ohhhh.. I actually tried eating this while I was driving and had to pull over because I almost caused a car accident. I would have that donut-thing's babies. And then eat them. No foolies.
author: Mindy W.

description: I was interested in two things here: 1) they sell day old goods (at least, I'm hoping that's what the reduced-priced "night-breads" were... otherwise it seems much more sinister...) 2) the poppy seed pastries! I went to St. Petersburg for a week a long time ago, and there was a market nearby that that this sweet bread with thick ribbons of poppy seeds and poppy seed paste in it, and I loved it. I've never had it since. I was hoping to find it here, and I did... in the night-breads section, no less! So, it was pretty good, and maybe the fresh ones are even better, but I'll never find out 'cause I'm pretty cheap. And after going here, I was also happy.
author: Lisa K.

description: There are a very few places that are a pure perfection of what they are.  Inexpensive, clearly authentic, delicious.  I loved everything we had there.  You're best off ordering things that seem authentic Russian, instead of things from the far case that caters to more traditional American tastes.
author: Zachary R.

description:
If you only have $2, get a piroshki. If you can't choose, close your eyes and pick one (maybe you'll end up with potato like me). Then watch the lady heat it up in the microwave and  get a nice hot piroshki. Make sure you have some napkins so that when you walk out and start eating, you'll have something to wipe the grease off (your face and hands).

I intend to come back for some other things.. some day.
author: Yosie G.

description: If this is how real piroshkis are supposed to taste like then I'm sold.  All the other Russian shops can't compare when it comes to their piroshkis.  I found that if you stop in around 8am that's when they're hot and freshly fried, grease heaven.  My fav is the beef filling, very well seasoned, long and greasy dough.  Total heart attack grub.
author: Emy B.

description: I recently checked this place out because a good friend suggested it. I can't say that I loved or hated it, just sort of ok. The service leaves A LOT to be desired. The staff are not friendly at all, and in a place like this where you are bound to have some questions about specific items, a friendlier face would be welcomed. I guess if you're driving down Geary and find parking right in front, I'd say you should stop in... if not, keep driving.
author: Laura S.

description: I crave for a Beef Piroshki once in a great while. THIS is the place to get the most authentic one here!! Yes, very fattening with sooo much grease that you have the full day intake with just one. The Napoleon are the rich filled cream ones & flaky pastry are super tasty, try the strawberry ones.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
This is a very unique Russian specialty bakery. There are so many items to choose from. And the prices are reasonable.

I go for their Piroshki's. My favorite are the beef, although they have a good variety to choose from. And they're huge!! Only drawback is they're greasy.

I haven't tried other items. Well, not yet. They all look good. I'll pass on the sweets, and rather go for meat-filled items or similar. I need a Russian friend to explain all the items. Will visit again for a review update.
author: Roger S.

description:
Hmmm.. maybe me and my friend bought the wrong things? We both did not like our choices.

And the young 'russian' girl behind the counter was not too happy or helpful.

Prob will not come back.
author: Jorge D.

description:
first time at a russian bakery.
people working the bakery are so delightful.

the girl recommended meat piroshkis. they were great!
we got the cinnamon & walnut pastry & napoleon.

all was great...so fun to try new things.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Not the friendliest service, as is common among the Eastern European (is that even politically correct anymore? ) 

My husband and I do not appreciate sour dough and this is our source for bread like back home. Their loaves are wonderful and they slice them for you. It is always advisable to ask if the bread is fresh though. They give you an honest answer.

Their deserts have been very popular among us and our friends. Their Cherry napoleons are to die for. And their cookies are great. I have almost never had any of their deserts and did not like it. And I am real picky with deserts.

As for their peroshki ... potato, mushroom, cabbage, cheese, meat ... yum yum yum. Even our almost 4 year old is an official addict. We try to buy lots of them and we keep them in the freezer, just pop them into the microwave and they are as fresh as when we bought them.

Oh man this is bad, now I have to make the trip to SF (I live in Livermore). 

The only problem I have is that they close at 9.
author: Mona O.

description:
I am Russian and I know what Russian food tastes like...especially all the baked little things I usually got at my grandma's. What they sell there is not bad, except for the bread --- it sucks! I would definitely suggest trying so called "hachapoori" (this is definitely not the right spelling, but just say it that way and they will understand you). 

The prices are not bad (not cheap though) and actually they got quite a selection. Reason for 4 stars is customer service that is lacking...they don't know the meaning of this at that store, maybe they are nicer with those who are not Russians, but what the hell...I am shopping there, smile at me at least ones...try to be happy! 

Overall, definitely a jewel to try some Russian baked goods.
author: Katja S.

description: I stop in to check the price i think i stop a couple of years ago.  I brought the cheapest thing just to review this place it was pretty good.  I going to try to stop in more often.  I want to try the big desserts i think the most expensive thing was 2.50.  Good service not as crowd and cheaper then in Chinatown.
author: John F.

description: Worth the trek to the Outer Richmond.  This russian bakery has many delicious treats including piroshkis (potatoe or cheese) and other sweets.  I don't know if its truly authentic, but its definitely unique.
author: Kevin C.

description:
As other reviewers have noted, this is a no-BS bakery that bakes some dang good Russian pastries. You can't be afraid of greasy food to eat here -- many things are deep-fried in it.

Everything I've tried there has been good:
* Piroshkis: cheese, potato, mushroom, cabbage, meat -- all good. Prefer the meat, though.
* Blintzes
* Kartoshka pastry: looks like a potato, but is a pastry filled with rum
* Pelmeni: from the guy across from the main counter. Picked up a huge bag of meat pelmeni for $12. Lasted for 6 meals.

I'll be back soon -- hopefully they have some vareniki and potato salad I can try out.

By the way, thank you Moscow & Tbilisi owners for letting me bring my bicycle inside the door while I pick out piroshkis and blintzes. Much appreciated.
author: Brooks S.

description:
A hole-in-the-wall bakery that is culturally fabulous, Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery Store is one of the reasons I love living in the Bay Area. The store sells many Russian and Georgian pastries. Two pastries are always at the top of my list when I go: chebureki (greasy, thin fried bread with meat filling) and the small poppy seed-filled pastry. 

The bakery also sells an assortment of other pastries that you might find familiar (for example, cannoli). These other pastries are not 5-star quality, but then you aren't really going there for common baked goods.
author: Turanga L.

description:
I used to buy pastries here a lot when I lived in SF in the late 90s. Back then there was always a line out the door and the pastries were fresh, cheap and delicious. Now, only the cheap part is true. 
The listless girl behind the counter sold me 4 different pastries today: a chocolate one, a napoleon, a "bird's milk" and a "mother-in-law". The chocolate pastry was made of dry tasteless powdered mix and the only flavor I could detect was baking soda. The napoleon was amazingly without any taste or texture at all. The bird's milk was OK, while the mother-in-law's would have been pleasant were it not so stale.  What a disappointment!
author: Alina D.

description: So very many tasty things!!!  I had a marvelous cheese blintz, and they had some amazing looking meringues.  So many options and I wish we could've gotten more but we were in a rush.  Will definitely return here!
author: Shannon N.

description: Went there yesterday and had some great vegan treats! Nice little place!
author: Joshua s.

description:
I constantly hear from my boyfriend's parents he doesn't embrace his Russian heritage enough. In the attempt to appease them, just a wee bit, I drug him to Moscow and Tbilisi Bakery Store. 

Entering the joint, your eyes are accosted by the plethora of items available. Do I want poppy seed cake? Pieroski? How about some sort of mashed walnut in tomato with eggplant? I, of course, didn't know what anything was. Said boyfriend was responsible for a few things: 1. explaining what I was ordering and 2. ordering for me.

No, you read #2 right, ordering for me. I'm absolutely a progressive woman. I don't need a man to order me food, BUT the greatest part of the bakery was all the customers and the counter workers spoke Russian. I heard no English aside from my feeble whispering of "Can we get that poppy seed thing... the one overflowing with poppy seeds?"  It was a total delight to listen in on a language I'm still foreign to, but on to the food.

We got:
Potato Pieroski: Delicious. Who doesn't need carbs wrapped in carbs. It was well seasoned and just, well, yummy.

Cheese Pieroski: Not nearly as tasty as it's potato counterpart. This reminded me of the butter cheese  you can find in South America wrapped in bread. Uninspiring, though my dog loved it.

Poppy seed cake: This was it. This was the most euphoric experience of the week, my friends. They had several options that increased in price as you added more poppy seed. We chose two of the $6 variety, which were really two small strips of sugared filo gripping to a tube of poppy seed that seemed bursting at the seems. Truth be told, I'm positive I would've tested positive for opiates after eating this tasty tidbit. Worth the $6 at least once in your life.

We haven't been back quite yet, but I have every intention of it!
author: Vee B.

description:
Totally authentic.  Every time I come here for a snack or two, I'm whisked back to old Leningrad - the much younger, tinier Frankie strolling along the shores of the Baltic with dad, then stopping at the Pribaltiyskaya hotel restaurant for a pastry (me), a cup of coffee (him), and a don't-tell-mom sip of dad's coffee (me again).

I love to bring my American friends here!  I've made so many converts!

By the way, Americans, if you like chocolate and almonds, try the "potato".  Take it from an honest to Gorbachev Russki!
author: Frankie D.

description: We love this place.  We have been going here for years.  Being half Russian and growing up on piroshki, Russian bread, poppyseed cakes, etc., I have always loved this sort of stuff and this is one place we always stop when in the city.  There are a lot of Russian places in the Outer Richmond but for fresh Russian bread, cakes, piroshki, etc., (and similar treats from the Caucasus) this is the place.  They also are one of the few places (aside from Sami Rami's on Mission) to have what Turks called tatli sucuk (sweet sausage), a string of walnuts encased in gelatinised pekmez (fruit molasses).  This is not a Russian thing, but is common in Turkey and the Caucasus countries like Georgia, Armenia, etc.  As the store's name implies, its emphasis is not simply Russian but also Georgian and Caucasian (from the Tblisi portion of the name, Tblisi being the capital of Georgia, which, until 1992, was ruled by Russia/USSR).
author: Wulfstan C.

description: The best piroshki with meat i ever had! Also their poppy seed streusel is to die for.
author: dragana s.

description: this is a great little bakery and the prices here are great. i like k love coming in here for a nice slice of cake for $3 or their other Russian baked good that you can try. the prioshki here are very addictive and i love their chalahlah
author: Seaera T.

description: The staff here are very friendly and the food here is always a hit. I highly recommend the meat piroshki  or the cheese piroshky.
author: Rob S.

description:
So I can't even spell or pronounce what we picked up and ate from here, but it was SOOOO good.  I think it starts with a P and let's just go with it.  We tried a couple of the things that start with P and they were so delicous and flavorful.  The flavor kinda lingered on my breath, but I guess that's the price you pay for eating something so fattening and delicious.  Also, I tasted a bit of the cherry dessert and it was very good.   I wonder how the Russian girls stay so skinny!

Also, I should mention that this place is totally cheap.  Those P things only cost $1.50 and they are much more filling than any of that crap you would get at the Starbucks bakery!
author: Amy Z.

description:
OH wow,

That's what's fresh, tasty and so so good on many different levels.
However, you GOTTA know what you wanna get, so, its better to go with someone who been there before and knows the stuff, cause people in the store are not that muchova friendly and advising.

My 2 thumbs up for:
1. Meat and other fillings pirozhki
2. Honey cake and "mother-in-law" cake
3. Hala-bread
4. Blini with different fillings

Gotta try those.

P.S. K Gray, you might get some for the sake of old times!
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description:
So my friends came up with an adventurous idea to jet around sf and taste what our city's bakeries and sweet shops have to offer. our first stop...russia.  (Palin may see russia from her backyard.... but I can taste it)

Had the potato piroshki  and it was great... cus i love potatoes! (reminded me of chinese donuts and other chinese bakery goods) can wait to head back to try more savory treats.
author: Lynn T.

description: Those piroshkis. $2. Really? Wow. Crap. Why on earth would this be less than 5 stars? If I was a stoner I'd give it an extra bonus star. I really love my neighborhood. So many cool secret and not-so-secret places to eat. I will never be skinny living in this neighborhood.
author: Rich B.

description: I love this place. Used to live nearby so would stop by for the pastries and piroshky. I think it has gone down a bit over recent years, but I still love it. I like the poppy seed triangles and a few of the other deserts and yes, the piroshkies are greacy delicious.
author: Fiona M.

description: Popped in here as I was in the area and hadn't eaten yet since last night (dinner - yeaaa...  I know what time it is and how long it's been) and decided to get a piroshki, which I love here and they are so cheap. Well, it's been a few months and noticed the price has popped up to $2 each for its potato, mushroom, meat and cabbage piroshkis, BUT still an awesome price!!! YummmmmmY!!
author: Tony L.

description:
Poppyseed kolache, cabbage and meat piroski, meringues, and Napoleons. Fatty heaven! This is the perfect place to go after a dinner on Geary to satisfy your sweet tooth and load up on meat filled pastries for the next day. 
This place is endorsed by my Russian pal - so you know its got to be good.
author: Stacy T.

description:
I'll be generous and give it a two, partly because it is a bakery geared toward an ethnicity that I know little to nothing about. Well I know that Russian men are super hot and the country offered up one of my favorite alcoholic beverages. Everything else I know came from cable TV. 

First and foremost the staff was awful, they get maybe half a star, my question was apparently a complete waste of time and inconvenience to them. Not friendly at all. They were talking amongst themselves in russain and prob would have been happier if we hadn't stopped by at all. I picked up a "potato" some chocolate on chocolate thing - gross and a meat piroshki. See, I've done enough TV watching to know to try that. The piroshki tasted like bacon fat - so I liked that. That is my kind of culture. 

Wont head back in the near future, but it was cool to attempt to expand my food cultured-ness
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
$2 for a piroshki filled with your choice of meat, cheese, mushrooms or cabbage, what more do you need? The blinsies are not for me, but their almond horn is delicious if it's fresh. If they are old the outside gets a little greasy. 

They have a wide selection of baked goods gut it seems like some of their stuff sells better than others, but I think you will be okay if you go with the piroshki. If you've ever had chinese rice congee, the fried grease sticks that you eat with it is exactly what a piroshki tastes like - except it has delicious fillngs.

Ask them to microwave the piroshki for you, tastes better warm. My favorite is the cheese.

4 stars.
author: Colin H.

description:
The first time I've eaten a piroshki from here was when my boyfriend's mother made us stop here to get some. The second time I actually went into the store. People behind the counter seemed pretty friendly. My favorite piroshki is the one filled with cheese. I haven't tried anything else because my boyfriend refused to talk to them. He didn't want to speak Russian in front of the asian girl behind the counter who spoke it fluently. He thought it was really strange... So I just went ahead and bought the piroshkis. Hopefully next time he'll help me ask about the other pastries.

Five stars because the piroshki are so greasy but awesomely good and prices are great. They're to die for.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Very yummy pastries and danish at this bakery ... 

I have been coming here for nearly 14 years now and LOVE the poppy seed rolls and the Bird Milk Cake.

Oddly the staff still greets me in Russian which I have grown to love. 

Enjoy!
author: Al B.

description:
Walked by this place a hundred times and finally stopped in today. I sort of thought they'd scoff at me for not ordering in Russian. I wish I hadn't been so stupid, because I've been missing out on amazing baked goods for too long.

Got some little bread/poppy seed concoction for under $2. It was great. I've heard the Piroshkis are good, so I hope to check that out soon. And the pieces of cake to the right of the register.. wow... maybe one day if I feel like I really need some cake. Looks absolutely amazing.

Great tasting baked goods. Very low prices. It's a winner.
author: jared c.

description: Beef piroshki is off the hook!!! Tastes just like stroganoff. It's oily and filling but I guess living in a winter locked country like Russia, you need something heavy for those heavy winters there. The almond cookies are also very good. Have been looking for a spot around town after visiting Piroshky Piroshky in Seattle. More of a bonus... Piroshki is $2!!! Can't get any better than that and it's good!!!
author: Shane R.

description:
Poppyseed kolache just like my grandma used to make.  SO GOOD.

Next time I'm getting some piroshki.
author: Megan D.

description:
Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery - What can I say?

BOMB! BOMB! BOMB!...the good kind! 
Undescript and unassuming as it is, hidden at the end of miles of restaurants and bakeries, looking for nobody's business other than the constant flow of frequent customers - lies a bakery with a great selection of breads, pasteries and prepared dishess. The food is great, the deserts are huge in portion and delicious, and if you're fortunate enough to get a fresh piroshkis, it's hard to argue that these are some of the best treats in San Francisco.
I found this place completely by accident, and find myself constantly going out of my way to end up here. I've sent many many people to this place, who have in turn sent many people. There is a reason for the momentum, people! Check this place out.

Note:
For readers who are put off by some of the other reviews regarding the young blonde lady who is ALWAYS working the front counter...a wink and a smile go a long way. Don't expect to be wowed by her customer service without first reaching out. She's truly a nice person.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Great place to get good (but not excellent) Russian baked goods. This sounds contradictory, but the imperfect quality is EXACTLY why I come here- it's like walking into a mid-range bakery in Moscow, and THAT, my friends, is an experience that is hard to replicate! Makes me miss home.


 And yes, it is yummy. Try the khachipuri- cheese-filled filo dough squares, and the almond paste cookies.
author: lizok

description:
I really meant 2 stars but I felt bad. They really really really used to be much better. I think they got a little stingy over the years - like the Poppy Seed Roll (a russian favorite) has fewer poppies and more roll every year. And some of the fancier sweets are lacking in ingredients....  nuts, creams, etc

it's still good for basics though. Fresh breads. warm treat on a cold summer SF day ))
author: brook l.

description: This place is a nice change from all the chains. In particular I like the poppy seed danish. Also good are the apple and cherry turnovers and the apple and nut pastries. Unpretentios but always reliable.
author: B. K.

description: The food here is great and there is such a wide selection of pastries (both sweet and savory) and prepared foods.  Plus, the staff are friendly.  I went over Easter weekend and they were selling the special Easter cake called "kulich."
author: Asteridae A.

description:
I've been eating the poppyseed bread from here my whole life, and don't believe there is anything more delicious in the world...IF you buy it on the right day.  it is always always delicious, but some days more so than others - it's not made consistently.  sometimes the bread is thicker, some days more poppyseeds are glooped on...

good piroshki's too.  lovely prices.  I can really only speak of the poppyseed, but everything else here looks just as devilishly good.
author: caitlin c.

description:
When I was a kid my dad used to bring me here for piroshkis after my eye doctor appointments. I still love this place SO much. Cheap comfort food at its BEST. 

Yeah, the piroshki are a little greasy, and not the most healthy thing in the world, but they are SO GOOD. Every time im in the city I have to stop in.
author: Charlotte J.

description: I always stop here when I'm on Geary.  They have great piroshkies.  I get extras and heat them up in a conventional oven (not microwave) at home later and they are still like fresh.  The stuffed cabbage and stuffed pepper are also good.  My favorite indulgence here though is the chocolate potato.  The only potato like thing about these is the shape, they are a desert treat.  They are very rich and amazingly good.  They are a little bit like a rum ball or brandy ball--you just gotta try one!  (or two!)
author: Diane P.
