description: Just like Nana used to make! If you're in the mood for Russian/Easter European baked goods, definitely go here. We're talking old-fashion, who-cares-about-calories fare. They also have a selection of prepared Georgian foods. I can't wait to see what specialties they have for Easter!
author: Julia D.

description:
i freaking love their piroshkis.  savory potato doughnut. fresh fresh fresh yummy rye breads. mother in law cake slices, those triangle things with poppy seeds galore.  mini loafs.  you have to try this place.  it is one of the businesses that makes the outer richmond unique and a destination for soul food of the world.  

the other side of the bakery is some sort of deli that i am curious about, but have not tried as there is rarely anyone manning the counter and they are a separate business from the bakery.
author: yayoi s.

description: The piroshkys here are delicious and always fresh, beware of eating too many it will leave you with the mother of all stomach aches.
author: Joshua L.

description: Fresh beef and cheese piroshki.  Would it help to consuder that piroshki are no greasier than a slice of pepperoni pizza; less, even? Lot of mentions of how greasy they are.  Mine wasn't bad.  Some reviews made them seemed like a an oily sponge. I heated in a preheated 350 oven for 15 minutes and it was chewy, crispy, outside, melty, and cheesy inside.
author: Marvella W.

description:
This place has been my favorite bakery since I was a kid.  Best piroshki with cabbage, along with some great cakes, and cherry deserts to boot.

Can't go wrong here!
author: B F.

description: I have topped in twice for piroshki, and both times they were fantastic.  My husband and I have had the beef and the beef and cheese piroshki.  We both prefer the beef.  It was a perfect blend of beef, sauteed onions, and spices.  They are best eaten heated up in the restaurant or at home (don't microwave).  They are crunchy on the outside, soft bread and beef filling inside.  They are large and a good value for $2.50 each.  There is a large selection of pastries available.  We tried the poppy seed cake and several meringues.  The poppy seed cake was good, but a little dry, not a "sweet" cake.  The meringues were sweet, crunchy, and airy.  We tried the chocolate, lemon, and mango.  The mango had a nice, distinct mango flavor and the chocolate was also good.  The lemon was mostly sweet, but without much lemon flavor.  The service was also great - very pleasant and helpful in explaining what the different items were.  I look forward to coming back to try many of their other menu items!
author: Stephanie K.

description: OK, so we kept on coming here for the piroshkis, so I guess they were better than I was letting on.  The Georgian seller moved out, but Georgian food is now being added to the front area, and it looks fresh and delicious.  Tables and seats are moving in.  This little remodel will be nice.
author: Lulu B.

description:
Akh, Tbilisi!  Okh, Tbilisi! Ukh, Tbilisi! (Now click your heels and raise arms to the sky to do an ecstatic Georgian dance). This is not a bad place if you're hankering for piroshki or khachapuri, but I tend to mistrust their sweets - tried the Napoleon cake and it was heavy and, well, underwhelming. Go over to New World Market less than a block away on the other side of Geary - now we're talkin' Napoleon. So because of this, I haven't tried the multitudes of their other pastries. I stick with my favorites, and one of them is churchxella. Come on, say it with me: Church. Hella. Easy! Now put it together and you've got quite possibly the weirdest-looking food item ever created. These things look like a cross between a rawhide doggie chew toy and something that came from the bottom of the reject pile in a dusty back room of an adult XXX superstore around Columbus and Broadway. Y'all know what I mean. For this reason, trying them for the first time takes guts. Tip: while still inside the shop, grab the string that sticks out of one end of the churchxella and rip it out sideways. Then keep it in the brown paper baggie as you're eating it (I mean the churchxella, not the string. The string you can throw away). It's loaded with walnuts and enrobed in a thick grape jello-like coating and it is deelish. Just don't  let the uninitiated see you eat it. "Hey baby, wanna see my churchxella? Don't be a-scared, you can take a bite..."


7/27/08 Stopped at the place today and found that they've raised the price of churchxella from $3.50 a, ahem, "piece" to $4.00. So now I won't be indulging in my too-cool-for-school-in-a-slightly-deranged-way favorite treat quite so often. Should I knock off a star for that? Dunno, let's wait and see.
author: Froggy V.

description: picked up borscht with meat piroski & 2 rugelach-like pastries - poppy seed and chocolate ..they barely made it out of the store! needing to heat the borscht slowed me down a bit, but the piroski was DOA.. it did not give its life in vain
author: John C.

description: Once in a while, I stop by at this place when I crave for those Russian real pirozhki and georgian hachapuries. As a person who knows how the authentic, real russian food should taste like, I would not even waste my time on russian bakery alike stores located in the same neighborhood. The baked goods are really good...mmmm...though, if you are watching what you are eating, i would not recommend this place since most of the stuff is fatty and sugary. Why five stars? Because this is the only place where u can get fresh, good smelling, good looking, good tasting russian baked stuff in SF.
author: jamila u.

description: I had piroshkys yesterday for the first time when a friend came in from out of town. We ordered an abundant order of mushroom piroshkys for her to take on her travels and let me tell you...YUM. Another new cuisine for me to explore. This place is cheap and good and from what i can tell pretty authentic. 1 pirosky= $2. A trek worthwhile.
author: Nicole C.

description: I've gone to this bakery a number of times over the years (it used to be called the Russian Bakery).  I've just come back from there today.  I'm giving it one star because the baked goods I get there are either not always baked correctly or their goods sit on the shelf too long, getting stale, and then being sold to the public (when they should be tossed in the garbage).  I usually just get the poppyseed rolls and poppyseed cake.  Once I bought poppyseed rolls that hadn't been baked long enough. Raw dough in the center.  Today the poppyseed roll I bought was good and I've never seen so much poppyseed (usually they are very chinzy with the poppyseed -- lotsa bread, not much seed).  I also bought one poppyseed cake and one honeycake.  Half the time these items are stale.  It happened again today.  The honeycake is hard.  Hard and dry.  Perhaps they don't know how to bake honeycake (it's my first time eating their honeycake), but it felt stale to me.  I gnawed on some of it for a while and then gave up.  Hard, dry, and stale.  The Poppyseed cake was also stale.  I know what the consistency should be like and it shouldn't be dry and hard.  Why oh Why does this bakery sell products that are beyond their shelf date?  The place may have a new name, it may be cleaner, they may have installed tables and chairs so you can eat you food there, but the hardness and staleness of the baked goods continue.  I go there about once or twice a year and usually something disappoints.  Today 2 of the 3 things I bought should not have been sold to the public.  And so for that they get 1 star and they get an occasional customer who may never go back there again.
author: Rudy G.

description:
This is definitely not a place for anorexic PC foodies and ambiance snobs. I try to buy something different every time I go in. My Slovac Grandma used to make poppyseed roll like this. Wonderful. 
The piroshkis,...ask if they "just came out"...2 can feed 2 guys. Split a meat and a potato, and you have lunch. Then get dessert. Too many to mention. Go look and try not to drool !
This is my comfort food. Delicious and fresh and full of memories.
author: Mikie E.

description:
unghhhhhhhhhhhh


that's the groan of someone who has just eaten creme horns, napoleons and other russian pastry goodness to the point of gluttony.

That person would be me.

My favorite is the almond cream tube thing dipped in chocolate.

And they are open till 9pm!  that's just cruel.
author: Meredith K.

description:
The BEST pirozhki;s every (other than MINE and my aunties which are baked not fried). 

If can't get her's or be fucked making them, it's the only place I'll go. I'm also happy they got very vego options but I don't like the cabbage ones since I hate cabbage pirozhkis. But for some reason they're always out of the Khatchapuri since I only got the luxury of having their last one but every time I go, they're out.  

But other than that, that's the only bone i got to pick with em..oh and they should be open past 9 too. 

The pirozhki's are to die for, the greasy, chewy, yet crunchy ends and the first bite of heaven. Then there's the amazing cheese, mushroom and potato filling's just had one and I have a nice dopey food coma at the mo. Yeah, I know it's super greasy which is bit of downer but I couldn't care less cos everything about it is perfect. There even better when they bring a freshly made tray too but I still like the end of the day ones. I've tried every pirozhki available from New World Market and the European place and other Russian and Easter European market but they can't hold a candle to these. They were dry, flaky (ugh, I did ask for a pistizi) and tasteless. 

Fuck, they're even better too the next day (just don't microwave them for too long or they'll get soggy or bake them too long since they get too hard). Oh and don't put em in the fridge, they get hard and yucky and ruin them. 

I've had their desserts which are yummy but too rich so i have em as a treat with a strong black coffee. I also love they're Rulyet too. 

The ladies behind the counter are nice and it's kinda cute when I speak my broken Russian with them. I thought one of em was Mongolian (I was right) and I spoke what little Mongolian i knew..little did I know they struck up a conversation with me..ooops. I told them I didn't really speak it so they went back to Russian. Again, at a loss, but they smiled and even gave me an extra cheese one on the house. :)

I couldn't care less if it was grubby looking and spartan but I like it that way. No bullshit, just great pirozhkis. I find the dingier the place the better the food and quality (for the most part). 

They're even better after a night of vodka and pickles too! 

If you steer away from carbs, fats and greasy, go here anyways and sin you're heart out. If you don't want the guilt, make your own or get your babushka to make em.
author: Misplaced Bogan M.

description:
i was waiting for a friend for dinner, and i forgot to get cash, so i walked down geary in search for a b of a so i could get some sweet moolah.

i come across this russian bakery, i peeked in to see what kind of stuff they had as i walked past it to the b of a atm a block down. as i was coming back with my fresh 20 bucks... i thought, hmm maybe i should buy something from this here bakery to break my 20 into smaller bills. because of course i would be doing myself a favor by having smaller bills when splitting a check for dinner. right? heh heh heh.......

so i walk in, and take a look at a fully stocked counter and cases of piroshkis, pastries, and cakes. i didn't know where to start. so all i did was walk in a stare at everything in the cases. i walked back and forth trying to choose one that would be good. 

but i don't know crap about russian food!!!!

so i look up and see the girl behind the counter look right back at me. i think she's waiting for me to order....

me: uhhhh......... what do u recommend?
her: well, do you want cake or a pastry?
me: (looking around....i just point at something) uhhh whats this?
her: honey cake... (nah, doesn't sound russian enough....i  point at something else) 
her: thats poppy cake (still not russian enough....)
me: uhh.... (shifty eyed....) i'll just take this "bird's milk"
her: ok...

so i gave her $3. and leave happy. and thinking....

gee i hope this is good. AND russian enough. 

so i'm still early for dinner so i go to my car, and think, hey life is short, gotta eat dessert first.

so i take a little smidgen of the many layers of the cake and cream souffle. hmm pretty good. i taste the chocolate ganache on top.  hmmm kinda tastes like chocolate on top of those chocolate topped doughnuts. interesting. i taste the little pink thing on top, hmm tastes like buttercream.... because it IS butttercream! i put it back into the box and go inside for dinner.

overall, the birds milk cake was good, AND also russian enough for me. 

but i wasn't satisfied, but i don't know if its REALLY russian.

so of course i'm a dork, i HAVE to text my one russian friend.

me: hey i went to this russian bakery on geary and got birds milk cake, is it russian? i want to know if its authentic. 
svetlana (my very russian friend): yeah it is, good shit! 

NOW irene is satisfied. irene has eaten her first russian dessert. all on her freaking own.

BOOYAH.

i will be back to try some piroskis. which i've had before from my very russian friend svetlana.
author: Irene C.

description: This place rocks my pants! I'm a sucker for sweets (my dentist can attest to that fact) and these are some of the best in town. I taught in Tbilisi many moons ago and when I discovered this bakery I was stoked, I also spent some years in Cleveland immersing myself in all things Polish, Hungarian and Russian. It's too bad we don't have more bakeries like this and less like those overpriced Frenchie ones all over town. There are still a plethora of goodies I have to try at this bakery, but it will have to include a massive bike ride in order to keep myself from becoming jabbaesque.
author: Colleen B.

description: This place makes a carb addict out of me (as if I wasn't enough of one already). I remember the cold, rainy months when I would take weekly trips across town to buy a bag of pastries big enough to last a week--each time vowing that this would be my last.  Yet when I got down to the last poppy seed roll, I'd freak out and make that trip across town once again. I don't even dare to try the piroshkis. It may just cause one addiction too many.
author: Rona J.

description: The first impression I had - Gulag-esk.  The woman behind the counter pretty much grunted at me when I timidly pointed at the meat piroshki. Not being much of a Russian food connossieur, I was a little overwhelmed by the ratio of Russian to English being spoken (99 to 1). I saw some other familiar items from my days in NY and the Beverly Hills Adjacent jewish ghetto: hamantashen, challah, rugulah. The rugulah that I had was dry and day old - not the cream cheese pastry wonder that a great rugulah should be. The piroshki, however, but a greasy TASTY gut bomb that was a tasty mix of beef, onion, spices, and the oh so wonderful fried dough. FRIED DOUGH! It was fresh at the store and also great reheated in the oven.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
$2 for a giant piroshiki filled with cheese, mushrooms, meat, or -- the best -- potato. grab one and go across the street to wait for the 38 in the fog.

weird femme hint:  put on lip gloss first:  theres so much grease that it floats on top and you don't mess up your lipstick.
author: Nora B.

description: Filled with various Russian baked goods. I've tried the chocolate cake, and some cookies but I thought that they were too sweet and not enought flavor. The best thing in there is actually their pirokshis! The prioshkis are about a foot long and filled with meat, potatoes, or cabbage. Very cheap for what you get...each piroshki is about $1.75. Great deep fried russian treat! Now all I need is some vodka to go with it!
author: Jessica h.

description: Nice counter person and helpful. The mushroom piroshki and the meat pastry had a decent flavor, but was so greasy, I could not eat. I think the oil was not fresh or the temperature was incorrect, as it was sopping with oil. The picture of the greasy bag was correct.
author: A I.

description: Twenty some years in this country, I have been missing all the European bakeries. About 10 years ago I found the French bakery Grain d'or (Andersen Bakery), I though I was in heaven; but just wait till 2 months ago, I accidentally found this Russian bakery while I was driving down west bound Geary, I literally slam on my brakes, made 4 right turns, & have my 1st Hala in the United States. Now I have at least 3 places to go for the birthday cakes and not having to Kamikaze myself. As of this date, I got my bakery alternatively from Andersen and Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery Store. Goodbye Safeway & Baker square, you can keep all those icing and sugars ++++ for the GRINGOs. I am with a world class bakeries!!!
author: Norm L.

description: whenever i visit this bakery, it's a must that i leave with their piroshki.  it's made fresh everyday and soooo yummy!
author: Kae B.

description: two words: almond horn. they are beyond delicious. try it and you will thank the lords that i planted this seed in your brain.
author: Mike G.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DSu_9YuthQ

my aunt and me going to the Russian bakery... my friends accuse me of making them "fat" by  bringing them here to indulge our sweet tooth... believe me the desserts are SWEET... too sweet ... but the piroshkis are pretty good... a tad bit greasy though  

if you are an early walker and live in the neighborhood... i swear the smell of the fresh baked bread is to die for... but you gotta eat the bread within a couple of days... cause it tends to get moldy quicker
author: Peta C.

description: I moved away from SF about 14 months ago. Know what I miss the most? Is it the Ocean or the hills, or the Pride Parade or the Ballet (yes to all those things, but...)? NO, it's the challah bread with poppyseeds at Moscow & Tbilisi bakery. Oy! Get it still slightly warm and it's like eating the best cake ever. Most of the time I bought it I'd just sit in my car and snarf at least 3-4 slices before I could continue my day. I've never had better Challah, even from Moishe's Bakery in NYC. Yes, the bakery is like going back to 1986 Soviet Union. The Kazakh ladies behind the counter, the general air of distracted customer service and yelling at someone in the back room, the complaining babushkas in line, the pre-made yummy borscht in plastic tubs. I'm aching just thinking about it and that I'm 600 miles away. In my opinion, if I had to choose between what's the greater SF landmark... Moscow tbilisi or the Golden Gate Bridge I'd have to pause for a few minutes to think about that one.
author: Regina K.

description:
cheap ass bread of all colors shapes and sizes
fantabulous pastries, my favorites are the cherry strudels, napoleon, and PIROSHKI.
i am a whale, i adore these deep fried goodnesses and can eat 2 of them. they are huge.
the only thing this place is lacking is customer service. the people never ever smile. EVER.
author: Helen N.

description: They have these incredible poppyseed rolls - like my grandmother used to make. The hamentaschen is just so-so.  Love the piroshki.
author: Bridget T.

description:
One word. Khachapuri.
They've got the best khachapuri I've had outside of Tbilisi. Even the shops in Moscow have nothing on their khachapuri. And they've got two kinds.
OK, two words. Khachapuri, khinkali.
I'll admit it, I haven't tried the khinkali yet. Apparently, it needs to be special ordered. But the very fact they make khinkali makes everything all right in my book. I just need to find out if they'll make Ajarian Khachapuri.

-edit-
I tried the khinkali. I bought 20 of them. Totally worth it.
author: Ben J.

description: Great bread (freshly baked and light;  they can slice it on the spot). Delicious fried piroshki. My all time favorite though is the baked ricotta triangle. Heat it up when you get home and you won't regret it. Service can be gruff but you can tell they're nice people :) They also have homemade borscht in jars to go, and lots of other tasty things. My only suggestion would be that they should put more poppy seed filling in the poppy seed breads.
author: Alp M.

description: I've met someone new.  He is long & lean, a lovely shade of bronze, and is the best beef injection this side of the Pacific!  His name is Cheburek.  Yes, I know we can never be... he is extremely bad for me, being deep-fried and all.  But when we are face to face, and his aroma is titillating my nostrils, there is nowhere else I'd rather be.  It's a brief encounter because I can't just fondle him... I have to ravage him immediately!  Afterward, I wish I hadn't been so hasty and relished the moment.  Then I think, I could always get me another...
author: Tara G.

description: The piroshkis are amazing, but they'll take your ass out! I went into a carb coma and woke up three hours later. Wow!
author: David H.

description: Their piroshki remind me of grandmas. And I have always received fresh, soft, warm bread. Apparently, I must be one of the lucky ones.
author: Lilarose L.

description:
chocolate potato! chocolate potato! chocolate potato!
ok, i dont know what this is called in english, i grew up calling it shokoladnaya kartoshka, and in fact that what even my parents called it, because thats exactly what it looks like.
They have it, go get it, its like a potato shaped brownie with nuts and its so goddamn good i bought it and stood outside the store and inhaled it. Then my heart hurt for some reason, but its ok, cause i had chocolate potato
author: Ross G.

description: This place has the best piroshki's I can find in the greater North Bay area. I have been getting them for years.
author: sandra d.

description: Delicious treats to be had here... poppyseed bread, cheese blintzes, and piroshki are my favorites. The fried things are super greasy but still so yummy!
author: Carolyn C.

description: Very yummy! PIROSHKI are good! The Poppy bread/roll thing is real good and best served heated up with melted butter. But that Almond Horn is Excellent!!!! if you get anything try the Almond Horn!!! one problem is the cakes are not real moist.... but maybe that is a Russian thing????
author: hel la m.

description: Me and my Russian family accidentally stumbled upon this place on our way to the DeYoung museum. This was an AMAZING find. Authentic homemade Russian food does not come around that often so this bakery was a real treat. Their piroshkis are beyond delicious, their bread is great and it stays fresh forever!
author: Maria V.

description: The piroshkis are amazing.  I love the mushroom or cabbage ones.  They have to be fresh or they get really heavy, so eat them immediately.  I also like the meringues.  This place is worth a special trip to the city from time to time. Best to go earlier in the day or they may run out of the kind of piroshkis you want.
author: Maria M.

description: good piroshki, rye bread not very ryeful.
author: Fzarond K.

description: The Piroskies are $2.00 grease bombs, but I LOVE them.  The Borsct is also wonderful.  Everything is reasonably priced and yummy.  Not Gourmet, but good.
author: She-Ra ..

description: I've always been intrigued by Russian delicacies, and they're somewhat hard to find in the burbs, so I was quite intrigued when we came across this place. The pastries are fresh. I had a beef piroski, which was surprisingly good. The lady at the counter heated it up for me, and I had it to go as a nice snack. Overall, I was quite impressed.
author: Barn M.

description: 2 dollar amazing piroshkis! Like honestly amazing piroshkis. Ridiculously large filling not those mass manufactured crap that I usually associate with a piroshki. For 2 dollars! Two stars for their 2 dollar meat piroshki alone. another one for their cherry bread and napoleon cake. So I like the napoleon cake. I've never had it anywhere else and honestly it's not that bad.  Minus one star because the workers sort of glare at me. Minus another because every time I get a cheese piroshki one the dough is raw in the middle, but you can't tell until you get a mouthful of it because it looks like the cheese they use. Oh never mind, most of the cheese is good. And I really do love this place. It's bailed me out of another gordo's burrito on so many occasions.
author: Nadia P.

description: Piroshki's, breads, desserts!  The piroshki's are nicely filled with a variety of treats - a little greasy but it just adds to the flavor.  The dessert choices are all tempting.  The prices the best part.
author: Blu n.

description: You also have to try a napoleon cake. It is wonderful!!!!!! Poppy seed bites are also great too.
author: vadim m.

description: Ok, so they are as mean as hell in there.  Today was the first day I actually has a nice lady help me.  But anyway...all I can say is ALMOND HORNS!  Because of those little precous things, this place gets 5 stars.
author: Dana A.

description: I mostly buy the Piroshkis, they are really good! prices are reasonable, large selection, good service. A nice place to go for a quick meal on the go!
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: I've been coming here on and off for the last 7 years and I have to say for what they lack in atmosphere they make up for in consistency. The meat peroshki are just like my grandma used to make sans the bean thread. The cake and sweets are always winnin' and the cheese blintzies are sooooo awesome. Always a stern Russian chick at the helm, kinda like a cold faced Moscovite staying very true to the name "Moscow". Gotta love it. 4 stars.
author: Natas N.

description: Great traditional Russian bakery and it's very cheap.  Some things to try, the buttercream filled donuts, poppyseed roll and potato (which is really a rum ball).  All the Russians know about this place, but one else!
author: Gisela S.

description:
Nondescript site, beautiful lookin' pastries.

$2.75 for a loaf of fresh bread on the way home in the evening...sweet!

some nice savory log-like things for 6-7 bucks...I'll try them soon.
author: salty j.

description:
I am Polish, so I was looking for something similar to our baked goods back home and this bakery is my favourite!
The small 'danish' with cottage cheese is best! Bread is v.good! Very nice service!
author: Joanna K.

description: If they really knew their market, you would be able to pay extra for one of the bakery ladies to come out from behind there and squeeze your cheeks and mumble off into "kakoi haroshyi..." and take you for a spin in a 1978 Lada.  Because there are two ways to enjoy M&T.  More simply, it's a bakery, with some interesting meat-pies and donuts.  At a higher level, available to an unlucky few, the bread smells, the index cards stuck into pastries, and especially the surly nonanswers from the staff (bathroom? "mmmm, ees out of oorder") , evoke memories.  It's all even more apt, since this place is stuck in 1980, and I'm not sure if you can find a place like this in Russia now.  One pirozhok (I like mushrooms) will fill you up for the whole day, but there are always poppyseed pastries, and, and... nu, there's always tomorrow.
author: Non P.

description: This place is DELICIOUS!! I'm of Ukrainian background and grew up on piroshkis and Russian food, and this place is such a find! I got a potato and cheese piroshki (both excellent but the potato one is way better). Do yourself a favor....GET AN ALMOND HORN! A crispy tube-like cookie dipped in chocolate on both ends filled with a thick sweet cream... delicious. I also got a huge almond cookie (it was really thick and chewy.. it wasent the best) and a cheese blinki ( a thin panfried pancake filled with a sweet cheese).. delicious. DEFINITELY try this place out!!
author: Sierra F.

description: Growing up in San Francisco, Piroshkis were a staple. That fried-dough filled with meat, cheese or vegetables with spices that you couldn't pinpoint was the comfort food that you could have for just a dollar as a treat after school. And then the prices started going up everywhere in San Francisco as real estate boomed. And by the time I left San Francisco, my beloved piroshkis were $3.75. Oh hell no!! I was not going to pay the amount for dough and meat anymore. Then one day in 2001,  I was strolling through the Richmond District and Freakin' Eureka... I found the Holy Piroshki and at the time it was $1.25 for a meat piroshki that was 8 inches long and delicious. Not only was the piroshki delicious but the desserts were gluttonous. No strawberry napoleon could compare with what they serve and for the price at the time which was $2.00. Unfortunately 8 years later, the price in piroshki has increased to $2.00 and the napoleon to $2.50, but both are still divine. Other goodies are the apple turnovers, the eclairs, the blintzes, and the chebureks (sp?). Yes, the food can be greasy, but it is worth it when you order it, ask them to heat it up and eat on the spot. My stomach loves it!! And you know that they are working hard all day b/c you can smell the aromas floating from the kitchen and actually see them working in the kitchen in the back. They have also now expanded to making special Russian salads. Sometimes there may be a line, but it is very well worth the wait. I even wait to come home to eat this because I cannot justify spending $4.00 plus on Piroshkis in Seattle when it tastes better at home.
author: Lorna D.

description: Bestisisest kept secret in the hood YO! So when I'm with Misha and Pasha we hit the Moscva et Tiblisi Bakery for the best Napoleon "karsochiks" in the 415. Word Yo! "Dooood, vlook et ol dees pastries. Eet ees delicacy. Yes?" In plain English, the French influenced Russian culture during the time fo Czar Peter to include it's national cuisine. It is at that point that the Napoleon or Mille-Feuille/Foglie (a thousand leaves)..... cause it sounds so sexy in a foreign tongue, came in to being.  Nobody, however sweet, wants to think they're eating leaves. So the Frenchys and Italians exported this amazing pastry cream and flaky layered experience to the Russians. Probably the only thing NOT served with a shot of vodka. There is only one place that makes a mean Napoleon on par with what dear ol' gran' mummy (Babushka) makes and that's this bakery. They have many other baked delicacies, but the Napoleon is the freshest, well made, dessert in the hood. It saves Russian cuisine from the bad Borscht rep it gets on the street, however undeserved. Coming back fo mo!
author: Johnny C.

description: mmmm love this place. me and my friends used to get high as hell in middle school and order like 5 piroshkis and eat em all. delish. their cakes are soooo good-the eclairs and i dont know what the others ones are called but their all good! although i cant eat ANYTHING that i used to eat in middle school (dietary reasons), i still let myself cheat once in a while and come to get their......i dont remember what their called but they are these cannoli looking things with custard in the middle and chocolate on the outside.  TO DIE FOR.  i highly suggest getting wasted and coming here-nothing hits the spot when ur high like a fried greasy meaty cheesy piroshiki.
author: Renee S.

description: after food poisoning and offering to buy the owner a Napoleon to watch her eat and have her be offended and not be willing to eat her own food, IT SAYS ALOT when an owner/baker is not willing to eat their own stale product even when their customer pays for the sample....great stale Napoleons & Apple strudle...NOT!  this place is the Chernobyl of Russian Bakeries in SF!!!
author: michael d.

description: My arteries squeal with joy whenever I consume hot, delicious, cheese piroshki out of a paper bag from Moscow & Tbilisi.  I don't think you can find better comfort food, especially when you're out in those cold, foggy avenues.  Their pastries also hit the spot, especially the giant, slightly sweet poppyseed roll that looks almost like a giant rugelach.
author: Alyson Y.

description: I used to go here with my mother after dentist appointments when I was ten. This place is the best. If you don't know what you're looking at, take the plunge. I have yet to have something that i didn't like. Breads, cakes, whatever you want. Delicious.
author: Matthew P.

description: Oh my god this place is orgasmic.  I dont care whether this place is authentic or not, the pastries are fuking awesom.  I would probably reccomend everything because i havnt had anything that wasnt mouth watering.  Its uber cheep too.
author: Daniel P.

description: Growing up in New York, I had a lot of exposure to Eastern European and Russian baked goods.  But I found this place quite disappointing.  I thought the bakery items were rather tasteless.  The honey cake I tried was bland expect for the few raisins here and there and wasn't very cakey.  I also tried a pale pastry thing that had some sour cherry and walnut filling (looked a bit like strudel, but with much, much heavier dough), and the dough tasted like stiff cardboard while completely overwhelming what little filling was in there.  The piroshki were a little better, but not much.  While it reconstituted itself pretty well in the toaster oven, achieving a nice crisp outside and doughy inside, again, the flavors were too subtle for my taste.  I found the service friendly, but very slow at the time I was there, and the overall ambiance of the bakery would not be out of place in the old Soviet Union.  I ate Russian pastries in Moscow and St. Petersburg, and they were way better than this, and my first wife's grandmother, who was Georgian, could bake circles around this place.
author: Mark H.

description: when it's plain looking inside and smells yummy like that walking in, you know they're all about business and it's all made fresh.  don't be scared to ask the russian counter girl questions, she's helpful as long as she understands your questions.  for all my non-egg readers that don't know a lot about russian foods, the piroshkis are egg free except the mushroom one.   kinda greasy though.  and if she warms it up for you, don't expect it to be hot, just warm, a little warm.  good place to stop in and try, but i may not be back but only because i'm not into those kinds of foods.
author: Monk R.

description: Ok folks...my husband and I have to say, we would hop on a plane and fly to San Francisco from Seattle to get our most absolute favorite treat in the world that graces the Moscow & Tbilisi bakery. The dream inducing, mouth watering, love of my life, ALMONDS HORN!!! You have to try it to believe it. I am a true lover of only the most decadent of sweets but this little beauty has my heart. It is the perfect combination of a buttery, chewy, almond cookie, ever so thinly rolled into a precious tube. The tube is then filled with a light and sweet creme. The delight is then dipped in chocolate on either side. When you bite into the divinity, the cream gooshes into your mouth with smooth harmony, balancing against the buttery chewy almond heaven(with a little hint of salt). The dark chocolate adds another layer of beauty. My husband talks about the Almonds Horn all of the time. If this place would ship, we would become a loyal customer. Whenever we visit San Francisco, this is the first place we go. Long live the Moscow & Tbilisi Bakery!!!
author: Tracy H.

description: Great place for cheap eats. 2 bucks gets you a piroshky, potato is the best but you can also get meat, cheese or mushroom. The horns and eclairs are good really good too.
author: Nadezda K.

description:
Dam I wish I never discovered this place either...because it is bad. I had four items there 3 of them went to garbage right away
Poppy-seed roll, it was awful - no flavor, no taste. The dough is hard and tasteless, some yellow color added to look like it has eggs in it but it is all water, flour and yeast., no other ingredients. I made a bite and had to throw it away. 
Baklava followed the roll - one glance was enough to suspect that it is not edible - it looked like it was made last year, no nuts or any other filling visible...
Meat piroshki - the filling was juicy and  I liked the taste, 1 star for it, the dough was not good though, again they seem to save on things that make pastries so good I mean eggs and milk
Eclair - I saved it in the frig for the morning and when I opened the box...all the icing went down in the box, etc. No wonder their prices are kind of low. This place has nothing to do with authenticity. Looks good tastes bad. The service is far from being perfect too.

I am Russian and new in the city .For real taste of Russia my friends recommended a bakery on Balboa "Cinderella" We'll see.
author: Lidia F.

description: one thing i hate about good bakeries in the city is that they're WAY overpriced and you have to wait in line with army of yuppies and/or hipsters, get a foot run over by a designer workout gear sporting noe valley mom with a $1,000 stroller and listen to some god-awful neo folk band or guitar strumming feminist before you can partake in your sweet, wonderful confection. not this place. this is a real old world style bakery run by (i assume from the name) georgians and russians. after the french, the best bakers in the world are from the former soviet union and this place lives up to that reputation. i got a napoleon and an eclair. the napoleon was sweet and delightfully flaky and the eclair was soft, had rich chocolate and wonderful, velvety custard with hints of brandy. the only thing that sucked was that my friend and i had to go sit on the curb to enjoy our delicious treats because there was no place to sit inside.  other than that, this place rocks. if you want great, traditional, european pastries without all the "atmosphere" and high prices, it's worth a trip out to the richmond. i haven't tried any of the savories, but i'll save that for next time.
author: cyrus t.

description: fantastic little gem in this gem of a food neighborhood. traditional no-frills russian bakery. potato piroshki is doughy, filling and delicious, ask them to warm it up for you. the meat blintzes are worth a try as well. this place is also dirt cheap. i HIGHLY recommend this bakery.
author: Lesley S.

description: yummy breads, but definitely try the mushroom piroshki!  great texture play with the bread and the filling.  try it heated, you'll see what i mean.
author: meijan w.
